*Saffron Walden, St Albans, St Briavels, St Ives (Cornwall), Salisbury, Saltash, Sandwich, Scarborough, Seaford, Shaftesbury, Sheffield, Sherbourne, Shrewsbury, Southampton, South Molton, Southwark, Southwell, Southwold, Stafford, Stamford, Stockton-on-Tees, Stratford-upon-Avon, Sudbury, Sunderland, Sutton Coldfield
*Tamworth, Taunton, Tenterden, Tewkesbury, Thaxted, Thetford, Tintagel, Tiverton, Torksey, Torrington, Totnes, Tregony, Truro

*Wainfleet, Wallingford, Walsall, Warwick, Wells (Somerset), Wenlock, Weymouth, Whitchurch (Hampshire), Whitchurch Canonicorum (Dorset), Wigan, Wilton, Winchester, Windsor, Wisbech, Wokingham, Woodstock, Wootton Bassett, Worcester, Wycombe

The tendency for the close corporation to treat the members of the governing body as the only corporators, and to repudiate the idea that the corporation was answerable to the inhabitants of the borough if the corporate property was squandered, became more and more manifest as the history of the past slipped into oblivion. The corporators came to regard themselves as members of a club, legally warranted in dividing the lands and goods of the same among themselves whensoever such a division should seem profitable. Even where the constitution of the corporation was not close by charter, the franchise tended to become restricted to an ever-dwindling electorate, as the old methods for the extension of the municipal franchise by other means than inheritance died out of use. At Ipswich in 1833 the \"freemen\" numbered only one fifty-fifth of the population. If the electorate was increased, it was done so by the wholesale admission to borough freedom (burgess status) to voters willing to vote as directed by the corporation at parliamentary elections.{{sfn
column5: Louth]] before the 1830s reforms for example was the governing body of its [[grammar school]] which was the major endowed landowner in the town.{{citation needed
column6: date=December 2016}} Growth of boroughs' corruption continued unchecked (but sometimes a little side-stepped see below) until the era of the Reform Bill. Several boroughs had by that time become insolvent, and some had recourse to their member of parliament to eke out their revenues. In Buckingham the mayor received the whole town revenue without rendering account; sometimes, however, heavy criminal charges fell upon the officers.{{sfn

column1: Before the Reform era dissatisfaction came to occasional fruition in Local Acts (of Parliament) which placed under the authority of special commissioners a variety of administrative details, which if the corporation had not been suspected would certainly not have been assigned to its care. The trust offered another convenient means of escape from difficulty, and in some towns out of the trust was developed a system of municipal administration where there was no recognised corporation. Thus at Peterborough the [[feoffee]]s who had succeeded to the control of certain ancient charities constituted a form of town council with very restricted powers. In the 17th century Sheffield was brought under the act \"to redress the misemployment of lands given to charitable uses\",{{sfn
column4: p=272}} and the municipal administration of what had been a borough passed into the hands of the trustees of the Burgery or [[Sheffield Town Trust
column5: Town Trust]]. The many special authorities created under act of parliament led to much confusion, conflict and overlapping, and increased the need for a general reform.{{sfn

column1: The reform of the boroughs was treated as part of the question of parliamentary reform. In [[Reform Act 1832
column2: 1832]] the exclusive privileges of the corporations in parliamentary elections having been abolished and male occupiers enfranchised, the question of the municipal franchise was next dealt with.{{sfn
column5: p=272}} In effect this made the borough parliamentary franchise the same as the county franchise. In 1833 a commission inquired into the administration of the municipal corporations,{{sfn
column8: p=272}} the commissioners found far more corporations than [[parliamentary Borough]]s, many of which had fallen into desuetude or were purely nominal if not moribund. Those that were active were essentially oligarchies of a closed number of families, there were a few exceptions whereby the councils were elected by all the local residents or those born there. The majority were not representative of the inhabitants.{{citation needed
column9: date=December 2016}} The result of the inquiry was the [[Municipal Corporations Act 1835]], which gave the municipal franchise to the ratepayers, but also allowed the [[Free tenant
column10: freemen]] to remain on the Roll. In all the municipal corporations dealt with by the act, the town council came to consist of a mayor, aldermen and councillors, and the councils were given like powers, being divided into those with and those without a commission of the peace.{{sfn
column13: p=272}} The Commissions of the Peace were also an instrument of reform. Many Boroughs had borough courts of the previous oligarchies of Mayor and Aldermen, advised by a [[Recorder (judge)
column14: Recorder]], these were abolished with the magistrates being appointed as per in the counties – many indeed were supposedly '[[county boroughs]]'. This reform was as crucial as that of the constitution of the council itself.

column1: The minutes were to be open to the inspection of any burgess, and an audit of accounts was required. Exclusive rights of retail trading, which in some towns were restricted to freemen of the borough,{{sfn
column4: p=272}} or to specialist guilds and companies (similar to those of the London [[livery companies]]),{{citation needed
column8: p=272}} The system of police, which in some places was still medieval in character{{sfn
column11: p=272}} as a town watch, was modernised along the lines of the [[Robert Peel
column13: date=December 2016}} placed under the control of the council. The various privileged areas within the bounds of a borough were with few exceptions made part of the borough. The powers of the council to alienate corporate property were closely restricted. The operations of the act were extended by later legislation, and the diverse amendments and enactments which followed were consolidated in the [[Municipal Corporations Act 1882]].{{sfn

column2: Action adventure platform video game for Wii and Nintendo DS}}

column5: known as '''''Sonic Colours''''' in PAL regions
column7: group=lower-alpha}} is a 2010 [[platform video game]] published by [[Sega]]. An installment in the ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' series, it follows [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)
column8: Sonic]]'s quest to stop his nemesis [[Doctor Eggman]] from enslaving an alien race and taking over the world. The gameplay is similar to prior ''Sonic'' games, with players collecting [[Rings (Sonic the Hedgehog)
column9: rings]] and defeating enemies; the camera perspective occasionally switches from [[Third-person view
column11: side-scrolling]] perspectives. The game also introduces [[Wisp (Sonic)
column12: Wisp]]s, [[power-ups]] the player can use to increase attack power and reach new areas.

column1: Development of ''Sonic Colors'' began in 2008, following the completion of ''[[Sonic Unleashed]]''. Examining criticisms of past games, the developers made Sonic the only playable character and worked to balance speed and platforming; the Wisps were introduced to diversify the gameplay without slowing it down. Two versions of the game were developed: one for the [[Wii]] by [[Sonic Team]], and one for the [[Nintendo DS]] by [[Dimps]]. The game was designed for a wider demographic than previous games, specifically children and fans of the ''[[Super Mario]]'' series. In anticipation of the game's release, Sega delisted several ''Sonic'' games with sub-average [[Metacritic]] scores to increase the value of the brand.

''Sonic Colors'' received positive reviews. Critics recommended the title for its graphics, audio, gameplay, replay value, and considered it an improvement over previous installments. However, some criticized its difficulty and weak [[multiplayer]] mode. The game was a commercial success, selling over two million copies. The Wisp power-ups introduced in ''Sonic Colors'' became a staple of the ''Sonic'' series.

column4: Gameplay screenshot of ''Sonic Colors'', showing Sonic in one of the game's levels]]

column1: ''Sonic Colors'' is a 2D [[platform game]] set in [[outer space]]. Players control [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)
column2: Sonic the Hedgehog]], whose goal is to save the [[Wisp (Sonic)
column3: Wisp]]s, an alien race that has been enslaved by [[Doctor Eggman]].<ref name=\"ignwii\" /> The game's main [[Overworld#Platform games
column4: hub]] is Doctor Eggman's Incredible Interstellar Amusement Park, an interplanetary [[amusement park]] that consists of six small planets chained to each other.<ref name=\"gswii\" /> Sonic must be guided through these planets to destroy the power source at their center.<ref name=\"nwr\"/>

column1: Each planet is split into seven parts: six main [[Level (video gaming)
column2: levels]] called acts and a [[Boss (video gaming)
column3: boss]] level.<ref name=\"gswii\" /> In each act, players must guide Sonic to the goal, whilst defeating enemies and dodging obstacles. In boss levels, players face one of Eggman's large robots, and must defeat it. Gameplay seamlessly shifts between [[Side-scrolling video game
column5: third-person]] perspectives.<ref name=\"gswii\" /><ref name=\"wired\" /> Upon completion of a level, players are given a grade dependent on their performance, with an \"S\" being the best and a \"D\" being the worst.<ref name=\"James Newton\">{{Cite web
column15: access-date=September 21, 2017}}</ref> As the player progresses through the game, more planets become available to select. Once each planet has been completed, a bonus seventh, which concludes the story, is unlocked.<ref name=\"brady\" />

column1: Players control Sonic using the [[Wii Remote]] (with or without the [[Wii Nunchuck
column3: Classic Controller]], or the [[Nintendo GameCube Controller]]. Sonic retains most of his abilities from ''[[Sonic Unleashed]]'':<ref name=\"sonicstadiuminterview\" /> he can perform a \"Sonic Boost\" which greatly increases his speed and allows him to smash through various objects;<ref name=\"wisp\">{{cite web
column6: title=Sonic Colors power-ups are looking a bit... familiar
column13: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> a homing attack that allows him to destroy enemies from long distances;<ref name=\"eurog\" /> and a stomp that enables him to quickly destroy objects below him. In certain levels, players are sent at high speeds and must perform a quick step maneuver to dodge walls and other hazards;<ref name=\"destructrev\" /> others see Sonic using a drift mechanic in order to make sharp turns. Sonic is also given a double-jump ability, which allows him to perform an additional jump in mid-air.<ref name=\"eurog\" />

column4: Sonic uses the Orange Rocket, one of the eight Wisps in ''Sonic Colors'']]

column1: A major aspect of ''Sonic Colors'' is the ability to activate Wisp [[power-up]]s.<ref name=\"grrev\" /> There are eight different types of Wisps, each with their own unique advantage dependent on their color.<ref name=\"ignwii\" /> Normal white-colored Wisps allow the player to get a speed boost at any time.<ref name=\"wisp\"/> The \"Cyan Laser\" turns Sonic into a laser that can bounce off solid surfaces to change the laser's path and to travel through power lines,<ref name=\"grrev\" /> while the \"Yellow Drill\" allows Sonic to drill through soft ground and water.<ref name=\"grrev\" /> The \"Orange Rocket\" allows Sonic to blast upward to tremendous heights;<ref name=\"gids\" /> the \"Pink Spikes\" allows Sonic to bond to walls and ceilings and to perform a spin dash to gain velocity and to destroy objects;<ref name=\"grrev\" /> the \"Green Hover\" enables Sonic to hover and to perform dashes across lines of rings;<ref name=\"gswii\" /> the \"Blue Cube\" gives Sonic the ability to turn blue blocks into blue rings and vice versa;<ref name=\"James Newton\" /> and the \"Purple Frenzy\", which turns Sonic into a berserker that chomps through anything in its path, increasing in size as it continues to eat.<ref name=\"gswii\" />
Like previous games, Sonic collects golden [[Rings (Sonic the Hedgehog)
column2: rings]],<ref name=\"gswii\" /> which protect him from a single hit by an enemy or obstacle, though they will scatter and blink before disappearing. Sonic starts the game with a limited number of [[Life (gaming)
column3: lives]]; if he is hit with no rings in his possession, he will lose a life.<ref name=\"ignwii\" /> If a player exhausts their lives, they will receive a [[game over]].<ref name=\"brady\" />

column2: co-operative]] [[two-player]] mode, ''Eggman's Sonic Simulator,'' in which players control Sonic-modeled robots or their [[Mii]] characters through a series of levels.<ref name=\"nwr\" /> These levels can be unlocked by collecting special Red Star Rings hidden throughout each act.<ref name=\"gswii\" /> Completing ''Sonic Simulator'' levels rewards the player [[Chaos Emeralds]], and once all seven are collected, Sonic can transform into [[Sonic the Hedgehog#Super transformation
column3: Super Sonic]] after collecting 50 rings in normal levels. As Super Sonic, players are invincible and can boost infinitely, though they cannot use Wisps and lose one ring per second, de-transforming when the ring counter hits zero.<ref name=\"brady\" /> The game also features online leaderboards, allowing players to upload their scores via [[Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection]].<ref name=\"gsds\">{{cite web

column4: A version of ''Sonic Colors'' (pictured) was developed by [[Dimps]] for the [[Nintendo DS]]]]

column1: Unlike the [[Wii]] version, the [[Nintendo DS]] version of ''Sonic Colors'' is a side-scroller reminiscent of the original [[Sega Genesis]] games that takes advantage of the system's dual-screen.<ref name=\"gids\">{{cite web
column4: title=Dimps Crafts Another Amazing 2D Sonic Game
column11: archivedate=April 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name=\"ignds\" /> Exclusive to the DS version are [[touchscreen]]-controlled special stages similar to the ones seen in ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 2]]'',<ref name=\"gids\"/> missions featuring various characters from throughout the franchise, a competitive multiplayer mode,<ref name=\"ignds\">{{cite web
column21: archivedate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> and an extra final boss.<ref name=\"brady\" /> The game features two additional Wisp types: \"Red Burst\", which allows Sonic to burst in midair and can activate certain objects such as a hot air balloon, Ferris wheel, and popcorn cannons;<ref name=\"brady\" /> and \"Violet Void\", which gives Sonic the ability to float and to suck up nearby objects, growing bigger in the process.<ref name=\"gids\"/> Unlockable concept art is also included.<ref name=\"gids\"/>

column1: Doctor Eggman opens an amusement park in space called Dr. Eggman's Incredible Interstellar Amusement Park, allegedly turning over a new leaf and making up for past transgressions. The park is made up of several planet-sized attractions. Suspicious, Sonic the Hedgehog and his best friend [[Tails (character)
column2: Tails]] investigate. They meet Yacker, who comes from a species of [[extraterrestrial life
column3: aliens]] known as Wisps. After Tails invents a translator to communicate with him, they learn that other Wisps have been enslaved by Eggman, who plans to harness their energy for a mind-control laser that will allow him to take over Earth.

column1: Sonic proceeds to visit the planets, liberating the Wisps and shutting down the generators linked to the amusement park. He meets many of his friends along the way, who are also exploring the park in an attempt to disrupt Eggman's plans.{{efn
column2: name=DS}} After Sonic frees the Wisps, Eggman tries to fire the cannon at the world, but a piece of wreckage causes it to malfunction. As the amusement park begins to explode, Sonic confronts Eggman. Eggman uses the Nega-Wisps to power his final contraption, a robot that uses the powers of all the Wisps that Sonic has met against him. As the machine gets weaker, the Wisps escape and help Sonic defeat Eggman, sending him hurtling off into space. The Wisps carry Sonic out of the exploding amusement park. Returning safely to Earth, Yacker thanks Sonic and Tails.

column1: However, Sonic and Tails soon learn that the leading Mother Wisp had been infected by the negative energy and transformed into the Nega-Mother Wisp. Using the power of the Chaos Emeralds, Sonic transforms into Super Sonic and fights her. Following her defeat, the Mother Wisp returns to normal and the Wisps part ways with the two heroes.{{efn
column3: Only in the Nintendo DS version.}} In a [[post-credits scene]], Eggman is seen stranded in space with his henchmen [[Orbot and Cubot]].

column2: quote= From a general game design perspective, in recent years we've been able to introduce Sonic to new fans, a lot of the Nintendo/''Mario'' fans, and because of that, we've made changes to the design, and we've designed things in ''Sonic Colors'' that we think will really appeal to people who are unfamiliar with the Sonic brand and the Sonic gameplay.
column3: source=Takashi Iizuka, on why ''Sonic Colors'' was designed to appeal to a wider demographic.<ref name=\"vg\"/>

column1: Development of ''Sonic Colors'' began in 2008, following the completion of ''Sonic Unleashed''.<ref name=\"Q&A\">{{cite web
column11: url-status=dead}}</ref> While they kept most of ''Unleashed''{{'}}s core gameplay elements,<ref name=\"sonicstadiuminterview\">{{cite web
column14: title=E3 2010 Q&A: Takashi Iizuka on Sonic Colors
column20: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> developers [[Sonic Team]] and [[Dimps]] decided to create an equal balance between speed and platforming similar to that of the games released for the Sega Genesis, in comparison to the straightforward gameplay of ''Unleashed''.<ref name=\"spong interview\">{{cite web
column23: title=Interviews// Sonic Colours Producer, Takashi Iizuka
column29: archivedate=June 18, 2012}}</ref> Following requests by fans, the team also made the decision to make Sonic the only playable character, and to omit \"gimmick\" themes such as the [[swordplay]] mechanic used in the 2009 [[Spin-off (media)
column30: spin-off]] ''[[Sonic and the Black Knight]]''.<ref name=\"canvas\"/> The team chose to develop ''Sonic Colors'' on [[Nintendo]]'s Wii and DS consoles, hoping to expand upon the audience attracted by the successful ''[[Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Games]]'' [[Crossover (fiction)

column1: One of the first ideas was the setting should be an amusement park; Sonic Team then realized that \"any sort of terrestrial amusement park would be too small to contain Sonic's adventures.\" From this came the idea of an interplanetary park, which would allow for more creativity and variance in the game.<ref name=\"canvas\">{{Cite journal
column8: pages=50–57}}</ref> The developers used [[Disneyland]] as visual inspiration for the levels.<ref name=\"spong interview\"/> Sonic Team also desired something that would diversify the gameplay, but did not slow it down. Thus, the Wisps were added to the game to expand and strengthen the gameplay without forcing the player to switch to [[List of Sonic the Hedgehog video game characters
column18: archivedate=March 26, 2014}}</ref> Another goal was to encourage players to revisit completed levels; Sonic Team accomplished this by adding segments requiring certain types of Wisps to levels preceding their first appearances.<ref>{{cite web
column28: archivedate=March 26, 2014}}</ref> The Wii version makes use of the [[PhysX]] [[physics engine]],<ref>''Sonic Colors'' cover art.</ref> previously used with 2007's ''[[Sonic and the Secret Rings]]'',<ref>{{cite web
column31: title=NVIDIA announces expanded support for PhysX and APEX from Sega, Capcom
column37: archivedate=September 23, 2017}}</ref> while the DS version uses the same engine used in the 2005 entry ''[[Sonic Rush]]'' and [[Sonic Rush Adventure

column2: Takashi Iizuka]], ''Sonic Colors'' was designed to appeal to a casual audience, particularly children and fans of the ''[[Super Mario]]'' series.<ref name=\"vg\">{{cite web
column5: title=New Sonic has been designed to appeal to Mario fans
column14: title=Sega: Sonic Colors is for everyone!
column21: archivedate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> Iizuka's statement that it was impossible to please all ''Sonic'' fans initially alienated those who had enjoyed prior entries such as ''Unleashed'' and ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode I]]'',<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=Sonic Colors designer tells you to stop being excited
column31: archivedate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> though Sega brand manager Judy Gilbertson later clarified that \"we’re also looking to create a game that is accessible to younger gamers as well as our ‘core’ fans.\"<ref name=\"everyone\"/> The script was written by ''[[MadWorld]]'' and ''[[Happy Tree Friends]]'' contributors [[Ken Pontac]] and [[Warren Graff]].<ref>{{cite web
column34: title=Sonic Colors Sends A Hedgehog Into (Mario's) Space
column41: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> ''Sonic Colors'' is also one of the first games in the series not to use the English voice cast from the ''[[Sonic X]]'' anime series following a major re-casting of the franchise in 2010, with [[Roger Craig Smith]] assuming the role of Sonic.<ref name=\"ignwii\">{{cite web
column54: title=Ninterview: Meet Roger Craig Smith – Voice Actor for Sonic the Hedgehog / Chris Redfield

column1: Sega first announced ''Sonic Colors'' in a blog post on May 26, 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column10: archivedate=May 21, 2016}}</ref> Demo versions of the game were playable at the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2010]],<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Sonic Colors – Gamescom: Grab Those Coins!
column29: title=SEGA PAXtravaganza – Booth and Community Event!
column36: archivedate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> and the [[Tokyo Game Show]].<ref>{{cite web
column39: title=Sega, Konami, and Level-5 Share Tokyo Game Show Plans
column45: archivedate=June 3, 2016}}</ref> On November 4, 2010, Sega held a ''Sonic Colors''-themed ice-skating event at [[Bryant Park]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web
column47: title=Join us in New York City for Sonic Colors Fun!
column54: archivedate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> [[BradyGames]] also published an official strategy guide, which launched alongside the game.<ref name=\"brady\">{{cite book
column57: title=Sonic Colors: BradyGames Official Strategy Guide
column60: isbn=9780744012583}}</ref> In anticipation of the game's release, Sega delisted multiple ''Sonic'' games with sub-average [[Metacritic]] scores to increase the value of the brand.<ref name=\"delisted\">{{cite news
column69: archivedate=May 11, 2011 }}</ref> ''Sonic Colors'' was first released in PAL regions on November 11, 2010, followed by a North American release on November 16, 2010 and in Japan on November 18, 2010.<ref name=\"ReleaseDate1\">{{cite news
column70: title= Australian Sonic Colours release date confirmed
column79: title= Sonic Colors Gameplay Excites, But That Theme Song Has To Go
column87: title=SEGA : Sonic Channel : Game Title : Wii
column94: archivedate=September 23, 2017}}</ref> People who pre-ordered the Japanese version of the game received a special card compatible with the arcade game ''Rekishi Taisen Gettenka'', allowing Sonic to appear in the game.<ref>{{cite web
column96: title=Sonic Pre-Order Bonus Puts The Hedgehog In The Warring States Era
column103: archivedate=July 25, 2015}}</ref> Those who pre-ordered the game through [[GameStop]] in North America received a Sonic shaped hat.<ref>{{cite web
column105: title= Sonic Colors pre-order GameStop bonus is this Sonic hat
column113: archivedate= June 18, 2012}}</ref> A special edition was also sold in Europe, featuring figurines of Sonic and the Wisps.<ref>{{cite web
column115: title= Euro Sonic Colours Special Edition is Filled With Toys

column1: The game's score was composed by [[Tomoya Ohtani]], Kenichi Tokoi, Fumie Kumatani, [[Hideaki Kobayashi (composer)
column2: Hideaki Kobayashi]], [[Mariko Nanba]], and [[Naofumi Hataya]], and was written to be more energetic than previous entries' scores.<ref name=\"canvas\"/> The in-game music is performed by the Amsterdam Session Orchestra. Jean Paul Makhlouf from the American band [[Cash Cash]] performed the game's opening song, \"Reach For The Stars\", and his brother Alex joined him in singing the ending song, \"Speak With Your Heart\". A three-CD soundtrack, ''Sonic Colors Original Soundtrack: Vivid Sounds × Hybrid Colors'', featuring music from the game was released on CD in Japan on December 22, 2010,<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=ウェーブマスター、Wii/DS「ソニック カラーズ」「ヴィヴィッド・サウンド × ハイブリッド・カラーズ」サントラ発売決定！
column10: language=Japanese}}</ref> with a digital version released via [[iTunes]] in January 2011.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Finally We Can Relate, Sonic Colours Soundtrack Now On iTunes!

column1: Both versions of ''Sonic Colors'' received \"generally favorable\" reviews, according to [[review aggregator]] Metacritic.<ref name=metacriticds>{{cite web
column15: archivedate= April 28, 2012 }}</ref> The game was also successful commercially; as of March 2011, it has sold 2.18 million copies.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Appendix of Consolidated Financial Statements Year Ended March 31, 2011

column1: The game's presentation was well received. Pedro Hernandez of ''Nintendo World Report'' described the graphics and animations as \"beautiful\" and \"gorgeous\".<ref name=\"nwr\">{{cite web
column10: archivedate=December 8, 2015}}</ref> Arthur Gies of ''[[IGN]]'' considered them to be among the best available on the Wii, praising the lighting, detail, and variety they offered.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/> Both Hernandez and Jane Douglas of ''[[GameSpot]]'' both praised the audio for incorporating familiar aspects of past ''Sonic'' games, and Douglas admired the \"jazzy, high-energy\" soundtrack as fitting for all levels.<ref name=\"nwr\"/><ref name=\"gswii\">{{cite web
column20: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> The new voice casting was also appreciated; Gies elaborated that the cast was \"much less annoying\" than the previous voice actors, and Hernandez considered their voices to be fitting for the characters.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/><ref name=\"nwr\"/>

column1: The gameplay was praised, particularly for the Wisps and its replay value. Al Bickham of ''[[Eurogamer]]'' considered the game's intertwining of platforming and speed to be successful, and also praised its use of the Wii Remote.<ref name=\"eurog\">{{cite web
column11: archivedate=April 27, 2012}}</ref> Gies, Douglas, and John Meyer of ''[[Wired (magazine)
column12: Wired]]'' praised the shift from third-person to side-scrolling, which Meyer described as \"elegant and cohesive\".<ref name=\"wired\">{{cite web
column15: title=Review: No-Nonsense Sonic Colors is The Best Hedgehog Game in Years
column21: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> Matthew Keast of ''[[GamesRadar]]'' called the Wisps the game's best feature, describing the element of backtracking to previously completed levels after unlocking more types as clever.<ref name=\"grrev\">{{cite web
column31: archivedate=April 27, 2012}}</ref> Tim Turi of ''[[Game Informer]]'' praised the Wisps for adding \"an interesting new gameplay mechanic without succumbing to Werehog-itis\",<ref name=\"gids\"/> and Gies compared the Wisps to power-ups from the ''Super Mario'' franchise, though he felt that ''Colors'' still felt distinctive and fresh.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/> Douglas, however, preferred basic platforming over using the Wisps.<ref name=\"gswii\"/>

column1: Some aspects of the game were criticized, however. Writing for ''[[Destructoid]]'', [[Jim Sterling]] described ''Sonic Colors'' as \"terribly designed\". He criticized the controls and physics, and felt the developers had not addressed problems present in previous games and concluded that the game was poor.<ref name=\"destructrev\">{{Cite web
column11: access-date=July 10, 2017}}</ref> Gies, Hernandez, Meyer, Turi, and Keast criticized the game's high difficulty level,<ref name=\"ignwii\"/><ref name=\"nwr\"/><ref name=\"wired\"/><ref name=\"grrev\" /><ref name=\"giwii\">{{cite web
column14: title=Sonic Drops The Ball Juggling The Second And Third Dimensions
column21: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> with Keast going as far to describe it as \"hardcore\".<ref name=\"grrev\"/> Both Gies and Douglas spoke negatively of the co-op ''Eggman's Sonic Simulator''; Gies described it as not fun,<ref name=\"ignwii\"/> and Douglas called it \"ugly\" and ultimately concluded that the multiplayer was weak. Douglas also made note of the boss fights as being repetitive.<ref name=\"gswii\"/>

column1: Regarding the game as a whole, critics felt that ''Sonic Colors'' was one of the best entries in the ''Sonic'' series.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/><ref name=\"wired\"/> ''IGN'' declared it one of the best games available for the Wii,<ref>{{cite web
column10: archivedate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> and awarded it their \"Quick Fix\" award of 2010.<ref name=\"quick\">{{cite web
column17: archivedate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> Douglas concluded that \"Wii owners shouldn't miss an opportunity to play with Sonic at his best\".<ref name=\"gswii\"/> ''[[Empire (film magazine)
column18: Empire]]'' considered ''Colors'' a return to form for the series,<ref name=\"empire\">{{cite web
column25: archivedate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> whose popularity had declined in recent years following a number of poorly received games such as [[Sonic the Hedgehog (2006 video game)

column1: ''Sonic Colors'' introduced the Wisp power-ups, which would go on to become a staple of the ''Sonic'' franchise.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Iizuka: Color Powers will be standard in future Sonic games
column12: archivedate=March 31, 2016}}</ref> Games featuring the Wisps include ''[[Sonic Generations]]'' (2011),<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Sonic Lost World Brings Back Wisp Powers, Producer Teases Casino Surprise
column22: title=Sonic: Lost World: Why Slowing Down is a Good Thing
column31: title=Sonic Forces Character Creation Feature Announced
column37: archivedate=May 22, 2017}}</ref> The story of ''Sonic Colors'' was adapted in [[Archie Comics]]' ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (comics)
column38: Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' comic book series.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: ''Sonic Generations'' was released in commemoration of the series' twentieth anniversary, and remade various aspects from past entries. The version of the game released for the [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3]], and [[Microsoft Windows]] features a reimagined version of ''Sonic Colors''{{'}}s Planet Wisp level.<ref>{{cite web
column11: archivedate=November 29, 2016}}</ref> The version of the game released for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] contains a remake of the Tropical Resort level.<ref>{{cite web

column2: Action adventure platform video game for Wii and Nintendo DS}}

column5: known as '''''Sonic Colours''''' in PAL regions
column7: group=lower-alpha}} is a 2010 [[platform video game]] published by [[Sega]]. An installment in the ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' series, it follows [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)
column8: Sonic]]'s quest to stop his nemesis [[Doctor Eggman]] from enslaving an alien race and taking over the world. The gameplay is similar to prior ''Sonic'' games, with players collecting [[Rings (Sonic the Hedgehog)
column9: rings]] and defeating enemies; the camera perspective occasionally switches from [[Third-person view
column11: side-scrolling]] perspectives. The game also introduces [[Wisp (Sonic)
column12: Wisp]]s, [[power-ups]] the player can use to increase attack power and reach new areas.

column1: Development of ''Sonic Colors'' began in 2008, following the completion of ''[[Sonic Unleashed]]''. Examining criticisms of past games, the developers made Sonic the only playable character and worked to balance speed and platforming; the Wisps were introduced to diversify the gameplay without slowing it down. Two versions of the game were developed: one for the [[Wii]] by [[Sonic Team]], and one for the [[Nintendo DS]] by [[Dimps]]. The game was designed for a wider demographic than previous games, specifically children and fans of the ''[[Super Mario]]'' series. In anticipation of the game's release, Sega delisted several ''Sonic'' games with sub-average [[Metacritic]] scores to increase the value of the brand.

''Sonic Colors'' received positive reviews. Critics recommended the title for its graphics, audio, gameplay, replay value, and considered it an improvement over previous installments. However, some criticized its difficulty and weak [[multiplayer]] mode. The game was a commercial success, selling over two million copies. The Wisp power-ups introduced in ''Sonic Colors'' became a staple of the ''Sonic'' series.

column3: Super Sonic]] after collecting 50 rings in normal levels. As Super Sonic, players are invincible and can boost infinitely, though they cannot use Wisps and lose one ring per second, de-transforming when the ring counter hits zero.<ref name=\"brady\" /> The game also features online leaderboards, allowing players to upload their scores via [[Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection]].<ref name=\"gsds\">{{cite web

column4: A version of ''Sonic Colors'' (pictured) was developed by [[Dimps]] for the [[Nintendo DS]]]]

column1: Unlike the [[Wii]] version, the [[Nintendo DS]] version of ''Sonic Colors'' is a side-scroller reminiscent of the original [[Sega Genesis]] games that takes advantage of the system's dual-screen.<ref name=\"gids\">{{cite web
column4: title=Dimps Crafts Another Amazing 2D Sonic Game
column11: archivedate=April 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name=\"ignds\" /> Exclusive to the DS version are [[touchscreen]]-controlled special stages similar to the ones seen in ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 2]]'',<ref name=\"gids\"/> missions featuring various characters from throughout the franchise, a competitive multiplayer mode,<ref name=\"ignds\">{{cite web
column21: archivedate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> and an extra final boss.<ref name=\"brady\" /> The game features two additional Wisp types: \"Red Burst\", which allows Sonic to burst in midair and can activate certain objects such as a hot air balloon, Ferris wheel, and popcorn cannons;<ref name=\"brady\" /> and \"Violet Void\", which gives Sonic the ability to float and to suck up nearby objects, growing bigger in the process.<ref name=\"gids\"/> Unlockable concept art is also included.<ref name=\"gids\"/>

column1: Doctor Eggman opens an amusement park in space called Dr. Eggman's Incredible Interstellar Amusement Park, allegedly turning over a new leaf and making up for past transgressions. The park is made up of several planet-sized attractions. Suspicious, Sonic the Hedgehog and his best friend [[Tails (character)
column2: Tails]] investigate. They meet Yacker, who comes from a species of [[extraterrestrial life
column3: aliens]] known as Wisps. After Tails invents a translator to communicate with him, they learn that other Wisps have been enslaved by Eggman, who plans to harness their energy for a mind-control laser that will allow him to take over Earth.

column1: Sonic proceeds to visit the planets, liberating the Wisps and shutting down the generators linked to the amusement park. He meets many of his friends along the way, who are also exploring the park in an attempt to disrupt Eggman's plans.{{efn
column2: name=DS}} After Sonic frees the Wisps, Eggman tries to fire the cannon at the world, but a piece of wreckage causes it to malfunction. As the amusement park begins to explode, Sonic confronts Eggman. Eggman uses the Nega-Wisps to power his final contraption, a robot that uses the powers of all the Wisps that Sonic has met against him. As the machine gets weaker, the Wisps escape and help Sonic defeat Eggman, sending him hurtling off into space. The Wisps carry Sonic out of the exploding amusement park. Returning safely to Earth, Yacker thanks Sonic and Tails.

column1: However, Sonic and Tails soon learn that the leading Mother Wisp had been infected by the negative energy and transformed into the Nega-Mother Wisp. Using the power of the Chaos Emeralds, Sonic transforms into Super Sonic and fights her. Following her defeat, the Mother Wisp returns to normal and the Wisps part ways with the two heroes.{{efn
column3: Only in the Nintendo DS version.}} In a [[post-credits scene]], Eggman is seen stranded in space with his henchmen [[Orbot and Cubot]].

column2: quote= From a general game design perspective, in recent years we've been able to introduce Sonic to new fans, a lot of the Nintendo/''Mario'' fans, and because of that, we've made changes to the design, and we've designed things in ''Sonic Colors'' that we think will really appeal to people who are unfamiliar with the Sonic brand and the Sonic gameplay.
column3: source=Takashi Iizuka, on why ''Sonic Colors'' was designed to appeal to a wider demographic.<ref name=\"vg\"/>

column1: Development of ''Sonic Colors'' began in 2008, following the completion of ''Sonic Unleashed''.<ref name=\"Q&A\">{{cite web
column11: url-status=dead}}</ref> While they kept most of ''Unleashed''{{'}}s core gameplay elements,<ref name=\"sonicstadiuminterview\">{{cite web
column14: title=E3 2010 Q&A: Takashi Iizuka on Sonic Colors
column20: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> developers [[Sonic Team]] and [[Dimps]] decided to create an equal balance between speed and platforming similar to that of the games released for the Sega Genesis, in comparison to the straightforward gameplay of ''Unleashed''.<ref name=\"spong interview\">{{cite web
column23: title=Interviews// Sonic Colours Producer, Takashi Iizuka
column29: archivedate=June 18, 2012}}</ref> Following requests by fans, the team also made the decision to make Sonic the only playable character, and to omit \"gimmick\" themes such as the [[swordplay]] mechanic used in the 2009 [[Spin-off (media)
column30: spin-off]] ''[[Sonic and the Black Knight]]''.<ref name=\"canvas\"/> The team chose to develop ''Sonic Colors'' on [[Nintendo]]'s Wii and DS consoles, hoping to expand upon the audience attracted by the successful ''[[Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Games]]'' [[Crossover (fiction)

column1: One of the first ideas was the setting should be an amusement park; Sonic Team then realized that \"any sort of terrestrial amusement park would be too small to contain Sonic's adventures.\" From this came the idea of an interplanetary park, which would allow for more creativity and variance in the game.<ref name=\"canvas\">{{Cite journal
column8: pages=50–57}}</ref> The developers used [[Disneyland]] as visual inspiration for the levels.<ref name=\"spong interview\"/> Sonic Team also desired something that would diversify the gameplay, but did not slow it down. Thus, the Wisps were added to the game to expand and strengthen the gameplay without forcing the player to switch to [[List of Sonic the Hedgehog video game characters
column18: archivedate=March 26, 2014}}</ref> Another goal was to encourage players to revisit completed levels; Sonic Team accomplished this by adding segments requiring certain types of Wisps to levels preceding their first appearances.<ref>{{cite web
column28: archivedate=March 26, 2014}}</ref> The Wii version makes use of the [[PhysX]] [[physics engine]],<ref>''Sonic Colors'' cover art.</ref> previously used with 2007's ''[[Sonic and the Secret Rings]]'',<ref>{{cite web
column31: title=NVIDIA announces expanded support for PhysX and APEX from Sega, Capcom
column37: archivedate=September 23, 2017}}</ref> while the DS version uses the same engine used in the 2005 entry ''[[Sonic Rush]]'' and [[Sonic Rush Adventure

column2: Takashi Iizuka]], ''Sonic Colors'' was designed to appeal to a casual audience, particularly children and fans of the ''[[Super Mario]]'' series.<ref name=\"vg\">{{cite web
column5: title=New Sonic has been designed to appeal to Mario fans
column14: title=Sega: Sonic Colors is for everyone!
column21: archivedate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> Iizuka's statement that it was impossible to please all ''Sonic'' fans initially alienated those who had enjoyed prior entries such as ''Unleashed'' and ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode I]]'',<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=Sonic Colors designer tells you to stop being excited
column31: archivedate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> though Sega brand manager Judy Gilbertson later clarified that \"we’re also looking to create a game that is accessible to younger gamers as well as our ‘core’ fans.\"<ref name=\"everyone\"/> The script was written by ''[[MadWorld]]'' and ''[[Happy Tree Friends]]'' contributors [[Ken Pontac]] and [[Warren Graff]].<ref>{{cite web
column34: title=Sonic Colors Sends A Hedgehog Into (Mario's) Space
column41: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> ''Sonic Colors'' is also one of the first games in the series not to use the English voice cast from the ''[[Sonic X]]'' anime series following a major re-casting of the franchise in 2010, with [[Roger Craig Smith]] assuming the role of Sonic.<ref name=\"ignwii\">{{cite web
column54: title=Ninterview: Meet Roger Craig Smith – Voice Actor for Sonic the Hedgehog / Chris Redfield

column1: Sega first announced ''Sonic Colors'' in a blog post on May 26, 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column10: archivedate=May 21, 2016}}</ref> Demo versions of the game were playable at the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2010]],<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Sonic Colors – Gamescom: Grab Those Coins!
column29: title=SEGA PAXtravaganza – Booth and Community Event!
column36: archivedate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> and the [[Tokyo Game Show]].<ref>{{cite web
column39: title=Sega, Konami, and Level-5 Share Tokyo Game Show Plans
column45: archivedate=June 3, 2016}}</ref> On November 4, 2010, Sega held a ''Sonic Colors''-themed ice-skating event at [[Bryant Park]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web
column47: title=Join us in New York City for Sonic Colors Fun!
column54: archivedate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> [[BradyGames]] also published an official strategy guide, which launched alongside the game.<ref name=\"brady\">{{cite book
column57: title=Sonic Colors: BradyGames Official Strategy Guide
column60: isbn=9780744012583}}</ref> In anticipation of the game's release, Sega delisted multiple ''Sonic'' games with sub-average [[Metacritic]] scores to increase the value of the brand.<ref name=\"delisted\">{{cite news
column69: archivedate=May 11, 2011 }}</ref> ''Sonic Colors'' was first released in PAL regions on November 11, 2010, followed by a North American release on November 16, 2010 and in Japan on November 18, 2010.<ref name=\"ReleaseDate1\">{{cite news
column70: title= Australian Sonic Colours release date confirmed
column79: title= Sonic Colors Gameplay Excites, But That Theme Song Has To Go
column87: title=SEGA : Sonic Channel : Game Title : Wii
column94: archivedate=September 23, 2017}}</ref> People who pre-ordered the Japanese version of the game received a special card compatible with the arcade game ''Rekishi Taisen Gettenka'', allowing Sonic to appear in the game.<ref>{{cite web
column96: title=Sonic Pre-Order Bonus Puts The Hedgehog In The Warring States Era
column103: archivedate=July 25, 2015}}</ref> Those who pre-ordered the game through [[GameStop]] in North America received a Sonic shaped hat.<ref>{{cite web
column105: title= Sonic Colors pre-order GameStop bonus is this Sonic hat
column113: archivedate= June 18, 2012}}</ref> A special edition was also sold in Europe, featuring figurines of Sonic and the Wisps.<ref>{{cite web
column115: title= Euro Sonic Colours Special Edition is Filled With Toys

column1: The game's score was composed by [[Tomoya Ohtani]], Kenichi Tokoi, Fumie Kumatani, [[Hideaki Kobayashi (composer)
column2: Hideaki Kobayashi]], [[Mariko Nanba]], and [[Naofumi Hataya]], and was written to be more energetic than previous entries' scores.<ref name=\"canvas\"/> The in-game music is performed by the Amsterdam Session Orchestra. Jean Paul Makhlouf from the American band [[Cash Cash]] performed the game's opening song, \"Reach For The Stars\", and his brother Alex joined him in singing the ending song, \"Speak With Your Heart\". A three-CD soundtrack, ''Sonic Colors Original Soundtrack: Vivid Sounds × Hybrid Colors'', featuring music from the game was released on CD in Japan on December 22, 2010,<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=ウェーブマスター、Wii/DS「ソニック カラーズ」「ヴィヴィッド・サウンド × ハイブリッド・カラーズ」サントラ発売決定！
column10: language=Japanese}}</ref> with a digital version released via [[iTunes]] in January 2011.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Finally We Can Relate, Sonic Colours Soundtrack Now On iTunes!

column1: Both versions of ''Sonic Colors'' received \"generally favorable\" reviews, according to [[review aggregator]] Metacritic.<ref name=metacriticds>{{cite web
column15: archivedate= April 28, 2012 }}</ref> The game was also successful commercially; as of March 2011, it has sold 2.18 million copies.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Appendix of Consolidated Financial Statements Year Ended March 31, 2011

column1: The game's presentation was well received. Pedro Hernandez of ''Nintendo World Report'' described the graphics and animations as \"beautiful\" and \"gorgeous\".<ref name=\"nwr\">{{cite web
column10: archivedate=December 8, 2015}}</ref> Arthur Gies of ''[[IGN]]'' considered them to be among the best available on the Wii, praising the lighting, detail, and variety they offered.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/> Both Hernandez and Jane Douglas of ''[[GameSpot]]'' both praised the audio for incorporating familiar aspects of past ''Sonic'' games, and Douglas admired the \"jazzy, high-energy\" soundtrack as fitting for all levels.<ref name=\"nwr\"/><ref name=\"gswii\">{{cite web
column20: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> The new voice casting was also appreciated; Gies elaborated that the cast was \"much less annoying\" than the previous voice actors, and Hernandez considered their voices to be fitting for the characters.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/><ref name=\"nwr\"/>

column1: The gameplay was praised, particularly for the Wisps and its replay value. Al Bickham of ''[[Eurogamer]]'' considered the game's intertwining of platforming and speed to be successful, and also praised its use of the Wii Remote.<ref name=\"eurog\">{{cite web
column11: archivedate=April 27, 2012}}</ref> Gies, Douglas, and John Meyer of ''[[Wired (magazine)
column12: Wired]]'' praised the shift from third-person to side-scrolling, which Meyer described as \"elegant and cohesive\".<ref name=\"wired\">{{cite web
column15: title=Review: No-Nonsense Sonic Colors is The Best Hedgehog Game in Years
column21: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> Matthew Keast of ''[[GamesRadar]]'' called the Wisps the game's best feature, describing the element of backtracking to previously completed levels after unlocking more types as clever.<ref name=\"grrev\">{{cite web
column31: archivedate=April 27, 2012}}</ref> Tim Turi of ''[[Game Informer]]'' praised the Wisps for adding \"an interesting new gameplay mechanic without succumbing to Werehog-itis\",<ref name=\"gids\"/> and Gies compared the Wisps to power-ups from the ''Super Mario'' franchise, though he felt that ''Colors'' still felt distinctive and fresh.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/> Douglas, however, preferred basic platforming over using the Wisps.<ref name=\"gswii\"/>

column1: Some aspects of the game were criticized, however. Writing for ''[[Destructoid]]'', [[Jim Sterling]] described ''Sonic Colors'' as \"terribly designed\". He criticized the controls and physics, and felt the developers had not addressed problems present in previous games and concluded that the game was poor.<ref name=\"destructrev\">{{Cite web
column11: access-date=July 10, 2017}}</ref> Gies, Hernandez, Meyer, Turi, and Keast criticized the game's high difficulty level,<ref name=\"ignwii\"/><ref name=\"nwr\"/><ref name=\"wired\"/><ref name=\"grrev\" /><ref name=\"giwii\">{{cite web
column14: title=Sonic Drops The Ball Juggling The Second And Third Dimensions
column21: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> with Keast going as far to describe it as \"hardcore\".<ref name=\"grrev\"/> Both Gies and Douglas spoke negatively of the co-op ''Eggman's Sonic Simulator''; Gies described it as not fun,<ref name=\"ignwii\"/> and Douglas called it \"ugly\" and ultimately concluded that the multiplayer was weak. Douglas also made note of the boss fights as being repetitive.<ref name=\"gswii\"/>

column1: Regarding the game as a whole, critics felt that ''Sonic Colors'' was one of the best entries in the ''Sonic'' series.<ref name=\"ignwii\"/><ref name=\"wired\"/> ''IGN'' declared it one of the best games available for the Wii,<ref>{{cite web
column10: archivedate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> and awarded it their \"Quick Fix\" award of 2010.<ref name=\"quick\">{{cite web
column17: archivedate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> Douglas concluded that \"Wii owners shouldn't miss an opportunity to play with Sonic at his best\".<ref name=\"gswii\"/> ''[[Empire (film magazine)
column18: Empire]]'' considered ''Colors'' a return to form for the series,<ref name=\"empire\">{{cite web
column25: archivedate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> whose popularity had declined in recent years following a number of poorly received games such as [[Sonic the Hedgehog (2006 video game)

column1: ''Sonic Colors'' introduced the Wisp power-ups, which would go on to become a staple of the ''Sonic'' franchise.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Iizuka: Color Powers will be standard in future Sonic games
column12: archivedate=March 31, 2016}}</ref> Games featuring the Wisps include ''[[Sonic Generations]]'' (2011),<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Sonic Lost World Brings Back Wisp Powers, Producer Teases Casino Surprise
column22: title=Sonic: Lost World: Why Slowing Down is a Good Thing
column31: title=Sonic Forces Character Creation Feature Announced
column37: archivedate=May 22, 2017}}</ref> The story of ''Sonic Colors'' was adapted in [[Archie Comics]]' ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (comics)
column38: Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' comic book series.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: ''Sonic Generations'' was released in commemoration of the series' twentieth anniversary, and remade various aspects from past entries. The version of the game released for the [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3]], and [[Microsoft Windows]] features a reimagined version of ''Sonic Colors''{{'}}s Planet Wisp level.<ref>{{cite web
column11: archivedate=November 29, 2016}}</ref> The version of the game released for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] contains a remake of the Tropical Resort level.<ref>{{cite web

column1: expand templates perFb team TfD outcomeandFb competition TfD outcomeandFb cl TfD outcomeandFb rbr TfD outcome,safe,Frietjes,"{{unreferenced
The '''Champions League 2008-2009''' is the season of '''[[EHF Champions League]]'''.
The '''Champions League 2008-2009''' is the season of '''[[EHF Champions League]]'''.

column2: Action adventure platform video game for Wii and Nintendo DS}}

column1: Development of ''Sonic Colors'' began in 2008, following the completion of ''[[Sonic Unleashed]]''. Examining criticisms of past games, the developers made Sonic the only playable character and worked to balance speed and platforming; the Wisps were introduced to diversify the gameplay without slowing it down. Two versions of the game were developed: one for the [[Wii]] by [[Sonic Team]], and one for the [[Nintendo DS]] by [[Dimps]]. The game was designed for a wider demographic than previous games, specifically children and fans of the ''[[Super Mario]]'' series. In anticipation of the game's release, Sega delisted several ''Sonic'' games with sub-average [[Metacritic]] scores to increase the value of the brand.

''Sonic Colors'' received positive reviews. Critics recommended the title for its graphics, audio, gameplay, replay value, and considered it an improvement over previous installments. However, some criticized its difficulty and weak [[multiplayer]] mode. The game was a commercial success, selling over two million copies. The Wisp power-ups introduced in ''Sonic Colors'' became a staple of the ''Sonic'' series.

column4: Gameplay screenshot of ''Sonic Colors'', showing Sonic in one of the game's levels]]

column1: ''Sonic Colors'' is a [[platform game]] set in [[outer space]]. Players control [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)
column2: Sonic the Hedgehog]], whose goal is to save the [[Wisp (Sonic)
column3: Wisp]]s, an alien race that has been enslaved by [[Doctor Eggman]].<ref name=\"ignwii\" /> The game's main [[Overworld#Platform games
column4: hub]] is Doctor Eggman's Incredible Interstellar Amusement Park, an interplanetary [[amusement park]] that consists of six small planets chained to each other.<ref name=\"gswii\" /> Sonic must be guided through these planets to destroy the power source at their center.<ref name=\"nwr\"/>

column1: Each planet is split into seven parts: six main [[Level (video gaming)
column2: levels]] called acts and a [[Boss (video gaming)
column3: boss]] level.<ref name=\"gswii\" /> In each act, players must guide Sonic to the goal, whilst defeating enemies and dodging obstacles. In boss levels, players face one of Eggman's large robots, and must defeat it. Gameplay seamlessly shifts between [[Side-scrolling video game
column5: third-person]] perspectives.<ref name=\"gswii\" /><ref name=\"wired\" /> Upon completion of a level, players are given a grade dependent on their performance, with an \"S\" being the best and a \"D\" being the worst.<ref name=\"James Newton\">{{Cite web
column15: access-date=September 21, 2017}}</ref> As the player progresses through the game, more planets become available to select. Once each planet has been completed, a bonus seventh, which concludes the story, is unlocked.<ref name=\"brady\" />

column1: Players control Sonic using the [[Wii Remote]] (with or without the [[Wii Nunchuck
column3: Classic Controller]], or the [[Nintendo GameCube Controller]]. Sonic retains most of his abilities from ''[[Sonic Unleashed]]'':<ref name=\"sonicstadiuminterview\" /> he can perform a \"Sonic Boost\" which greatly increases his speed and allows him to smash through various objects;<ref name=\"wisp\">{{cite web
column6: title=Sonic Colors power-ups are looking a bit... familiar
column13: archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> a homing attack that allows him to destroy enemies from long distances;<ref name=\"eurog\" /> and a stomp that enables him to quickly destroy objects below him. In certain levels, players are sent at high speeds and must perform a quick step maneuver to dodge walls and other hazards;<ref name=\"destructrev\" /> others see Sonic using a drift mechanic in order to make sharp turns. Sonic is also given a double-jump ability, which allows him to perform an additional jump in mid-air.<ref name=\"eurog\" />

column4: Sonic uses the Orange Rocket, one of the eight Wisps in ''Sonic Colors'']]

column1: A major aspect of ''Sonic Colors'' is the ability to activate Wisp [[power-up]]s.<ref name=\"grrev\" /> There are eight different types of Wisps, each with their own unique advantage dependent on their color.<ref name=\"ignwii\" /> Normal white-colored Wisps allow the player to get a speed boost at any time.<ref name=\"wisp\"/> The \"Cyan Laser\" turns Sonic into a laser that can bounce off solid surfaces to change the laser's path and to travel through power lines,<ref name=\"grrev\" /> while the \"Yellow Drill\" allows Sonic to drill through soft ground and water.<ref name=\"grrev\" /> The \"Orange Rocket\" allows Sonic to blast upward to tremendous heights;<ref name=\"gids\" /> the \"Pink Spikes\" allows Sonic to bond to walls and ceilings and to perform a spin dash to gain velocity and to destroy objects;<ref name=\"grrev\" /> the \"Green Hover\" enables Sonic to hover and to perform dashes across lines of rings;<ref name=\"gswii\" /> the \"Blue Cube\" gives Sonic the ability to turn blue blocks into blue rings and vice versa;<ref name=\"James Newton\" /> and the \"Purple Frenzy\", which turns Sonic into a berserker that chomps through anything in its path, increasing in size as it continues to eat.<ref name=\"gswii\" />
Like previous games, Sonic collects golden [[Rings (Sonic the Hedgehog)
column2: rings]],<ref name=\"gswii\" /> which protect him from a single hit by an enemy or obstacle, though they will scatter and blink before disappearing. Sonic starts the game with a limited number of [[Life (gaming)
column3: lives]]; if he is hit with no rings in his possession, he will lose a life.<ref name=\"ignwii\" /> If a player exhausts their lives, they will receive a [[game over]].<ref name=\"brady\" />

column2: co-operative]] [[two-player]] mode, ''Eggman's Sonic Simulator,'' in which players control Sonic-modeled robots or their [[Mii]] characters through a series of levels.<ref name=\"nwr\" /> These levels can be unlocked by collecting special Red Star Rings hidden throughout each act.<ref name=\"gswii\" /> Completing ''Sonic Simulator'' levels rewards the player [[Chaos Emeralds]], and once all seven are collected, Sonic can transform into [[Sonic the Hedgehog#Super transformation
column3: Super Sonic]] after collecting 50 rings in normal levels. As Super Sonic, players are invincible and can boost infinitely, though they cannot use Wisps and lose one ring per second, de-transforming when the ring counter hits zero.<ref name=\"brady\" /> The game also features online leaderboards, allowing players to upload their scores via [[Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection]].<ref name=\"gsds\">{{cite web
