column2: Serbian]] (singular ''strip'') and come in all shapes and sizes, merging influences from [[American comic book

column1: Comics started developing in Serbia in the late 19th century, mostly in [[Humor magazine
column3: children’s magazines]]. From the 1920s to the end of the 1980s, Serbian comics were part of the larger [[Yugoslavia
column4: Yugoslav]] comics scene; a large number of titles was published from 1932 to 1991, mainly in [[Serbo-Croatian language]]. After [[Yugoslav Wars
column5: the breakup of Yugoslavia]] and the crisis in the 1990s, Serbian comics have experienced a revival.
quote=When we started out, nobody thought how it’d all turn out, or what it’d become. How far we’d come! Simply put, we liked the new medium, although nobody realized it was a new medium.

Zigomar]]'', created by artist Nikola Navojev and writer Branko Vidić and heavily influenced by foreign [[masked hero]] comics, is considered one of the most notable titles of the \"Golden Age of Serbian Comics\".]]

column1: In 1932 ''Veseli četvrtak'' (''Merry Thursday''), an illustrated magazine for children, appeared in [[Belgrade]]; an unusually large amount of space was allotted to [[cartoon]]s. The magazine featured foreign works such as ''[[The Katzenjammer Kids]]'' and ''[[Felix the Cat]]'', but also ''Doživljaji Mike Miša'' (''The Adventures of Mika the Mouse''), a [[Mickey Mouse]] [[pastiche]] by Serbian authors. Other [[Weekly newspaper
column2: weeklies]] and dailies such as ''Vreme'' and ''Pravda'' followed suit.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Tri generacije srpskih strip autora u Francuskom institutu, od Đorđa Lobačeva do Alekse Gajića
column7: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> In 1934, one whole page of ''[[Politika]]'' newspaper was devoted to ''[[Secret Agent X-9]]''. In addition to adventure comics, [[Walt Disney]]'s [[funny animal]]s were also popular at the time, especially Mickey Mouse, whose name would be used in the titles of a number of Yugoslav comic publications: ''Mika Miš'', ''Mikijeve novine'' (''Mickey's Newspapers''), ''Mikijevo carstvo'' (''Mickey's Empire''). An editor named Dušan Timotijević named the new art form \"strip\", after English \"[[comic strip]]\".

column1: In 1934, the first two specialized [[comic magazine]]s appeared - ''Strip'' and ''Crtani film'' (''Cartoon''). Their appearance and content were influenced by the Italian magazines ''[[Topolino]]'', ''[[L'Audace]]'' and ''[[L'Avventuroso]]'', as well as French magazines ''[[Le Journal de Mickey]]'' and ''[[Hop-là!]]''. [[White émigré
column2: Russian immigrant]] [[Nikola Navojev]] debuted in the pages of ''Strip'' with his works. Although he died at the age of 27,<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> Navojev was a prolific author who created a number of characters for Strip, of which [[Jungle girl (stock character)
column7: jungle girl]] Tarcaneta (''Tarzanette'') is best-known today.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> In 1935, inspired by the adventures of [[Alex Raymond]]'s X-9, Vlastimir Belkić created the first original character in Serbian comics named Hari Vils.<ref>{{Cite web
column14: access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref> Similarly, other two Russian immigrants, artist [[Đorđe Lobačev]] and writer Vadim Kurganski, began working on their first comic, called ''Krvavo nasledstvo'' (''Bloody Heritage''), serialized in the illustrated periodical ''Panorama''.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column18: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> Not only was it the first successful modern comic produced in Serbia, but also the first title set in Yugoslavia.<ref>{{Cite book

column4: ''[[Master Death]]'', drawn by Đorđe Lobačev and published in ''Mikijevo carstvo'', is one of the most notable titles of the \"Golden Age of Serbian comics\". Published on the eve of World War II, ''Master Death'' carried a strong anti-war message.]]

column1: Most of the Golden Age artists were Russian immigrants, collectively known as the Belgrade Circle and gathered at first around the ''Mika Miš'' magazine. Soon enough it was transformed into a real comic magazine, reprinting foreign classics like ''[[Prince Valiant]]'', [[Phantom (comics)
column2: ''Phantom'']] and ''[[Flash Gordon]]'', but also publishing comics by the local authors. ''Mika Miš'' lasted from 1936 to 1941, when it ended with issue 505.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Mika Mis (1936 - 1941) by Aleksandar J. Ivkovic < Serbia and Montenegro @ Disney Comics Worldwide
column6: access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> Its domination would not be questioned until 1939 and the emergence of ''Mikijevo carstvo'' and ''[[Politikin Zabavnik]]''. The key figures behind all three publications were editors Aleksandar J. Ivković and Milutin Ignjačević.<ref name=\":0\" /> From 1935 to 1941 about twenty comic magazines were launched in Serbia, published weekly and bi-weekly, mostly in black-and-white. They were sold throughout Yugoslavia. In order to boost sales in the western parts of Yugoslavia (today's [[Croatia]] and [[Slovenia]]), some publications were printed not only in the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet
column7: Serbian Cyrillic]] but also [[Latin alphabet]]. Comics were distributed through [[convenience store]]s, [[Newsagent's shop
column9: newsboys]], with an average print run of 10,000 - 30,000 copies.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=[Projekat Rastko] Zdravko Zupan: The Golden Age of Serbian Comics

column1: The notable works were inspired by cultural classics and [[Serbian folklore]]. The shortlist includes [[Ivan Šenšin]]'s ''Hrabri vojnik Švejk'' (an adaptation of [[Jaroslav Hašek]]'s novel ''[[The Good Soldier Švejk]]'') and ''Zvonar Bogorodičine crkve'' (and adaptation of [[Victor Hugo]]'s novel ''[[The Hunchback of Notre-Dame]]''), [[Sergej Solovjev]]'s ''Carev štitonoša'' (''Emperor's Squire''), ''Robin Hud'' (''[[Robin Hood]]'') and ''Ajvanho'' (an adaptation of [[Walter Scott]]'s ''[[Ivanhoe]]''), Lobačev's ''[[Master Death]]'', ''Baron Minhauzen'' (an adaptation of [[Rudolf Erich Raspe]]'s ''[[Baron Munchausen
column2: The Surprising Adventures of Baron Munchausen]]'') and ''Biberče'' (''Pepper-Boy'', based on the Serbian folk [[fairytale]] of the same name), [[Konstantin Kuznjecov]]'s ''Grofica Margo'' (''Countess Margo'') and ''Bajka o caru Saltanu'' (an adaptation of [[Alexander Pushkin]]'s [[poem]] ''[[The Tale of Tsar Saltan]]''). Unlike most of his contemporaries, [[Sebastijan Lechner]] also wrote his own scripts, such as ''Džarto''.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> Similarly, Navojev teamed up with [[Script (comics)
column8: ''Zigomar'']]. Some of the titles were reprinted in [[France
column12: title=The MysterIous Flame of Queen Loana: YUGOSLAVIAN COMICS IN TURKEY - PART 1: COUNTESS MARGO
column16: website=The MysterIous Flame of Queen Loana
column17: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> while ''Zigomar'' was also published in [[Bulgaria]], [[Italy]] and [[Argentina]].<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Other creators of \"the first generation\" included Vsevold Guljevič, Aleksije Ranhner, Đorđe Janković, Moma Marković, Marijan Ebner, Vojin Đorđević, Nikola Tiščenko, Dragan Savić and Đorđe Mali. Lobačev's brother-in-law Valerian Apuhtin became the first professional [[letterer]] in Serbia. Another young artist at the time, [[Živorad Mitrović]] would revisit this period in his 1982 film ''Savamala''.<ref>{{Citation
The Golden Age of Serbian comics ended with the Nazi [[invasion of Yugoslavia]] in 1941. After [[World War II]] some authors were executed as [[Collaborationism
column10: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> by [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia
column11: the new communist regime]] or forced to [[Emigration

column1: After World War II, the communist government considered comics a decadent product of the [[Western world#Cold War context
column2: West]], therefore worthless and even harmful for children. In 1946 [[State-controlled media
column4: Borba]]'' criticized comics as \"[[black market]] [[ersatz good]]s\".<ref>{{Cite web
column8: access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref> For years to come, comics would be discouraged or outright banned. New magazines like ''Tri ugursuza'' (''Three Rowdies'', the Yugoslav title of ''[[Les Pieds Nickelés]]'') and ''Vrabac'' (''The Sparrow'') were short-lived, although comic strips and cartoons survived in the humor magazines ''Jež'' (''Hedgehog'')<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> and ''Mali Jež'' (''Little Hedgehog''), where [[Milorad Dobrić]] and Dejan Nastić published in the 1960s.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: The outlook changed after the [[Tito–Stalin Split
column2: Tito-Stalin Split]] in 1948. In 1951 Walt Disney’s comics returned to Serbia’s newspapers. In 1952 ''Politikin Zabavnik'' was revived, boasting a circulation of 450,000 in the 1970s.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref> (The magazine is still published, having reached its 3000th issue in 2009.)<ref>{{Cite web
column9: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> Lobačev was welcomed back to the pages of ''Zabavnik'' in 1965. However, it would publish few local comics until [[Lazo Sredanović]]’s ''[[Dikan]]'' in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web

column4: ''[[Dikan]]'' by Lazo Sredanović was commissioned by ''[[Politikin Zabavnik]]'' and modeled after ''[[Asterix]]''.]]

column1: Nevertheless, back in the 1950s comic magazines like ''Robinzon'' (''[[Robinson Crusoe
column2: Robinson]]'') and ''Veseli zabavnik'' were still censored, but even the [[Yugoslav People's Army]] started publishing some.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=[Projekat Rastko] Zdravko Zupan: Strip u Srbiji 1955-1972.
column6: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> Zdravko Sulić began his career in such a publication, most of his works later published in the magazine [[Kekec (magazine)
column12: Borba]] in 1957, featuring French comics such as ''[[Lucky Luke]]'', [[The Smurfs
column13: ''Smurfs'']] and ''[[Chlorophylle]]'', but also domestic titles, including the works of \"the second generation\" of creators, like Aleksandar Hecl of ''Vinetu'' (''[[Winnetou]]'') fame.<ref>{{Cite web
column18: four-color]] ''Kekec'' publication reached the print run of 300,000 copies.<ref name=\":2\" /> ''Kekec'' lasted for 1532 issues and ended in 1990.

column1: 1957 also saw teachers from the small town of [[Gornji Milanovac]] launch [[student newspaper]] ''[[Dečje novine]]'', which grew into a major publisher. Their most successful characters were [[Mirko and Slavko]], heroes of the [[eponym]]ous [[comic book]]. In the 1960s the adventures of the two [[Yugoslav Partisans
column2: Partisans]] peaked at 200,000 copies per issue. To date, it is the only Yugoslav comic adapted into a [[live action]] movie.<ref>Marković, Đorđe (2012). SFRJ za početnike. Delta Video.</ref> The title was serialized in the ''Nikad robom'' comic book series, which also printed works by Petar Radičević (''Mystery Knight''), Radivoj Bogičević (''Akant''), Božidar Veselinović (''Dabiša'') and Živorad Atanacković (''Hajduk Veljko''), all inspired by the history of the [[South Slavs]]. The same publisher launched a number of other magazines, including ''Zenit'' and ''Biblioteka Lale'' (which first reprinted [[Marvel Comics
column3: Marvel comics]] in Yugoslavia) and ''Eks almanah'' (which introduced [[DC Comics

column1: [[File:Cover to YU strip issue 31, featuring Kobra, art by Branislav Kerac.jpg
column5: Kobra]]'' by [[Branislav Kerac]], a comic which merged influences from [[Action film

column2: spin-off]] in 1977, the ''[[YU strip]]'' magazine turned to be the seminal publication for Serbian authors. Teamed up with writer [[Svetozar Obradović]], [[Branislav Kerac]] had already debuted with ''Lieutenant Tara'' in the ''Zlatni kliker'' magazine.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> The duo went on to create [[Kobra (comic book)
column7: ''Kobra'']], the most popular Yugoslav comic of the 1980s. Kerac’s super-heroine [[Cat Claw]] reached even greater success abroad.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> A number of local creators ([[Zoran Janjetov]], [[R. M. Guéra
column12: R.M. Guera]], [[Darko Perović]], [[Zoran Tucić]], [[Vujadin Radovanović]], [[Željko Pahek]], [[Dejan Nenadov]], [[Vladimir Krstić - Laci
column13: Vladimir Krstić]] and many others) published their early stories in ''YU strip'' before they went on to work for foreign publishers. The magazine lasted for 85 issues and ended in 1987.

column1: By the late 1970s, the scene rebounded after the blow it had suffered from the 1972 tax law<ref>{{Cite web
column4: access-date=2016-07-21}}</ref> which targeted not only the [[Yellow journalism
column5: yellow press]] but also comics. From 1971 to 1981, 11,611 issues of comics and [[Pulp magazine
column6: pulp novels]] were printed in Yugoslavia, a total of 717 million copies in the country of 22 million people.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Yugopapir: Fenomen popularnosti stripa: U Jugoslaviji je od 1971 - 81. prodato 716 miliona primeraka

column1: Meanwhile, the student press welcomed [[comics studies]]<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref> and [[alternative comics]] of \"the third generation\",<ref>{{Cite journal
column17: via=}}</ref> inspired by ''[[Métal hurlant]]''. The ''Pegaz'' magazine was another publication that nurtured comics theory; it was also where the award-winning  ''Svemironi'' strip by Lazar Stanojević premiered in 1975.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In addition, comic groups like Belgrade Circle 2 and Bauhaus 7 appeared, comic album was introduced as a new format, and the first [[Animated cartoon
column2: animated short]] based on a comic was filmed.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-30}}</ref> The mass media embraced comics insomuch that the [[Radio Television of Serbia
column7: national television]] produced an educational series on the medium.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: first=RTS, Radio televizija Srbije, Radio Television of

column1: Another new trend in the 1960s was the emergence of more comic magazines outside of Belgrade. Published by Forum in [[Novi Sad]], ''Panorama'' was eventually transformed into ''[[Stripoteka]]'', which reached issue 1000 in 2004<ref>{{Cite web
column4: access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> and still comes out today. [[Dnevnik (Serbia)
column5: Dnevnik]] launched ''Zlatna serija'' and ''Lunov magnus strip'', featuring [[Italian comics
column7: ''Tex'']] and ''[[Zagor]]''. In the 1980s Kerac spearheaded teams of writers and artists working on [[Licensed production
column10: Blek]] comics for these two publishers. The list included artists [[Branko Plavšić]], [[Goran Đukić Gorski (artist)
column12: Miodrag Ivanović]], [[Pavel Koza]], [[Marinko Lebović]], [[Petar Meseldžija]], Milan Miletić, [[Sibin Slavković]] and [[Dragan Stokić Rajački]]. The [[Ninja (comic book)
column14: Lun kralj ponoći]] comics were similarly manufactured, but were based on the Yugoslav pulp novels of the same names.

column1: Until 1991 Serbian comics were part of Yugoslav comics. Distributed via newsstands, most comics were sold throughout Yugoslavia, written by and large in the common [[Shtokavian]] dialect and often printed in the Latin alphabet.
Publications from other republics, especially Croatia, from Plavi Vjesnik to ''[[Alan Ford (comics)
column2: Alan Ford]]'', had a great influence on creators and readers in Serbia. A [[Play (theatre)
column3: play]] titled ''Alan Ford'' written by Mirjana Lazić and directed by Kokan Mladenović was staged at Teatar T in Belgrade in 1994. [[Radio Belgrade]] produced a [[radio drama]] based on the play in 2002.

column1: Also, authors worked for publishers outside Serbia, e.g. artists Dušan Reljić, Bojan Đukić, Ratomir Petrović, [[Zdravko Zupan]], [[Nikola Maslovara]] and Zoran Kovačević, as well as writer Lazar Odanović collaborated on the licensed [[Tom and Jerry]] comics for ''[[Vjesnik]]''.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Slobodan Ivkov: 60 godina stripa u Srbiji
column5: access-date=2016-07-24}}</ref> Finally, artists exhibited at the joint Yugoslav Comics Festival in [[Vinkovci]] (Salon jugoslovenskog stripa).

column1: The local comic book industry collapsed with the breakup of Yugoslavia.

column4: Graphic novel ''Treći argument'' (''[[The Third Argument]]''), drawn by Zoran Tucić and written by [[Zoran Stefanović]], was based on the works of writer [[Milorad Pavić]].]]In the 1990s dozens of Serbian artists turned to foreign publishers. After ''Bernard Panasonik,'' Zoran Janjetov was chosen to work on ''Before the Incal'',<ref>{{Cite web
column11: Jodorowsky]]. In 1998 Janjetov would go on to draw ''[[The Technopriests]]''. Darko Perović collaborated with writer [[Enrique Sánchez Abulí
column12: Enrique Abuli]] before he started working on ''[[Magico Vento]]'' (written by [[Gianfranco Manfredi]]) for [[Sergio Bonelli Editore]].<ref>{{Cite web
column16: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> In 1998 [[Aleksa Gajić]] graduated with ''[[Technotise]]'' ([[graphic novel]] written by Darko Grkinić) from the [[University of Arts in Belgrade]] and went on to work for [[Soleil Productions]] as the illustrator on ''[[Scourge of the Gods]]''. In 2009 he would revisit those characters in his ''[[Technotise: Edit & I]]'' [[animated feature film]], first of its kind in Serbia.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column20: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> R.M. Guerra worked in Europe for years<ref>{{Cite web
column24: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> before illustrating [[Jason Aaron]]’s ''[[Scalped]]'' for DC Comics’ [[Imprint (trade name)
column26: Vertigo]] in 2007. Željko Pahek and Zoran Tucić published in [[Heavy Metal (magazine)
column27: ''Heavy Metal'']] and other magazines abroad.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Back home, enthusiasts kept the scene alive. First [[Direct market
column2: comic book stores]] were opened<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> and [[comic book convention]]s organized.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> A co-founder of the [[International Comics Festival \"Salon stripa\"
column11: International Comics Festival in Belgrade]] and teacher at the “Đorđe Lobačev“ comics school, artist [[Vladimir Vesović]] launched ''Tron'' in 1992<ref name=\":3\" /> and ''Stripmania'' in 1996.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=I L I J A D A: Резултати претраживања за mania
column14: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> The former also carried comics by local creators, such as ''Swindle'' by Đorđe Milosavljević and Miroljub Milutinović Brada, which was adapted for television in 2020.<ref>{{Cite web
column20: access-date=2020-01-24}}</ref> The latter was printed by Luxor Comics, a publishing house owned by [[Milan Konjević]], who also wrote and published ''[[Generation Tesla]]'' and ''Twilight Fighters'' in 1995, as well as ''Factor 4'' and ''Wild Magic'' in 2006, all titles drawn by Serbian artists. Before he started working for [[Dupuis]], artist [[Milan Jovanović (artist)
column21: Milan Jovanović]] teamed up with Croatian writer [[Darko Macan]] to produce [[La Bête Noire (comics)
column26: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> the five-part series was published by Zlatko Milenković, editor of the pioneering ''Strip vesti'' [[web portal]].<ref>{{Cite web
column30: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> 2007 saw two more series appear; writer Marko Stojanović with a team of artists launched ''[[Vekovnici]]'' (''Endless''),<ref>{{Cite web
column36: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> while Vladimir Tadić created ''Zabava za celu porodicu'' (''Fun for the Whole Family'') with a different artistic team.<ref>{{Cite web
column38: title=Zabava za celu porodicu - Enciklopedija - www.stripovi.com - Prozor u svijet stripa
column40: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> In a category of his own, award-winning illustrator<ref>{{Cite web
column44: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> [[Đorđe Milović]] continues to create his ''Stories about the Clay''.<ref>{{Cite web
column48: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> Forum's successor Marketprint revamped ''Stripoteka'' after an eight-year break in 1999<ref>{{Cite web
column57: access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref> officially the first [[manga]] title in Serbia. However, the circulations were low and the newsstand editions struggled to find their feet.

column2: underground comics]] experienced an unprecedented boom. Aleksandar Rakezić alias [[Aleksandar Zograf]], author of ''Life Under Sanctions'' ([[Fantagraphics Books]], 1994), had laid a groundwork as a pioneer of comic [[fanzine]]s in the 1980s. A decade later, authors like Danilo Milošev Wostok, Saša Mihajlović, Danijel Savović, Radovan Popović, Nikola Vitković, Lazar Bodroža and many others gathered around self-published editions and managed to create original and authentic works.<ref>{{Cite book
column13: title=Oct. 2nd – ON THE MARGINS: NEW COMIX FROM CROATIA AND SERBIA {{!}} Floating World Comics
column15: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> For the first time since the late 1980s, a comic was censored in Serbia.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: access-date=2016-07-30}}</ref> Some would eventually try their hand at mainstream, like Leonid Pilipović<ref>{{Cite web
column29: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> or turn to illustration, like Neda Dokić<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In the 21st century new publishers (such as Lavirint, System Comics, Komiko, Darkwood, Rosenkrantz and others) continue to nurture international as well as Serbian comics.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> However, the print runs remain limited, so artists have been forced to seek work abroad, especially in France.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> The list includes Vladimir Aleksić,<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Aleksic, Vladimir - Bibliographie, BD, photo, biographie
column44: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> and others. Comics in Serbia had all but retreated to bookstores and galleries until publisher Veseli četvrtak reintroduced Bonelli comics to the newsstands in 2008. As of 2018, the best-selling graphic novel in recent history has been ''Sat'' (''Watch''), a [[World War I
column45: WW1]] story written by [[Dragan de Lazare
column46: Dragan Lazarević De Lazare]] and drawn by [[Vujadin Radovanović
column47: Vujadin Radovanović Vuja]] with colors by [[Rade Tovladijac]]; it was distributed in 120,000 copies via daily ''[[Večernje novosti]]'' to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the [[Armistice of 11 November 1918]].<ref>{{Cite web

column7: access-date=2020-01-29}}</ref> loosely based on Miloš Slavković's  ''Lightstep Chronicles'' comic was developed by [[Eipix Entertainment]]; the book itself was funded on [[Kickstarter]] in 2017<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=LIGHTSTEP CHRONICLES – Retro Futurist Space Opera Comic Book
column12: access-date=2020-01-29}}</ref> and published by [[Dark Horse Comics
column13: Dark Horse]] a year later.<ref>{{Cite web

column2: documentary series]] featuring interviews with local authors.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Dokumentarni serijal \"Kvadrati i oblačići\" od petka na RTV1

column2: Serbian]] (singular ''strip'') and come in all shapes and sizes, merging influences from [[American comic book

column1: Comics started developing in Serbia in the late 19th century, mostly in [[Humor magazine
column3: children’s magazines]]. From the 1920s to the end of the 1980s, Serbian comics were part of the larger [[Yugoslavia
column4: Yugoslav]] comics scene; a large number of titles was published from 1932 to 1991, mainly in [[Serbo-Croatian language]]. After [[Yugoslav Wars
column5: the breakup of Yugoslavia]] and the crisis in the 1990s, Serbian comics have experienced a revival.
quote=When we started out, nobody thought how it’d all turn out, or what it’d become. How far we’d come! Simply put, we liked the new medium, although nobody realized it was a new medium.

Zigomar]]'', created by artist Nikola Navojev and writer Branko Vidić and heavily influenced by foreign [[masked hero]] comics, is considered one of the most notable titles of the \"Golden Age of Serbian Comics\".]]

column1: In 1932 ''Veseli četvrtak'' (''Merry Thursday''), an illustrated magazine for children, appeared in [[Belgrade]]; an unusually large amount of space was allotted to [[cartoon]]s. The magazine featured foreign works such as ''[[The Katzenjammer Kids]]'' and ''[[Felix the Cat]]'', but also ''Doživljaji Mike Miša'' (''The Adventures of Mika the Mouse''), a [[Mickey Mouse]] [[pastiche]] by Serbian authors. Other [[Weekly newspaper
column2: weeklies]] and dailies such as ''Vreme'' and ''Pravda'' followed suit.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Tri generacije srpskih strip autora u Francuskom institutu, od Đorđa Lobačeva do Alekse Gajića
column7: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> In 1934, one whole page of ''[[Politika]]'' newspaper was devoted to ''[[Secret Agent X-9]]''. In addition to adventure comics, [[Walt Disney]]'s [[funny animal]]s were also popular at the time, especially Mickey Mouse, whose name would be used in the titles of a number of Yugoslav comic publications: ''Mika Miš'', ''Mikijeve novine'' (''Mickey's Newspapers''), ''Mikijevo carstvo'' (''Mickey's Empire''). An editor named Dušan Timotijević named the new art form \"strip\", after English \"[[comic strip]]\".

column1: In 1934, the first two specialized [[comic magazine]]s appeared - ''Strip'' and ''Crtani film'' (''Cartoon''). Their appearance and content were influenced by the Italian magazines ''[[Topolino]]'', ''[[L'Audace]]'' and ''[[L'Avventuroso]]'', as well as French magazines ''[[Le Journal de Mickey]]'' and ''[[Hop-là!]]''. [[White émigré
column2: Russian immigrant]] [[Nikola Navojev]] debuted in the pages of ''Strip'' with his works. Although he died at the age of 27,<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> Navojev was a prolific author who created a number of characters for Strip, of which [[Jungle girl (stock character)
column7: jungle girl]] Tarcaneta (''Tarzanette'') is best-known today.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> In 1935, inspired by the adventures of [[Alex Raymond]]'s X-9, Vlastimir Belkić created the first original character in Serbian comics named Hari Vils.<ref>{{Cite web
column14: access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref> Similarly, other two Russian immigrants, artist [[Đorđe Lobačev]] and writer Vadim Kurganski, began working on their first comic, called ''Krvavo nasledstvo'' (''Bloody Heritage''), serialized in the illustrated periodical ''Panorama''.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column18: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> Not only was it the first successful modern comic produced in Serbia, but also the first title set in Yugoslavia.<ref>{{Cite book

column4: ''[[Master Death]]'', drawn by Đorđe Lobačev and published in ''Mikijevo carstvo'', is one of the most notable titles of the \"Golden Age of Serbian comics\". Published on the eve of World War II, ''Master Death'' carried a strong anti-war message.]]

column1: Most of the Golden Age artists were Russian immigrants, collectively known as the Belgrade Circle and gathered at first around the ''Mika Miš'' magazine. Soon enough it was transformed into a real comic magazine, reprinting foreign classics like ''[[Prince Valiant]]'', [[Phantom (comics)
column2: ''Phantom'']] and ''[[Flash Gordon]]'', but also publishing comics by the local authors. ''Mika Miš'' lasted from 1936 to 1941, when it ended with issue 505.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Mika Mis (1936 - 1941) by Aleksandar J. Ivkovic < Serbia and Montenegro @ Disney Comics Worldwide
column6: access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> Its domination would not be questioned until 1939 and the emergence of ''Mikijevo carstvo'' and ''[[Politikin Zabavnik]]''. The key figures behind all three publications were editors Aleksandar J. Ivković and Milutin Ignjačević.<ref name=\":0\" /> From 1935 to 1941 about twenty comic magazines were launched in Serbia, published weekly and bi-weekly, mostly in black-and-white. They were sold throughout Yugoslavia. In order to boost sales in the western parts of Yugoslavia (today's [[Croatia]] and [[Slovenia]]), some publications were printed not only in the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet
column7: Serbian Cyrillic]] but also [[Latin alphabet]]. Comics were distributed through [[convenience store]]s, [[Newsagent's shop
column9: newsboys]], with an average print run of 10,000 - 30,000 copies.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=[Projekat Rastko] Zdravko Zupan: The Golden Age of Serbian Comics

column1: The notable works were inspired by cultural classics and [[Serbian folklore]]. The shortlist includes [[Ivan Šenšin]]'s ''Hrabri vojnik Švejk'' (an adaptation of [[Jaroslav Hašek]]'s novel ''[[The Good Soldier Švejk]]'') and ''Zvonar Bogorodičine crkve'' (and adaptation of [[Victor Hugo]]'s novel ''[[The Hunchback of Notre-Dame]]''), [[Sergej Solovjev]]'s ''Carev štitonoša'' (''Emperor's Squire''), ''Robin Hud'' (''[[Robin Hood]]'') and ''Ajvanho'' (an adaptation of [[Walter Scott]]'s ''[[Ivanhoe]]''), Lobačev's ''[[Master Death]]'', ''Baron Minhauzen'' (an adaptation of [[Rudolf Erich Raspe]]'s ''[[Baron Munchausen
column2: The Surprising Adventures of Baron Munchausen]]'') and ''Biberče'' (''Pepper-Boy'', based on the Serbian folk [[fairytale]] of the same name), [[Konstantin Kuznjecov]]'s ''Grofica Margo'' (''Countess Margo'') and ''Bajka o caru Saltanu'' (an adaptation of [[Alexander Pushkin]]'s [[poem]] ''[[The Tale of Tsar Saltan]]''). Unlike most of his contemporaries, [[Sebastijan Lechner]] also wrote his own scripts, such as ''Džarto''.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> Similarly, Navojev teamed up with [[Script (comics)
column8: ''Zigomar'']]. Some of the titles were reprinted in [[France
column12: title=The MysterIous Flame of Queen Loana: YUGOSLAVIAN COMICS IN TURKEY - PART 1: COUNTESS MARGO
column16: website=The MysterIous Flame of Queen Loana
column17: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> while ''Zigomar'' was also published in [[Bulgaria]], [[Italy]] and [[Argentina]].<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Other creators of \"the first generation\" included Vsevold Guljevič, Aleksije Ranhner, Đorđe Janković, Moma Marković, Marijan Ebner, Vojin Đorđević, Nikola Tiščenko, Dragan Savić and Đorđe Mali. Lobačev's brother-in-law Valerian Apuhtin became the first professional [[letterer]] in Serbia. Another young artist at the time, [[Živorad Mitrović]] would revisit this period in his 1982 film ''Savamala''.<ref>{{Citation
The Golden Age of Serbian comics ended with the Nazi [[invasion of Yugoslavia]] in 1941. After [[World War II]] some authors were executed as [[Collaborationism
column10: access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> by [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia
column11: the new communist regime]] or forced to [[Emigration

column1: After World War II, the communist government considered comics a decadent product of the [[Western world#Cold War context
column2: West]], therefore worthless and even harmful for children. In 1946 [[State-controlled media
column4: Borba]]'' criticized comics as \"[[black market]] [[ersatz good]]s\".<ref>{{Cite web
column8: access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref> For years to come, comics would be discouraged or outright banned. New magazines like ''Tri ugursuza'' (''Three Rowdies'', the Yugoslav title of ''[[Les Pieds Nickelés]]'') and ''Vrabac'' (''The Sparrow'') were short-lived, although comic strips and cartoons survived in the humor magazines ''Jež'' (''Hedgehog'')<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> and ''Mali Jež'' (''Little Hedgehog''), where [[Milorad Dobrić]] and Dejan Nastić published in the 1960s.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: The outlook changed after the [[Tito–Stalin Split
column2: Tito-Stalin Split]] in 1948. In 1951 Walt Disney’s comics returned to Serbia’s newspapers. In 1952 ''Politikin Zabavnik'' was revived, boasting a circulation of 450,000 in the 1970s.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref> (The magazine is still published, having reached its 3000th issue in 2009.)<ref>{{Cite web
column9: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> Lobačev was welcomed back to the pages of ''Zabavnik'' in 1965. However, it would publish few local comics until [[Lazo Sredanović]]’s ''[[Dikan]]'' in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web

column4: ''[[Dikan]]'' by Lazo Sredanović was commissioned by ''[[Politikin Zabavnik]]'' and modeled after ''[[Asterix]]''.]]

column1: Nevertheless, back in the 1950s comic magazines like ''Robinzon'' (''[[Robinson Crusoe
column2: Robinson]]'') and ''Veseli zabavnik'' were still censored, but even the [[Yugoslav People's Army]] started publishing some.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=[Projekat Rastko] Zdravko Zupan: Strip u Srbiji 1955-1972.
column6: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> Zdravko Sulić began his career in such a publication, most of his works later published in the magazine [[Kekec (magazine)
column12: Borba]] in 1957, featuring French comics such as ''[[Lucky Luke]]'', [[The Smurfs
column13: ''Smurfs'']] and ''[[Chlorophylle]]'', but also domestic titles, including the works of \"the second generation\" of creators, like Aleksandar Hecl of ''Vinetu'' (''[[Winnetou]]'') fame.<ref>{{Cite web
column18: four-color]] ''Kekec'' publication reached the print run of 300,000 copies.<ref name=\":2\" /> ''Kekec'' lasted for 1532 issues and ended in 1990.

column1: 1957 also saw teachers from the small town of [[Gornji Milanovac]] launch [[student newspaper]] ''[[Dečje novine]]'', which grew into a major publisher. Their most successful characters were [[Mirko and Slavko]], heroes of the [[eponym]]ous [[comic book]]. In the 1960s the adventures of the two [[Yugoslav Partisans
column2: Partisans]] peaked at 200,000 copies per issue. To date, it is the only Yugoslav comic adapted into a [[live action]] movie.<ref>Marković, Đorđe (2012). SFRJ za početnike. Delta Video.</ref> The title was serialized in the ''Nikad robom'' comic book series, which also printed works by Petar Radičević (''Mystery Knight''), Radivoj Bogičević (''Akant''), Božidar Veselinović (''Dabiša'') and Živorad Atanacković (''Hajduk Veljko''), all inspired by the history of the [[South Slavs]]. The same publisher launched a number of other magazines, including ''Zenit'' and ''Biblioteka Lale'' (which first reprinted [[Marvel Comics
column3: Marvel comics]] in Yugoslavia) and ''Eks almanah'' (which introduced [[DC Comics

column1: [[File:Cover to YU strip issue 31, featuring Kobra, art by Branislav Kerac.jpg
column5: Kobra]]'' by [[Branislav Kerac]], a comic which merged influences from [[Action film

column2: spin-off]] in 1977, the ''[[YU strip]]'' magazine turned to be the seminal publication for Serbian authors. Teamed up with writer [[Svetozar Obradović]], [[Branislav Kerac]] had already debuted with ''Lieutenant Tara'' in the ''Zlatni kliker'' magazine.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> The duo went on to create [[Kobra (comic book)
column7: ''Kobra'']], the most popular Yugoslav comic of the 1980s. Kerac’s super-heroine [[Cat Claw]] reached even greater success abroad.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> A number of local creators ([[Zoran Janjetov]], [[R. M. Guéra
column12: R.M. Guera]], [[Darko Perović]], [[Zoran Tucić]], [[Vujadin Radovanović]], [[Željko Pahek]], [[Dejan Nenadov]], [[Vladimir Krstić - Laci
column13: Vladimir Krstić]] and many others) published their early stories in ''YU strip'' before they went on to work for foreign publishers. The magazine lasted for 85 issues and ended in 1987.

column1: By the late 1970s, the scene rebounded after the blow it had suffered from the 1972 tax law<ref>{{Cite web
column4: access-date=2016-07-21}}</ref> which targeted not only the [[Yellow journalism
column5: yellow press]] but also comics. From 1971 to 1981, 11,611 issues of comics and [[Pulp magazine
column6: pulp novels]] were printed in Yugoslavia, a total of 717 million copies in the country of 22 million people.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Yugopapir: Fenomen popularnosti stripa: U Jugoslaviji je od 1971 - 81. prodato 716 miliona primeraka

column1: Meanwhile, the student press welcomed [[comics studies]]<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-07-18}}</ref> and [[alternative comics]] of \"the third generation\",<ref>{{Cite journal
column17: via=}}</ref> inspired by ''[[Métal hurlant]]''. The ''Pegaz'' magazine was another publication that nurtured comics theory; it was also where the award-winning  ''Svemironi'' strip by Lazar Stanojević premiered in 1975.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In addition, comic groups like Belgrade Circle 2 and Bauhaus 7 appeared, comic album was introduced as a new format, and the first [[Animated cartoon
column2: animated short]] based on a comic was filmed.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-07-30}}</ref> The mass media embraced comics insomuch that the [[Radio Television of Serbia
column7: national television]] produced an educational series on the medium.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: first=RTS, Radio televizija Srbije, Radio Television of

column1: Another new trend in the 1960s was the emergence of more comic magazines outside of Belgrade. Published by Forum in [[Novi Sad]], ''Panorama'' was eventually transformed into ''[[Stripoteka]]'', which reached issue 1000 in 2004<ref>{{Cite web
column4: access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> and still comes out today. [[Dnevnik (Serbia)
column5: Dnevnik]] launched ''Zlatna serija'' and ''Lunov magnus strip'', featuring [[Italian comics
column7: ''Tex'']] and ''[[Zagor]]''. In the 1980s Kerac spearheaded teams of writers and artists working on [[Licensed production
column10: Blek]] comics for these two publishers. The list included artists [[Branko Plavšić]], [[Goran Đukić Gorski (artist)
column12: Miodrag Ivanović]], [[Pavel Koza]], [[Marinko Lebović]], [[Petar Meseldžija]], Milan Miletić, [[Sibin Slavković]] and [[Dragan Stokić Rajački]]. The [[Ninja (comic book)
column14: Lun kralj ponoći]] comics were similarly manufactured, but were based on the Yugoslav pulp novels of the same names.

column1: Until 1991 Serbian comics were part of Yugoslav comics. Distributed via newsstands, most comics were sold throughout Yugoslavia, written by and large in the common [[Shtokavian]] dialect and often printed in the Latin alphabet.
Publications from other republics, especially Croatia, from Plavi Vjesnik to ''[[Alan Ford (comics)
column2: Alan Ford]]'', had a great influence on creators and readers in Serbia. A [[Play (theatre)
column3: play]] titled ''Alan Ford'' written by Mirjana Lazić and directed by Kokan Mladenović was staged at Teatar T in Belgrade in 1994. [[Radio Belgrade]] produced a [[radio drama]] based on the play in 2002.

column1: Also, authors worked for publishers outside Serbia, e.g. artists Dušan Reljić, Bojan Đukić, Ratomir Petrović, [[Zdravko Zupan]], [[Nikola Maslovara]] and Zoran Kovačević, as well as writer Lazar Odanović collaborated on the licensed [[Tom and Jerry]] comics for ''[[Vjesnik]]''.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Slobodan Ivkov: 60 godina stripa u Srbiji
column5: access-date=2016-07-24}}</ref> Finally, artists exhibited at the joint Yugoslav Comics Festival in [[Vinkovci]] (Salon jugoslovenskog stripa).

column1: The local comic book industry collapsed with the breakup of Yugoslavia.

column4: Graphic novel ''Treći argument'' (''[[The Third Argument]]''), drawn by Zoran Tucić and written by [[Zoran Stefanović]], was based on the works of writer [[Milorad Pavić]].]]In the 1990s dozens of Serbian artists turned to foreign publishers. After ''Bernard Panasonik,'' Zoran Janjetov was chosen to work on ''Before the Incal'',<ref>{{Cite web
column11: Jodorowsky]]. In 1998 Janjetov would go on to draw ''[[The Technopriests]]''. Darko Perović collaborated with writer [[Enrique Sánchez Abulí
column12: Enrique Abuli]] before he started working on ''[[Magico Vento]]'' (written by [[Gianfranco Manfredi]]) for [[Sergio Bonelli Editore]].<ref>{{Cite web
column16: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> In 1998 [[Aleksa Gajić]] graduated with ''[[Technotise]]'' ([[graphic novel]] written by Darko Grkinić) from the [[University of Arts in Belgrade]] and went on to work for [[Soleil Productions]] as the illustrator on ''[[Scourge of the Gods]]''. In 2009 he would revisit those characters in his ''[[Technotise: Edit & I]]'' [[animated feature film]], first of its kind in Serbia.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column20: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> R.M. Guerra worked in Europe for years<ref>{{Cite web
column24: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> before illustrating [[Jason Aaron]]’s ''[[Scalped]]'' for DC Comics’ [[Imprint (trade name)
column26: Vertigo]] in 2007. Željko Pahek and Zoran Tucić published in [[Heavy Metal (magazine)
column27: ''Heavy Metal'']] and other magazines abroad.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Back home, enthusiasts kept the scene alive. First [[Direct market
column2: comic book stores]] were opened<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> and [[comic book convention]]s organized.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> A co-founder of the [[International Comics Festival \"Salon stripa\"
column11: International Comics Festival in Belgrade]] and teacher at the “Đorđe Lobačev“ comics school, artist [[Vladimir Vesović]] launched ''Tron'' in 1992<ref name=\":3\" /> and ''Stripmania'' in 1996.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=I L I J A D A: Резултати претраживања за mania
column14: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> The former also carried comics by local creators, such as ''Swindle'' by Đorđe Milosavljević and Miroljub Milutinović Brada, which was adapted for television in 2020.<ref>{{Cite web
column20: access-date=2020-01-24}}</ref> The latter was printed by Luxor Comics, a publishing house owned by [[Milan Konjević]], who also wrote and published ''[[Generation Tesla]]'' and ''Twilight Fighters'' in 1995, as well as ''Factor 4'' and ''Wild Magic'' in 2006, all titles drawn by Serbian artists. Before he started working for [[Dupuis]], artist [[Milan Jovanović (artist)
column21: Milan Jovanović]] teamed up with Croatian writer [[Darko Macan]] to produce [[La Bête Noire (comics)
column26: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> the five-part series was published by Zlatko Milenković, editor of the pioneering ''Strip vesti'' [[web portal]].<ref>{{Cite web
column30: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> 2007 saw two more series appear; writer Marko Stojanović with a team of artists launched ''[[Vekovnici]]'' (''Endless''),<ref>{{Cite web
column36: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> while Vladimir Tadić created ''Zabava za celu porodicu'' (''Fun for the Whole Family'') with a different artistic team.<ref>{{Cite web
column38: title=Zabava za celu porodicu - Enciklopedija - www.stripovi.com - Prozor u svijet stripa
column40: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> In a category of his own, award-winning illustrator<ref>{{Cite web
column44: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> [[Đorđe Milović]] continues to create his ''Stories about the Clay''.<ref>{{Cite web
column48: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> Forum's successor Marketprint revamped ''Stripoteka'' after an eight-year break in 1999<ref>{{Cite web
column57: access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref> officially the first [[manga]] title in Serbia. However, the circulations were low and the newsstand editions struggled to find their feet.

column2: underground comics]] experienced an unprecedented boom. Aleksandar Rakezić alias [[Aleksandar Zograf]], author of ''Life Under Sanctions'' ([[Fantagraphics Books]], 1994), had laid a groundwork as a pioneer of comic [[fanzine]]s in the 1980s. A decade later, authors like Danilo Milošev Wostok, Saša Mihajlović, Danijel Savović, Radovan Popović, Nikola Vitković, Lazar Bodroža and many others gathered around self-published editions and managed to create original and authentic works.<ref>{{Cite book
column13: title=Oct. 2nd – ON THE MARGINS: NEW COMIX FROM CROATIA AND SERBIA {{!}} Floating World Comics
column15: access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> For the first time since the late 1980s, a comic was censored in Serbia.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: access-date=2016-07-30}}</ref> Some would eventually try their hand at mainstream, like Leonid Pilipović<ref>{{Cite web
column29: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> or turn to illustration, like Neda Dokić<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In the 21st century new publishers (such as Lavirint, System Comics, Komiko, Darkwood, Rosenkrantz and others) continue to nurture international as well as Serbian comics.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> However, the print runs remain limited, so artists have been forced to seek work abroad, especially in France.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> The list includes Vladimir Aleksić,<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Aleksic, Vladimir - Bibliographie, BD, photo, biographie
column44: access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> and others. Comics in Serbia had all but retreated to bookstores and galleries until publisher Veseli četvrtak reintroduced Bonelli comics to the newsstands in 2008. As of 2018, the best-selling graphic novel in recent history has been ''Sat'' (''Watch''), a [[World War I
