column1: '''WrestleMania XIX''' was the 19th annual [[WrestleMania]] [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) [[List of WWE pay-per-view events
column3: World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE). It took place on March 30, 2003, at [[Safeco Field]] in [[Seattle
column9: World Wrestling Entertainment]]}}</ref> The event was the first WrestleMania held in the [[U.S. state
column11: Washington]]. A record-breaking 54,097 fans from all fifty states and numerous countries from around the world at Safeco Field resulted in a gate attendance [[Gross (economics)
column16: title=WrestleMania XIX Breaks Attendance Record at SAFECO Field

column1: WrestleMania XIX was the first WrestleMania to be promoted under the WWE name and the first to have taken place after the [[WWE brand extension]]. It was a [[WWE brand extension
column2: joint-promotion]] pay-per-view event, featuring performers from the [[Raw (WWE brand)
column4: SmackDown!]] brands. The tagline for WrestleMania XIX was \"''Dare to Dream''\". The official theme song for the event was \"[[Crack Addict (song)
column5: Crack Addict]]\" by [[Limp Bizkit]]. Limp Bizkit performed the theme song live, as well as \"[[Rollin' (Air Raid Vehicle)]]\" during [[The Undertaker]]'s entrance.

column1: The main match from the SmackDown! brand was [[Kurt Angle]] versus [[Brock Lesnar]] for the [[WWE Championship]], which Lesnar won by [[Pin (professional wrestling)
column11: publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}}</ref> The main match from the Raw brand was the third WrestleMania meeting between [[Dwayne Johnson
column12: The Rock]] and [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]], in which The Rock won via pinfall after performing three Rock Bottoms on Austin; this marked Austin's final official match before his retirement from in-ring performance due to injuries sustained in previous years.<ref name=\"WMFacts\">{{cite web
column20: title=Full WWE WrestleMania XIX Results - 3/30/03 - Seattle, Washington
column23: publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> The other predominant match from the Raw brand was the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column24: World Heavyweight Championship]] bout between [[Triple H]] and [[Booker T (wrestler)
column25: Booker T]], which Triple H won by pinfall after performing a [[Facebuster#Double underhook facebuster
column30: publisher=TWM News}}</ref> Other matches on the [[Card (sports)#Undercard
column31: undercard]] included [[Shawn Michaels]] versus [[Chris Jericho]],<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/> and [[Hulk Hogan]] versus [[Vince McMahon
column32: Mr. McMahon]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Street Fight

column1: [[WrestleMania]] is considered [[World Wrestling Entertainment]]'s (WWE) flagship event, having first been held in [[WrestleMania I
column2: 1985]]. It is the longest-running professional wrestling event in history and is held annually between mid-March to mid-April.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=WrestleMania 29 press conference brings WWE to Radio City Music Hall
column9: quote=... WWE's flagship event lights up MetLife Stadium ... WrestleMania}}</ref> It was the first of WWE's original four pay-per-views, which includes [[Royal Rumble]], [[SummerSlam]], and [[Survivor Series]], dubbed the \"Big Four\".<ref>Ian Hamilton. ''Wrestling's Sinking Ship: What Happens to an Industry Without Competition'' (p. 160)</ref> It has been described as the [[Super Bowl]] of [[sports entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=WrestleMania is Super Bowl of sports entertainment
column17: archivedate=March 31, 2014}}</ref> It was the first WrestleMania promoted under the WWE name, following the company being renamed from World Wrestling Federation (WWF) to WWE in May 2002. It was also the first WrestleMania to be held under the first [[WWE brand extension
column18: brand extension]] that began in March 2002, which split the roster between the [[Raw (WWE brand)
column20: SmackDown]] brands, represented by the shows of the same name. It was also the first WrestleMania to feature the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column21: World Heavyweight Championship]] that was introduced for Raw in September 2002 after the WWE Undisputed Championship became exclusive to SmackDown and renamed to WWE Championship.

column1: A documentary entitled ''The Mania of WrestleMania'' was filmed live during the event and released the following year. It was the first sole production from [[WWE Studios

column2: feud]] heading into [[WrestleMania]] on the [[WWE SmackDown
column4: brand]] was between [[Kurt Angle]] and [[Brock Lesnar]], with the two feuding over the [[WWE Championship]]. Angle won the title three months prior at [[Armageddon (2002)
column5: Armageddon]] by defeating then-champion [[Big Show]] with Lesnar's help; Lesnar had lost the title at [[Survivor Series (2002)
column6: Survivor Series]] in November 2002 after his agent, [[Paul Heyman]], betrayed him and assisted Big Show in winning the match.<ref>{{cite web
column10: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the edition of ''SmackDown!'' immediately following Armageddon, Angle revealed that he too had taken on Heyman as his agent and together they would ensure Lesnar never got a shot to regain his title. Lesnar responded by brutally attacking Angle following the show, injuring the champion's knee.<ref>http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/smackdown02.htm</ref>

column2: Royal Rumble]], Angle faced [[Chris Benoit]] for his championship while Lesnar was forced to wrestle Big Show for a spot in the [[Royal Rumble match]], which guaranteed the winner a shot at his [[WWE Brand Extension
column3: brand]]'s championship at WrestleMania. Angle defeated Benoit by submission to retain his title. Lesnar defeated Big Show, despite interference from Heyman, to win his way into the Royal Rumble, which he entered at number 29 and won after last eliminating [[The Undertaker]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: publisher=WWE}}</ref> The following month at [[No Way Out (2003)
column8: No Way Out]], Lesnar and Benoit defeated [[The World's Greatest Tag Team
column9: Team Angle]] (Kurt Angle, [[Shelton Benjamin]], and [[Charlie Haas]]) in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match
column11: Edge]] was supposed to team up with Lesnar & Benoit to wrestle Team Angle in the scheduled [[Professional wrestling match types#Six Man Tag Team match
column12: Six Man Tag team match]] but Edge was attacked backstage and it was announced he could not participate in the match.<ref name=\"NWO1\">{{cite web
column16: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref><ref name=\"NWO2\">{{cite web
column20: accessdate=2008-02-22}}</ref> On the March 6 episode of ''[[WWE SmackDown
column21: SmackDown!]]'', Lesnar defeated [[Paul Heyman]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Cages
column22: steel cage match]] to earn a championship match against Angle.<ref name=\"SDMar61\">{{cite web
column26: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the March 13 episode of ''SmackDown!'', Angle defeated Lesnar to retain the WWE Championship. Before the match began, Kurt, who was \"praying\" in the corner, switched with his brother [[Eric Angle
column27: Eric]]. Lesnar then came out and the match began. Shortly after the match began, Benjamin and Haas came to the ring and distracted Lesnar, which gave Eric time to switch back with Kurt. As Lesnar regained his focus, Kurt was able to pin him with a [[Pin (professional wrestling)#Small package
column28: small package]] for the win.<ref name=\"SDMar131\">{{cite web
column32: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> The following week on the March 20 episode of ''SmackDown!'', SmackDown General Manager [[Stephanie McMahon]] told Angle that if he tried to get himself disqualified, counted out or if his brother, Benjamin, or Haas try to interfere in their match on Angle's behalf, he would lose the title.<ref name=\"SDMar201\">{{cite web

column1: The main feud on the [[WWE Raw
column3: The Rock]] and [[Stone Cold Steve Austin
column4: Steve Austin]]. On the February 20 episode of ''SmackDown!'', The Rock returned to WWE after a six-month hiatus from wrestling (since [[SummerSlam (2002)
column5: SummerSlam]]). On that evening, he was in a confrontation with [[Hulk Hogan]] before their [[WrestleMania X8]] rematch at [[No Way Out (2003)
column6: No Way Out]]. At No Way Out, The Rock defeated Hogan with the help of [[Vince McMahon
column7: Mr. McMahon]]. On the February 24 episode of ''Raw'', The Rock moved to the Raw brand and competed in a [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)
column8: 20-man Battle royal]] that would determine the number one contender for the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column9: World Heavyweight Championship]]. The Rock however, lost after he was eliminated by [[Booker T (wrestler)
column10: Booker T]]; after the match, The Rock criticized Austin for being chosen as the ''Superstar of the Decade'' by the WWE fans in January, beginning the feud between Rock and Austin.<ref name=\"RAWFeb242\">{{cite web
column14: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the March 3 episode of ''Raw'', Austin, who was on a long hiatus before returning at No Way Out,<ref name=\"NWO1\"/> made his WWE television return, as he cut a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Promo
column15: promo]] about the WWE fans, before he was interrupted by The Rock, who challenged him to a match at WrestleMania because The Rock was obsessed of not beating Austin at a WrestleMania event as by the time they fought at [[WrestleMania XV]] and [[WrestleMania X-Seven
column16: X-Seven]] during a four-year span. As soon as the challenge was made, Raw General Manager [[Eric Bischoff]] announced that the following week on ''Raw'', The Rock would face Booker T in a match, and if he won, he would have the choice to face either Austin or Triple H at WrestleMania.<ref name=\"RAWMar32\">{{cite web
column19: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the March 10 episode of ''Raw'', Rock, with Bischoff's approval, announced that he would pick his own opponent for later that night, which turned out to be [[Gregory Helms
column20: The Hurricane]], in hopes for The Rock to gain an easy victory. However, Austin made his way down the entrance ramp, which distracted The Rock and allowed The Hurricane to [[Pin (professional wrestling)#Roll-up
column21: roll up]] The Rock into a successful pinfall, which made the Austin-Rock match at WrestleMania official.<ref name=\"RAWMar102\">{{cite web
column25: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the March 24 episode of ''Raw'', Austin was banned from entering the arena. He managed to enter the arena and attack The Rock, however, before The Rock fled the ring.<ref name=\"RAWMar242\">{{cite web

column1: The secondary feud on the SmackDown! brand was between [[Hulk Hogan]] and [[Vince McMahon
column2: Mr. McMahon]]. One month prior at No Way Out, during a match between Hogan and The Rock, McMahon came down to the ring, only to distract Hogan, which allowed the referee, [[Sylvan Grenier]] to give The Rock a chair, which Rock used to hit Hogan and pin him for the win.<ref name=\"No Way Out - Main events\">{{cite web
column6: title=Co-Main Events: Triple H vs. Scott Steiner for the World Heavyweight Championship (RAW) and The Rock vs. Hulk Hogan (SmackDown)
column7: publisher=WWE}}</ref> After No Way Out, McMahon proclaimed that Hulkamania was dead and proclaiming a new 'mania; McMahonamania. On the March 6 episode of ''SmackDown!'', Hogan informed McMahon that Hulkamania was not dead and that McMahon had nothing to do with creating it. McMahon informed Hogan that he did not hate Hulkamaniacs or Hulkamania, but he hated Hogan. He then told Hogan that he hated him for leaving WWE (then known as the WWF) for [[Ted Turner]]'s [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) and for testifying against him in the [[Vince McMahon#Legal trial
column8: steroid trial]] in the 1990s. McMahon proceeded by challenging Hogan to a match at WrestleMania where if Hogan lost, he would have to retire from [[professional wrestling]]. Hogan accepted his challenge later that night.<ref name=\"SDMar61\"/> Two weeks later on the March 20 episode of ''SmackDown!'', McMahon and Hogan had a contract signing for their match at WrestleMania. As Hogan was preparing to sign the contract, McMahon attacked with a steel chair from behind. Shortly afterward, McMahon hit Hogan several times with the chair in the head, causing him to [[Blading (professional wrestling)
column9: bleed]]. McMahon then signed the contract and forced Hogan to sign with his blood.<ref name=\"SDMar201\"/>

column1: Another feud on the Raw brand was between [[Triple H]] and [[Booker T (wrestler)
column2: Booker T]], with the two feuding over the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column3: World Heavyweight Championship]]. Triple H won the title three months prior at [[Armageddon (2002)
column4: Armageddon]] by defeating then-champion [[Shawn Michaels]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Two out of three falls
column5: 3 Stages of Hell match]].<ref name=\"Armageddon - HHH vs HBK\">{{cite web
column8: title=Triple H defeated Shawn Michaels in a Three Stages of Hell Match to win the World Heavyweight Championship
column10: accessdate=2008-02-23}}</ref> Since that event, Triple H had wrestled [[Scott Steiner]] during the following two pay-per-view events for the World Heavyweight Championship. First was at the [[Royal Rumble (2003)
column11: Royal Rumble]], where Triple H got himself disqualified when he nailed Steiner with the [[sledgehammer]] but retained the title. Then at No Way Out, he defeated Steiner by [[Professional wrestling#Pinfall
column12: pinfall]] to retain the title. On the February 24 episode of ''Raw'', Booker T won a [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)
column13: 20-man battle royal]] by last eliminating The Rock to become the number one contender to the World Heavyweight Championship at WrestleMania.<ref name=\"RAWFeb242\"/> On the March 3 episode of ''Raw'', World Heavyweight Champion Triple H cut a controversial promo on Booker T. Triple H downplayed Booker T's WCW success, pointing out that the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship]] had been held by non-wrestlers like [[Vince Russo]] and actor [[David Arquette]] calling WCW and its title \"a joke\". He implied that Booker T, as a convicted criminal, would never win a world championship in WWE. In the WrestleMania XIX press conference [[Michael Cole (wrestling)
column14: Michael Cole]] questioned Triple H as to whether he had cut a racist promo, Triple H confirmed this was not the case and was indeed referring to Booker's criminal past.<ref>{{cite web
column17: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the March 10 episode of ''Raw'', Booker T got revenge by attacking Triple H in the bathroom, laying him out.<ref>{{cite web
column20: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the March 24 episode of ''Raw'', Booker T and [[Goldust]] defeated Triple H and [[Ric Flair]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Tag team match

column1: Another feud from the Raw brand was the squabble over the [[WWE Women's Championship (1956–2010)
column2: Women's Championship]]; the champion Victoria had captured the title from Trish Stratus at [[Survivor Series (2002)
column3: Survivor Series]]. Then at Armageddon, Victoria defeated Stratus and Jacqueline in a [[Professional wrestling#Triple Threat match
column4: triple threat match]] to retain the Women's Championship. Stratus and the returning Jazz had a match on ''Raw'' to determine who would challenge Victoria for the title at WrestleMania. During the match, Victoria entered the ring and hit both women with the title belt, earning a double disqualification. It was then announced that Victoria would defend the title against both Stratus and Jazz in a triple threat match at the event.

column1: A smaller feud, also from the Raw brand was between [[Chris Jericho]] and [[Shawn Michaels]]. After Shawn Michaels lost the World Heavyweight Championship to Triple H at Armageddon, he appeared in an in-ring segment with Chris Jericho, during which Jericho stated Michaels was washed up. After mocking Michaels and threatening to attack him, Jericho turned around into a [[superkick]]. When Michaels was a guest on Jericho's in-ring show ''The Highlight Reel'' the following month, Jericho claimed he had idolized Michaels from a young age and that he had been his inspiration to become a wrestler. At the Royal Rumble, Jericho eliminated Michaels from the Royal Rumble match. Michaels returned later in the match and attacked Jericho, helping to lead to his elimination. The two agreed to meet at WrestleMania XIX in a match.

column2: class=wikitable style=\"font-size:90%; margin: 0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; float: right; clear: right;\"

column3: Kane]] and [[Rob Van Dam]] faced [[Val Venis
column4: Chief Morley]] and [[Lance Storm]] (with [[The Dudley Boyz]], ([[Bubba Ray Dudley]] and [[D-Von Dudley]])) for the [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)
column5: World Tag Team Championship]] on ''[[WWE Heat
column6: Sunday Night Heat]]''. At the end, while the referee was distracted, the Dudleyz performed the [[Professional wrestling double-team maneuvers
column7: 3D (Dudley Death Drop)]] on Storm. After that, Bubba dropped an elbow on RVD, allowing Storm to [[pin (professional wrestling)
column8: pin]] RVD, thus Storm and Morley retained the titles.<ref name=\"WMFacts\" /><ref name=\"WMFacts2\">{{cite web

column4: An attendance record-setting 54,097 fans at Safeco Field for WrestleMania XIX]]

column2: Ashanti]] sang a rendition of \"[[America the Beautiful]]\".<ref name=\"Gerweck\">{{cite web

column1: In the first match that aired, [[Rey Mysterio]] faced [[Matt Hardy]] for the [[WWE Cruiserweight Championship (1991–2007)
column6: publisher=WWE}}</ref> The match began with back and forth action between the two, until Hardy performed a ''[[Cutter (professional wrestling)#Twist of Fate
column7: Twist of Fate]]'' for a near-fall.<ref name=\"Gerweck\"/> Mysterio retaliated by delivering a ''[[Professional wrestling attacks#Tiger feint kick
column8: 619]]'' on Hardy, but as Mysterio delivered a West Coast Pop, Hardy ducked into a [[Pin (professional wrestling)#Roll-up
column9: roll-up]] that saw Hardy use the ring ropes for leverage and successfully pinned Mysterio, thus Hardy retained the Cruiserweight Championship.<ref name=\"SLAM\">{{cite web

column1: In the next match, [[The Undertaker]] and [[Nathan Jones (wrestler)
column4: A-Train]] in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types
column5: tag team match]].<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/> It was then announced that The Undertaker would have to face both Show and Train in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match
column6: handicap match]].<ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> Both Show and Train had the advantage of The Undertaker at the start of the match; however, late into the match, Jones entered the match and attacked Show, allowing The Undertaker to deliver a ''[[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Tombstone piledriver
column7: Tombstone Piledriver]]'' on A-Train for a successful pinfall, thus The Undertaker won the match and remained undefeated at WrestleMania.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/>

column3: Jazz]] and [[Trish Stratus]] fought in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches
column4: triple threat match]] for the [[WWE Women's Championship (1956-2010)
column5: WWE Women's Championship]].<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> Throughout the match, Jazz and Victoria would double-team Stratus and [[Stevie Richards
column6: Steven Richards]], who was at ringside in Victoria's corner, would intervene in the match.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/> As Jazz was thrown over the top rope onto ringside, however, Richards came in the ring with a steel chair and tried to hit Stratus with it but missed and hit it off the ropes, allowing Stratus to perform the Stratus Faction on him. Victoria went for the ''[[Neckbreaker#Gory neckbreaker
column7: Widow's Peak]]'' on Stratus, who countered with a chick kick to Victoria to win the match and the women's title, tying [[The Fabulous Moolah]]'s record of four title reigns.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/>

column1: The next match was a triple threat [[WWE Raw Tag Team Championship
column2: WWE Tag Team Championship]] match between the team of [[Rhyno]] and [[Chris Benoit]], against the team of [[Los Guerreros#World Wrestling Entertainment
column4: Chavo]] and [[Eddie Guerrero]]), and the champions, [[The World's Greatest Tag Team
column5: Team Angle]] ([[Shelton Benjamin]] and [[Charlie Haas]]).<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/><ref name=\"SLAM\"/> Rhyno delivered a ''[[Professional wrestling attacks#Spear
column6: Gore]]'' on Chavo but Benjamin tagged himself into the match and pinned Chavo, to win the match and retain the Tag Team Championship.<ref name=\"Gerweck\"/>

column5: Chris Jericho and Shawn Michaels after their match]]

column1: In the fifth match, [[Chris Jericho]] faced [[Shawn Michaels]].<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> Jericho had the advantage over Michaels at the start of the match, as he early on applied the ''[[Boston crab
column2: Walls of Jericho]]'' onto Michaels.<ref name=\"Gerweck\"/> Later in the match, Jericho hit Michaels with a Sweet Chin Music for a near fall and Michaels attempted ''[[Superkick
column3: Sweet Chin Music]]'' on Jericho, who countered into the ''Walls of Jericho''. After Michaels escaped the hold, He hit Jericho with a Sweet Chin Music for a near fall. Later, Jericho attempted a [[suplex]] that Michaels countered into a roll-up that gave Michaels the successful pinfall victory. After the match, Jericho offered to shake Michaels's hand and they hugged before Jericho attacked Michaels with a low blow.<ref name=\"Gerweck\"/><ref name=\"SLAM\"/>

column1: Before the next match begun, a fatal four-way pillow fight (hosted by [[Jonathan Coachman]]) took place between [[Stacy Keibler]], [[Torrie Wilson]], Tanya Ballinger, and [[Kitana Baker]]. The match went to a no contest when all four women teamed up, pulling down Coachman's pants and pinning him.<ref name=\"Gerweck\"/>
The next match was a [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column2: World Heavyweight Championship]] match between [[Booker T (wrestler)
column3: Booker T]] and [[Triple H]].<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> The match began with Booker in control of the match over Triple H, however, [[Ric Flair]], who was at ringside in Triple H's corner, threw Booker's knee into the steel steps. The attack allowed Triple H to work over Booker's leg, as he applied various submission holds onto Booker's leg including the [[Professional wrestling holds#Indian deathlock
column4: Indian deathlock]]. Booker T retaliated and took control of the match; after he delivered a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Somersault leg drop
column5: Harlem Hangover leg drop]], Booker grasped his knee in pain, which allowed Triple H to recover and perform a ''[[Facebuster#Double underhook facebuster
column6: Pedigree]]'' for a pinfall, thus Triple H won the match and retained the World Heavyweight Championship.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/>

column1: The seventh match was a [[Hardcore wrestling
column2: Street fight]] between [[Hulk Hogan]] and the WWE Chairman, [[Vince McMahon
column3: Mr. McMahon]].<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> Both Hogan and McMahon tested each other's strength in the beginning of the match, until McMahon threw Hogan at ringside. Hogan then countered a [[folding chair#Professional wrestling
column4: chairshot]] by McMahon into several of his own, that caused McMahon to bleed from the head.<ref name=\"Gerweck\"/> Late into the match, [[Roddy Piper]] interfered in the match as he hit Hogan with a [[Pipe (material)
column5: pipe]]. Hogan however, later retaliated by delivering a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Big boot
column7: running leg drop]]s to McMahon and successfully pinned McMahon, thus Hogan won the match.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/>

column4: The Rock vs. Stone Cold Steve Austin]]

column1: The next and final match on the [[Card (sports)#Undercard
column2: undercard]], was the encounter of [[Dwayne Johnson
column3: The Rock]] and [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]].<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> The match began with Austin and The Rock brawling in the ring, which ended up at ringside. Throughout the match, The Rock worked over Austin's leg, which included applying a [[Sharpshooter (professional wrestling)
column4: Sharpshooter]] on Austin. The Rock then began to taunt Austin, as he put on his vest and imitated his taunts, which led both to use their finishers with unsuccessful pins. Austin performed the [[Stunner (professional wrestling)
column5: Stone Cold Stunner]] on The Rock for a near-fall, much to Austin's dismay. After he failed to win with the People's Elbow, The Rock then performed two Rock Bottoms on Austin for two near-falls. The Rock performed a third Rock Bottom on Austin, winning the match.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/>

column4: [[Brock Lesnar]] attempting a shooting star press on [[Kurt Angle]].]]

column2: main event]], [[Brock Lesnar]] faced [[Kurt Angle]] for the [[WWE Championship]], where if Kurt Angle was [[Professional wrestling#Disqualification
column4: counted out]], he would lose the title.<ref name=\"WMFacts\"/><ref name=\"WMWWE\"/> The match began with Lesnar and Angle wrestling back and forth, until Angle countered a shoulder block into a [[Suplex#German suplex
column5: German suplex]]. Lesnar would then attempt an ''[[Facebuster#Fireman's carry facebuster
column6: F-5]]'' on Angle but Angle countered it into an ''[[Professional wrestling holds#Ankle lock
column7: Ankle Lock]]'', that Lesnar was able to escape out of.<ref name=\"SLAM\"/> As Lesnar escaped, Angle would hit an Angle Slam for a near fall. He later attempted another ''[[Professional wrestling throws#Olympic slam
column8: Angle Slam]]'', however, Lesnar countered into an ''F-5'' for a near-fall. Lesnar performed another ''F-5,'' and instead of [[Pin (professional wrestling)#Cover
column9: covering]] Angle, Lesnar climbed to the top rope and botched a ''[[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Shooting star press
column10: Shooting Star Press]]'' on Angle, which Angle covered for by pinning Lesnar for a near-fall. After Lesnar kicked out, Angle picked up Lesnar only to be hit with a third  ''F-5'', Lesnar then successfully pinned Angle, winning the match and the WWE Title. After the match, Angle and Lesnar shook hands and embraced closing the show.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Brock Lesnar's first WWE Championship reign

column1: On the ''SmackDown!'' after WrestleMania, SmackDown General Manager [[Stephanie McMahon]] announced [[Kurt Angle]] suffered a pulled [[hamstring]] and a neck injury, while Lesnar suffered multiple [[concussion]]s. She later announced that a tournament would take place to determine the number one contender to Lesnar's WWE Championship.<ref name=\"SDApr3\">{{cite web
column5: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the April 17 episode of ''Smackdown!'', [[John Cena]] would become the number one contender after he defeated [[Chris Benoit]] in the tournament's final match.<ref name=\"SDApr17\">{{cite web
column10: Backlash]], Lesnar defeated Cena to retain the WWE Championship.<ref>{{cite web
column14: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> Lesnar would then feud with [[Big Show]], as he defeated him at [[Judgment Day (2003)
column15: Judgment Day]] to retain the WWE Championship in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Container-based variations
column16: stretcher match]]. Lesnar would however lose the WWE Championship to Angle at [[Vengeance (2003)
column17: Vengeance]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches
column18: triple threat match]] that also involved Big Show.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Kurt Angle's July WWE Championship reign
column26: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> Lesnar then regained the WWE Championship from Angle on the September 18 episode of ''SmackDown!'', in an [[Iron Man match]] winning 5-4.<ref>{{cite web
column33: title=Brock Lesnar's Third WWE Championship reign

column1: On the April 3 episode of ''SmackDown!'', [[Vince McMahon
column2: Mr. McMahon]] forced [[Hulk Hogan]] to leave WWE forever as a part of their storyline.<ref name=\"SDApr3\">{{cite web
column6: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the May 1 episode of ''SmackDown!'', \"Mr. America\" (who was in reality Hogan under a mask), made his debut on ''[[Piper's Pit]]'', where McMahon promised to prove America was in reality Hogan.<ref name=\"SDMay12\">{{cite web
column10: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> Also involved in the feud was [[Zach Gowen]], a one legged wrestler who was brought into the feud by Mr. America.<ref name=\"SDJune5\">{{cite web
column14: publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> After multiple failed attempts to prove Mr. America was Hogan, however, McMahon succeeded on the July 3 episode of ''SmackDown!'', after he aired footage of Mr. America unmasking and revealing himself to be Hogan. He then announced that Hogan was fired from WWE.<ref name=\"SDJul3\">{{cite web

column1: On the ''Raw'' episode after WrestleMania, [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]] was fired from the WWE in storyline by then-[[Professional wrestling authority figures#General Managers
column2: Raw General Manager]] [[Eric Bischoff]] due to medical reasons.<ref name=\"RAWWM\">{{cite web
column8: publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> Austin was then re-hired by WWE CEO, [[Linda McMahon]], however, as Co-Raw General Manager on April 28.<ref>{{cite web
column13: The Rock]] taunted Austin for his firing; which proceeded to Rock challenging another superstar in a match.<ref name=\"RAWWM\"/> [[Bill Goldberg
column14: Goldberg]] would answer the Rock's challenge by stating that \"you're [The Rock is] next\", which led to Goldberg [[Professional wrestling attacks#Spear
column15: spear]]ing The Rock.<ref name=\"RAWWM\"/> On the April 14 episode of ''Raw'', The Rock would accept a challenge made by Goldberg, which he rejected a week earlier, in which the two would wrestle each other at Backlash.<ref>{{cite web
column21: publisher=WrestleView}}</ref> At Backlash, Goldberg successfully pinned Rock.<ref>{{cite web
column25: publisher=World Wrestling Entertainment}}</ref> After the match, The Rock gave a farewell speech in which he stated that he was to take a sabbatical from professional wrestling.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The event received highly positive reviews from various websites and wrestling publications. Most of the critics rated Jericho vs Michaels match as the match of the night. John Powell of [[Canadian Online Explorer]]'s professional wrestling section rated the event a perfect score of 10 out of 10 stars, which was a higher rating than the [[WrestleMania X8
column2: previous year's event]]. The main event between Brock Lesnar and Kurt Angle for the WWE Championship was rated the highest with a score of 9 out of 10 stars, the match between The Rock and Stone Cold Steve Austin was rated 8 out of 10 stars, the match between Booker T and Triple H for the World Heavyweight Championship was rated 7.5 out of 10 stars, the match between Shawn Michaels and Chris Jericho was also  rated 7.5 out of 10 stars and the Street Fight between Vince McMahon and Hulk Hogan receiving the lowest rating of 4 out of 10 stars. He also noted that \"it was the WWE slugging homeruns last night at WrestleMania XIX. Criticized for not making the most of the talent it has, the WWE had all the bases covered and proved that if the entire organization puts forth the effort, they can deliver a superior sports entertainment product\" and further claimed that \"WrestleMania XIX was not only a outstanding show but it will surely go down as one of the best WrestleManias ever\".<ref>{{cite web

column1: '''Luke Zachrich''' (born October 1, 1981) is a retired [[American people
column4: professional boxer]] who formerly competed in the [[Middleweight (MMA)
column5: Middleweight]] division of the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]]<ref>{{cite web
column9: date=November 10, 2014}}</ref> A professional mixed martial arts competitor since 2006 until his release from the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship
column10: UFC]] in 2014, Zachrich was a member of [[Forrest Griffin
column11: Team Forrest]] on the seventh season of [[The Ultimate Fighter: Team Rampage vs. Team Forrest
column12: The Ultimate Fighter]], and has also fought for [[King of the Cage]], [[Bellator Fighting Championship
column13: Bellator]], Xtreme Fighting Organization, and Ultimate Victory Challenge, the latter of which he was the inaugural Middleweight Champion.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=UVC 20 results: Luke Zachrich and Lance Palmer take home first UVC pro titles

column1: In the first few years of his career, he trained with [[professional wrestling]] and [[mixed martial arts]] legend [[Dan Severn]] at The Beast Academy in [[Coldwater, Michigan]], before relocating to [[Jorge Gurgel
column2: Team Jorge Gurgel]] in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]. He now fights out his own training facility, the Ronin Training Center, where he is also one of the head instructors.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=TUF 7 and Bellator Veteran Luke Zachrich Approaches True MMA Contendership
column6: date=March 28, 2014}}</ref> During his professional career, he held a martial arts record of 14–4, with seven of his fourteen wins coming by way of [[Submission (combat sports)
column11: title=Luke Zachrich Get’s [sic] A Decision Victory At UFC 175
column14: access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> Zachrich is currently ineligible for the Tapology.com [[Middleweight (MMA)
column15: Middleweight]] rankings due to his retirement from [[Mixed martial arts

column1: Zachrich was born on October 1, 1981, in [[Defiance, Ohio]]. During his [[freshman]] year, Zachrich was a varsity football player at [[Bowling Green University]] in [[Bowling Green, Ohio]]. After sustaining an injury in one of the last scheduled games of the season, he chose to discontinue his upstart career in football and find a different profession.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Site News: \"TUF\" cast member Luke Zachrich joins MMAjunkie.com

column1: In the last couple of years in college, Zachrich was a part-time [[lacrosse]] player and then graduated with [[bachelor's degree]] in 2005. Around the same time, he stumbled upon mixed martial arts and began training with UFC legend and [[UFC Hall of Fame
column2: Hall of Famer]] [[Dan Severn]] at his gym, The Beast Academy, in [[Coldwater, Michigan]] and also trained with renowned Jujitsu practitioner Dave Morris.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Luke Zachrich > MMA > Brazilian Jujitsu > sports training
column6: accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> An upstart, Zachrich trained for two years under the tutelage of Severn and [[Jorge Gurgel]]'s team, before accepting a last-minute offer to compete in an amateur bout in early 2006.

column1: During an interview with MMA.TV, he was asked about how he made the transition to mixed martial arts.

column2: Honestly, it was by chance. I had a short stint in college football and when that was over I really felt something missing in my life. Being a competitor was all I had ever known. So I started driving from Bowling Green to Toledo and started boxing. I continued that through the last couple years of college. Then, it just seemed like I kept meeting people and training with them that were involved in different aspects of MMA. Even though I had no intentions or aspirations of ever fighting.

column1: Then one day, I met an MMA guy when I moved back to Defiance, Ohio, [and] started training with him for fun and after a few months, someone needed a last minute fill in and I said yes. I won that fight pretty easily but I still didn't really see myself as a fighter. After that first fight, I just kept getting more offers and kept winning.<ref name=\"MMATVInterview\" />}}

In the first combat bout of his career, Zachrich faced off against fellow fighting newcomer Ben Kelley at Mega Fighting Championship's premiere event on January 14, 2006. It was a showcase of heavy stand-up striking for a majority of the bout, with Zachrich coming out on top with a first round [[Knockout
column2: technical knockout]] victory. Following more training, Zachrich would receive the opportunity to turn pro three months later.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Amateur MMA: MFC 1 - Mega Fighting Championship Results
column10: date=January 14, 2006}}</ref> On April 15, 2006, he made a successful transition to professional mixed martial arts, as he submitted Cliff Perillo with strikes at the Ultimate Fight Series.<ref>{{cite web

column1: At 1–0, Zachrich continued his slow-and-steady climb up the divisional rankings, and would collect another victory on May 6, 2006, in the form of a thirty-one second TKO of Micah Bender in the preliminary portion of FightFest 3.<ref>{{cite web
On September 29, 2006, Zachrich fought Jason Zazelenchuk at [[List of KOTC events
column2: King of the Cage: Detonator]], winning the fight by a quick [[rear-naked choke]] in the first round.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=King of the Cage: Detonator Official Results
column6: date=September 29, 2006}}</ref> After compiling a 1–1 record in regional promotions, getting the first loss of his career against Danny Ruiz by [[armbar]], and rebounding by submitting Shane Krutchten with an armbar, he returned to the promotion and submitted Brad Burrick, also by an armbar, at [[List of KOTC events
column7: King of the Cage: Explosion]] on June 15, 2007.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=KOTC: Explosion Official Results and Stats

column1: After capturing Xtreme Fighting Organization's middleweight championship with a vicious first round knockout of mixed martial arts journeyman William 'Bill' Hill, the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship
column2: UFC]] announced that Zachrich would be one of the sixteen [[Middleweight (MMA)
column3: Middleweight]] competitors set to take part in the seventh season of their hit reality show, [[The Ultimate Fighter]], hosted by coaches [[Quinton Jackson]] and [[Forrest Griffin]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Luke Zachrich Tapped for \"The Ultimate Fighter 7?

column1: Zachrich took on Patrick Schultz in the preliminary round, taking Schultz out with a quick first round rear-naked choke. Impressing the two coaches, he was the final pick by [[Forrest Griffin]] of [[Forrest Griffin
In the quarter-finals, Zachrich faced off against [[Rampage Jackson
column3: Dan \"Cosmo\" Cramer]]. Despite having the considerable edge in overall experience, he was defeated with a second round TKO and was eliminated from the show.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Zachrich returned to the regional circuit soon after his Ultimate Fighter elimination, and his next fight was quickly put in place for the Full Contact Fight Series 28 event on September 6, 2008, where he took on regional journeyman Michael Musslewhite. In this contest, he continued to showcase his ever-improving boxing skills, taking Musslewhite out with a first-round knockout and moving himself to 8–1 in his growing career.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=HDNet Fights Video Vault: Luke Zachrich vs. Mike Musselwhite at FCFS

column1: For his tenth career fight, he took on Robert Thompson at ICF: Breakout on April 11, 2009. Thompson, who came into the fight with a three-fight losing streak hanging over his head, would not fare well against Zachrich, and would be submitted with a keylock in the third round.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=UFC vets Carter, Christison, Cruz and Zachrich set for Cincinnati ICF show
column7: title=ICF Breakout: Robert Thompson vs. Luke Zachrich

column1: He faced J.R. Hines at ICF: Sacrifice on May 16, 2009.<ref>{{cite web
column5: date=May 11, 2009}}</ref> Zachrich took the fight to the ground early on and submitted Hines with a keylock in the first round, and with the victory, garnered the attention of [[Indiana (state)
column6: Indiana]] based organization, MMA Big Show, who announced that they had signed him to a multi-fight deal on October 21, 2009.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=ICF: Sacrifice Post-Event Interview with Luke Zachrich (May 28, 2009)
column14: accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref> He was given Byron Sutton as his first opponent, and the two were expected to compete at the promotion's New Dawn event on January 9, 2010, however, the fight would be taken off the card by the promoter shortly after it was announced for undisclosed reasons.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Junie Browning returns for 'Onslaught' at MMA Big Show on Nov. 28
column20: title= MMA Big Show returns Jan. 9th-Gary Goodridge vs. Ron Sparks & 4 star prospect Luke Zachrich on card
column22: accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> It wasn't until March 24, 2010, that it was announced that Zachrich had been signed by [[Bjorn Rebney]]'s upstart mixed martial arts company, [[Bellator MMA]].<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=Bellator Fighting Championships signs Luke Zachrich

column1: Zachrich made his first and only appearance for the promotion at [[Bellator 16]], and was matched-up against [[World Extreme Cagefighting]] veteran [[Eric Schambari]] in the middleweight tournament quarter-finals on April 29, 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Bellator adds \"TUF 7\" alum Luke Zachrich for season-two middleweight tourney
column7: title=Bellator Signs TUF 7’s Luke Zachrich for Season Two Middleweight Tournament
column11: title=Eric Schambari Vs. Luke Zachrich Set For Bellator 16
column13: date=April 26, 2010}}</ref> He accepted the opportunity to fight Schambari having been battling nagging back injuries in the months heading into the fight, and after a back-and-forth first couple of minutes, with Zachrich nearly catching his opponent in a [[guillotine choke]], he lost the fight by an [[arm-triangle choke]] in the first round.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Bellator 16 Recap: Middleweights Bring It, Ask Where They Can Find Some Decent Barbeque
column17: date=April 29, 2010}}</ref> He was subsequently released from the promotion shortly after the bout.

column1: Zachrich faced Nick Kraus for the inaugural Ultimate Victory Challenge middleweight title at UVC 20: Clash at the Coliseum on August 4, 2012,<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Luke Zachrich, Lance Palmer top UVC 20 card
column5: date=July 30, 2012}}</ref> winning the bout by unanimous decision.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=UVC 20 results: Luke Zachrich and Lance Palmer take home first UVC pro titles
column11: title=UVC 20 Results: Luke Zachrich and Lance Palmer Get Wins at Home
column13: date=August 5, 2012}}</ref> He made his next appearance for UVC against Marcus Finch at UVC 23 on May 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Fight Preview: Luke Zachrich faces Marcus Finch in the main event at UVC 23: Invasion
column19: title=Luke Zachrich vs. Marcus Finch: A year in the making
column21: date=April 23, 2013}}</ref> Zachrich won the fight via unanimous decision.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=UVC 23: Luke Zachrich vs. Marcus Finch

column1: He faced off against Justin Gamble at AAMMA 34: Proving Ground 2 on August 10, 2013, winning the fight by a [[armbar
column2: straight armbar]] forty-five seconds into the first round.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=AAMMA: Justin Gamble vs. Luke Zachrich
column8: title=AMMA 34 \"Proving Grounds\" II: Looked almost like a Kentucky vs Ohio MMA Championship Event
column10: date=August 19, 2013}}</ref> The quick and impressive finish would also earn Zachrich ''Submission of the Year'' honors from Bluegrass MMA, and at the end of the 2013, was the close runner-up in the 2013 Pro Male Breakout Fighter awards by BlueGrass MMA, with future UFC bantamweight [[Cody Garbrandt]] narrowly snagging the lead slot in that category.<ref name=\"BlueGrassZachrich\">{{cite web
column14: date=January 13, 2014}}</ref> Zachrich was tabbed to face UFC veteran [[Luigi Fioravanti]] at UVC 27 on February 8, 2014,<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=UFC vet Luigi Fioravanti set to face Luke Zachrich at UVC 27
column22: date=December 16, 2013}}</ref> but the fight would be postponed a month to March 15, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=UVC 27 Moved to March 15; Zachrich-Fioravanti Headlines
column26: date=January 29, 2014}}</ref> However, a couple of weeks after the fight was rescheduled, the entire event would be canceled by the promoter for undisclosed reasons.<ref>{{cite web

column1: When [[Josh Samman]] had to pull out of his scheduled bout against [[Caio Magalhães]] due to an injury, Zachrich was signed to a multi-fight contract and stepped up as a short-notice replacement for Samman at [[UFC on Fox 11]] on April 19, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Caio Magalhaes vs. Luke Zachrich booked for UFC on FOX 11 with Josh Samman hurt
column7: title=Luke Zachrich confident ahead of debut at UFC on FOX 11
column9: date=April 18, 2014}}</ref> He lost the bout by TKO in just forty-four seconds, after being dropped by heavy body shots from Magalhães.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=UFC on FOX 11 results, photos: Body shot leads Caio Magalhaes past Luke Zachrich

column1: In his second fight with the promotion, Zachrich faced promotional newcomer Guilherme Vasconcelos at [[UFC 175]] on July 5, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Guilherme Vasconcelos vs. Luke Zachrich joins UFC 175 lineup
column5: date=May 8, 2014}}</ref> Zachrich would earn his first UFC victory with a dominant unanimous decision verdict over Vasconcelos, effectively outworking his [[Brazilian people
column6: Brazilian]] counterpart on the feet and showing improved takedown defense.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=UFC 175 results, photos: Luke Zachrich outworks Guilherme Vasconcelos
column14: date=July 5, 2014}}</ref> He then faced touted promotional newcomer and expert [[Judoka]] practitioner [[Dan Kelly (judoka)
column15: Dan Kelly]] at [[UFC Fight Night: Rockhold vs. Bisping]] on November 7, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Daniel Kelly makes UFC debut vs. Luke Zachrich at UFC Fight Night 55
column19: accessdate=November 25, 2014}}</ref> Zachrich would be a significant betting favorite coming into the bout, however, he was outboxed on the feet and towards the end of the first round, was taken down by Kelly and subsequently submitted with a [[kimura lock
column22: title=UFC Fight Night 55 results: Daniel Kelly beats up, then taps Luke Zachrich
column26: title=Daniel Kelly submits Luke Zachrich in first round at UFC Fight Night 55

column1: Zachrich announced on Twitter on August 1, 2015, that he had successfully recovered from a lingering back injury and was in the process of returning to active MMA competition.<ref>{{cite web
column5: date=August 1, 2015}}</ref> However, on October 19, 2015, it was confirmed that Zachrich was released from the promotion and has since retired from [[Mixed martial arts
column8: title=UFC Releases Over A Dozen More Fighters, More Coming?

column2: quote = Boxing is something that I always wanted to do. It is getting harder and harder for me to get MMA fights to stick. So this is a way for me to stay active.  I had a lot of fun out there tonight.  I am in no way done with MMA, but boxing is definitely something I look forward to doing again.
column5: source=-Zachrich, in his interview with Robert \"Turtle\" Whitson of Cage Passion Media.}}

column1: A few weeks before making his debut with the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]], Zachrich competed in a cruiserweight boxing bout against [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)
column2: Strikeforce]] veteran and combat journeyman John \"J.P.\" Felty at TBC: Championship Boxing, getting a technical knockout victory over Felty in the second round with two seconds left.<ref name=\"ZachrichBoxing\">{{cite web
column4: title=Zachrich Makes Successful Pro Boxing Debut

column1: In a post-fight interview with Cage Passion Media, Zachrich said that he simply took the fight to keep himself busy and was already planning on returning to mixed martial arts, but didn't rule out the possibility of taking another boxing bout in the future.<ref name=\"ZachrichBoxing\" />
Following his release from the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship
column2: UFC]] in 2015, Zachrich made his return to boxing on January 15, 2016, scoring a TKO over the debuting Gary Vandyne at the [[Hollywood Casino Columbus
column8: accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref> Less than two months later, Zachrich booked another boxing match and won a unanimous decision against Bill Yates on March 4, 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column18: accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref> Zachrich has not competed in any amateur or professional boxing bouts since his decision victory over Yates.

column1: Zachrich holds an undergraduate degree in [[Bachelor of Applied Science
column2: applied sciences]] from [[Bowling Green State University]].<ref name=\"LukeZachrichProfile\" /> He is currently married and has children.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Video: 'TUF' vet, newlywed, pizza peddler Luke Zachrich returns from two-year layoff
column6: date=August 4, 2012}}</ref> On top of competing in mixed martial arts, Zachrich revealed in an interview with [[MMAJunkie]] that he also remotely manages three [[Mellow Mushroom]] restaurants, and plans on opening and managing more in the future.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=UFC's Luke Zachrich puts Mellow Mushroom on back burner for renewed MMA career
column12: title=Luke Zachrich interview with Cageside Cain
column14: accessdate=September 14, 2015}}</ref> In 2017, Zachrich started a new position as a [[sales representative]] for the [[Columbus, Ohio]] branch of [[Stryker Corporation]], a [[Fortune 500]] [[medical technologies]] firm originally based in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]].<ref name=\"LukeZachrichProfile\" />

column14: title=UVC 20 results: Luke Zachrich and Lance Palmer take home first UVC pro titles

column1: In the first few years of his career, he trained with [[professional wrestling]] and [[mixed martial arts]] legend [[Dan Severn]] at The Beast Academy in [[Coldwater, Michigan]], before relocating to [[Jorge Gurgel
column2: Team Jorge Gurgel]] in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]. He now fights out his own training facility, the Ronin Training Center, where he is also one of the head instructors.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=TUF 7 and Bellator Veteran Luke Zachrich Approaches True MMA Contendership
column6: date=March 28, 2014}}</ref> During his professional career, he held a martial arts record of 14–4, with seven of his fourteen wins coming by way of [[Submission (combat sports)
column11: title=Luke Zachrich Get’s [sic] A Decision Victory At UFC 175
column14: access-date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> Zachrich is currently ineligible for the Tapology.com [[Middleweight (MMA)
column15: Middleweight]] rankings due to his retirement from [[Mixed martial arts

column1: Zachrich was born on October 1, 1981, in [[Defiance, Ohio]]. During his [[freshman]] year, Zachrich was a varsity football player at [[Bowling Green University]] in [[Bowling Green, Ohio]]. After sustaining an injury in one of the last scheduled games of the season, he chose to discontinue his upstart career in football and find a different profession.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Site News: \"TUF\" cast member Luke Zachrich joins MMAjunkie.com

column1: In the last couple of years in college, Zachrich was a part-time [[lacrosse]] player and then graduated with [[bachelor's degree]] in 2005. Around the same time, he stumbled upon mixed martial arts and began training with UFC legend and [[UFC Hall of Fame
column2: Hall of Famer]] [[Dan Severn]] at his gym, The Beast Academy, in [[Coldwater, Michigan]] and also trained with renowned Jujitsu practitioner Dave Morris.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Luke Zachrich > MMA > Brazilian Jujitsu > sports training
column6: accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> An upstart, Zachrich trained for two years under the tutelage of Severn and [[Jorge Gurgel]]'s team, before accepting a last-minute offer to compete in an amateur bout in early 2006.

column1: During an interview with MMA.TV, he was asked about how he made the transition to mixed martial arts.

column2: Honestly, it was by chance. I had a short stint in college football and when that was over I really felt something missing in my life. Being a competitor was all I had ever known. So I started driving from Bowling Green to Toledo and started boxing. I continued that through the last couple years of college. Then, it just seemed like I kept meeting people and training with them that were involved in different aspects of MMA. Even though I had no intentions or aspirations of ever fighting.

column1: Then one day, I met an MMA guy when I moved back to Defiance, Ohio, [and] started training with him for fun and after a few months, someone needed a last minute fill in and I said yes. I won that fight pretty easily but I still didn't really see myself as a fighter. After that first fight, I just kept getting more offers and kept winning.<ref name=\"MMATVInterview\" />}}

In the first combat bout of his career, Zachrich faced off against fellow fighting newcomer Ben Kelley at Mega Fighting Championship's premiere event on January 14, 2006. It was a showcase of heavy stand-up striking for a majority of the bout, with Zachrich coming out on top with a first round [[Knockout
column2: technical knockout]] victory. Following more training, Zachrich would receive the opportunity to turn pro three months later.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Amateur MMA: MFC 1 - Mega Fighting Championship Results
column10: date=January 14, 2006}}</ref> On April 15, 2006, he made a successful transition to professional mixed martial arts, as he submitted Cliff Perillo with strikes at the Ultimate Fight Series.<ref>{{cite web

column1: At 1–0, Zachrich continued his slow-and-steady climb up the divisional rankings, and would collect another victory on May 6, 2006, in the form of a thirty-one second TKO of Micah Bender in the preliminary portion of FightFest 3.<ref>{{cite web
On September 29, 2006, Zachrich fought Jason Zazelenchuk at [[List of KOTC events
column2: King of the Cage: Detonator]], winning the fight by a quick [[rear-naked choke]] in the first round.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=King of the Cage: Detonator Official Results
column6: date=September 29, 2006}}</ref> After compiling a 1–1 record in regional promotions, getting the first loss of his career against Danny Ruiz by [[armbar]], and rebounding by submitting Shane Krutchten with an armbar, he returned to the promotion and submitted Brad Burrick, also by an armbar, at [[List of KOTC events
column7: King of the Cage: Explosion]] on June 15, 2007.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=KOTC: Explosion Official Results and Stats

column1: After capturing Xtreme Fighting Organization's middleweight championship with a vicious first round knockout of mixed martial arts journeyman William 'Bill' Hill, the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship
column2: UFC]] announced that Zachrich would be one of the sixteen [[Middleweight (MMA)
column3: Middleweight]] competitors set to take part in the seventh season of their hit reality show, [[The Ultimate Fighter]], hosted by coaches [[Quinton Jackson]] and [[Forrest Griffin]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Luke Zachrich Tapped for \"The Ultimate Fighter 7?

column1: Zachrich took on Patrick Schultz in the preliminary round, taking Schultz out with a quick first round rear-naked choke. Impressing the two coaches, he was the final pick by [[Forrest Griffin]] of [[Forrest Griffin
In the quarter-finals, Zachrich faced off against [[Rampage Jackson
column3: Dan \"Cosmo\" Cramer]]. Despite having the considerable edge in overall experience, he was defeated with a second round TKO and was eliminated from the show.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Zachrich returned to the regional circuit soon after his Ultimate Fighter elimination, and his next fight was quickly put in place for the Full Contact Fight Series 28 event on September 6, 2008, where he took on regional journeyman Michael Musslewhite. In this contest, he continued to showcase his ever-improving boxing skills, taking Musslewhite out with a first-round knockout and moving himself to 8–1 in his growing career.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=HDNet Fights Video Vault: Luke Zachrich vs. Mike Musselwhite at FCFS

column1: For his tenth career fight, he took on Robert Thompson at ICF: Breakout on April 11, 2009. Thompson, who came into the fight with a three-fight losing streak hanging over his head, would not fare well against Zachrich, and would be submitted with a keylock in the third round.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=UFC vets Carter, Christison, Cruz and Zachrich set for Cincinnati ICF show
column7: title=ICF Breakout: Robert Thompson vs. Luke Zachrich

column1: He faced J.R. Hines at ICF: Sacrifice on May 16, 2009.<ref>{{cite web
column5: date=May 11, 2009}}</ref> Zachrich took the fight to the ground early on and submitted Hines with a keylock in the first round, and with the victory, garnered the attention of [[Indiana (state)
column6: Indiana]] based organization, MMA Big Show, who announced that they had signed him to a multi-fight deal on October 21, 2009.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=ICF: Sacrifice Post-Event Interview with Luke Zachrich (May 28, 2009)
column14: accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref> He was given Byron Sutton as his first opponent, and the two were expected to compete at the promotion's New Dawn event on January 9, 2010, however, the fight would be taken off the card by the promoter shortly after it was announced for undisclosed reasons.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Junie Browning returns for 'Onslaught' at MMA Big Show on Nov. 28
column20: title= MMA Big Show returns Jan. 9th-Gary Goodridge vs. Ron Sparks & 4 star prospect Luke Zachrich on card
column22: accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> It wasn't until March 24, 2010, that it was announced that Zachrich had been signed by [[Bjorn Rebney]]'s upstart mixed martial arts company, [[Bellator MMA]].<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=Bellator Fighting Championships signs Luke Zachrich

column1: Zachrich made his first and only appearance for the promotion at [[Bellator 16]], and was matched-up against [[World Extreme Cagefighting]] veteran [[Eric Schambari]] in the middleweight tournament quarter-finals on April 29, 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Bellator adds \"TUF 7\" alum Luke Zachrich for season-two middleweight tourney
column7: title=Bellator Signs TUF 7’s Luke Zachrich for Season Two Middleweight Tournament
column11: title=Eric Schambari Vs. Luke Zachrich Set For Bellator 16
column13: date=April 26, 2010}}</ref> He accepted the opportunity to fight Schambari having been battling nagging back injuries in the months heading into the fight, and after a back-and-forth first couple of minutes, with Zachrich nearly catching his opponent in a [[guillotine choke]], he lost the fight by an [[arm-triangle choke]] in the first round.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Bellator 16 Recap: Middleweights Bring It, Ask Where They Can Find Some Decent Barbeque
column17: date=April 29, 2010}}</ref> He was subsequently released from the promotion shortly after the bout.

column1: Zachrich faced Nick Kraus for the inaugural Ultimate Victory Challenge middleweight title at UVC 20: Clash at the Coliseum on August 4, 2012,<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Luke Zachrich, Lance Palmer top UVC 20 card
column5: date=July 30, 2012}}</ref> winning the bout by unanimous decision.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=UVC 20 results: Luke Zachrich and Lance Palmer take home first UVC pro titles
column11: title=UVC 20 Results: Luke Zachrich and Lance Palmer Get Wins at Home
column13: date=August 5, 2012}}</ref> He made his next appearance for UVC against Marcus Finch at UVC 23 on May 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Fight Preview: Luke Zachrich faces Marcus Finch in the main event at UVC 23: Invasion
column19: title=Luke Zachrich vs. Marcus Finch: A year in the making
column21: date=April 23, 2013}}</ref> Zachrich won the fight via unanimous decision.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=UVC 23: Luke Zachrich vs. Marcus Finch

column1: He faced off against Justin Gamble at AAMMA 34: Proving Ground 2 on August 10, 2013, winning the fight by a [[armbar
column2: straight armbar]] forty-five seconds into the first round.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=AAMMA: Justin Gamble vs. Luke Zachrich
column8: title=AMMA 34 \"Proving Grounds\" II: Looked almost like a Kentucky vs Ohio MMA Championship Event
column10: date=August 19, 2013}}</ref> The quick and impressive finish would also earn Zachrich ''Submission of the Year'' honors from Bluegrass MMA, and at the end of the 2013, was the close runner-up in the 2013 Pro Male Breakout Fighter awards by BlueGrass MMA, with future UFC bantamweight [[Cody Garbrandt]] narrowly snagging the lead slot in that category.<ref name=\"BlueGrassZachrich\">{{cite web
column14: date=January 13, 2014}}</ref> Zachrich was tabbed to face UFC veteran [[Luigi Fioravanti]] at UVC 27 on February 8, 2014,<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=UFC vet Luigi Fioravanti set to face Luke Zachrich at UVC 27
column22: date=December 16, 2013}}</ref> but the fight would be postponed a month to March 15, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=UVC 27 Moved to March 15; Zachrich-Fioravanti Headlines
column26: date=January 29, 2014}}</ref> However, a couple of weeks after the fight was rescheduled, the entire event would be canceled by the promoter for undisclosed reasons.<ref>{{cite web

column1: When [[Josh Samman]] had to pull out of his scheduled bout against [[Caio Magalhães]] due to an injury, Zachrich was signed to a multi-fight contract and stepped up as a short-notice replacement for Samman at [[UFC on Fox 11]] on April 19, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Caio Magalhaes vs. Luke Zachrich booked for UFC on FOX 11 with Josh Samman hurt
column7: title=Luke Zachrich confident ahead of debut at UFC on FOX 11
column9: date=April 18, 2014}}</ref> He lost the bout by TKO in just forty-four seconds, after being dropped by heavy body shots from Magalhães.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=UFC on FOX 11 results, photos: Body shot leads Caio Magalhaes past Luke Zachrich

column1: In his second fight with the promotion, Zachrich faced promotional newcomer Guilherme Vasconcelos at [[UFC 175]] on July 5, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Guilherme Vasconcelos vs. Luke Zachrich joins UFC 175 lineup
column5: date=May 8, 2014}}</ref> Zachrich would earn his first UFC victory with a dominant unanimous decision verdict over Vasconcelos, effectively outworking his [[Brazilian people
column6: Brazilian]] counterpart on the feet and showing improved takedown defense.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=UFC 175 results, photos: Luke Zachrich outworks Guilherme Vasconcelos
column14: date=July 5, 2014}}</ref> He then faced touted promotional newcomer and expert [[Judoka]] practitioner [[Dan Kelly (judoka)
column15: Dan Kelly]] at [[UFC Fight Night: Rockhold vs. Bisping]] on November 7, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Daniel Kelly makes UFC debut vs. Luke Zachrich at UFC Fight Night 55
column19: accessdate=November 25, 2014}}</ref> Zachrich would be a significant betting favorite coming into the bout, however, he was outboxed on the feet and towards the end of the first round, was taken down by Kelly and subsequently submitted with a [[kimura lock
column22: title=UFC Fight Night 55 results: Daniel Kelly beats up, then taps Luke Zachrich
column26: title=Daniel Kelly submits Luke Zachrich in first round at UFC Fight Night 55

column1: Zachrich announced on Twitter on August 1, 2015, that he had successfully recovered from a lingering back injury and was in the process of returning to active MMA competition.<ref>{{cite web
column5: date=August 1, 2015}}</ref> However, on October 19, 2015, it was confirmed that Zachrich was released from the promotion and has since retired from [[Mixed martial arts
column8: title=UFC Releases Over A Dozen More Fighters, More Coming?

column2: quote = Boxing is something that I always wanted to do. It is getting harder and harder for me to get MMA fights to stick. So this is a way for me to stay active.  I had a lot of fun out there tonight.  I am in no way done with MMA, but boxing is definitely something I look forward to doing again.
column5: source=-Zachrich, in his interview with Robert \"Turtle\" Whitson of Cage Passion Media.}}

column1: A few weeks before making his debut with the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]], Zachrich competed in a cruiserweight boxing bout against [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)
column2: Strikeforce]] veteran and combat journeyman John \"J.P.\" Felty at TBC: Championship Boxing, getting a technical knockout victory over Felty in the second round with two seconds left.<ref name=\"ZachrichBoxing\">{{cite web
column4: title=Zachrich Makes Successful Pro Boxing Debut

column1: In a post-fight interview with Cage Passion Media, Zachrich said that he simply took the fight to keep himself busy and was already planning on returning to mixed martial arts, but didn't rule out the possibility of taking another boxing bout in the future.<ref name=\"ZachrichBoxing\" />
Following his release from the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship
column2: UFC]] in 2015, Zachrich made his return to boxing on January 15, 2016, scoring a TKO over the debuting Gary Vandyne at the [[Hollywood Casino Columbus
column8: accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref> Less than two months later, Zachrich booked another boxing match and won a unanimous decision against Bill Yates on March 4, 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column18: accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref> Zachrich has not competed in any amateur or professional boxing bouts since his decision victory over Yates.

column1: Zachrich holds an undergraduate degree in [[Bachelor of Applied Science
column2: applied sciences]] from [[Bowling Green State University]].<ref name=\"LukeZachrichProfile\" /> He is currently married and has children.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Video: 'TUF' vet, newlywed, pizza peddler Luke Zachrich returns from two-year layoff
column6: date=August 4, 2012}}</ref> On top of competing in mixed martial arts, Zachrich revealed in an interview with [[MMAJunkie]] that he also remotely manages three [[Mellow Mushroom]] restaurants, and plans on opening and managing more in the future.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=UFC's Luke Zachrich puts Mellow Mushroom on back burner for renewed MMA career
column12: title=Luke Zachrich interview with Cageside Cain
column14: accessdate=September 14, 2015}}</ref> In 2017, Zachrich started a new position as a [[sales representative]] for the [[Columbus, Ohio]] branch of [[Stryker Corporation]], a [[Fortune 500]] [[medical technologies]] firm originally based in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]].<ref name=\"LukeZachrichProfile\" />

column8: access-date=2017-01-27}}</ref> Following a several month-long transitional period, it commences operations the following year.

column1: ** The [[Euro]] is officially introduced in the [[Eurozone]] countries.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: * [[January 17]] – [[Mount Nyiragongo]] erupts in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], displacing an estimated 400,000 people.
* [[January 18]] – The [[Sierra Leone Civil War]] comes to a conclusion with the defeat of the [[Revolutionary United Front]] by government forces.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Sierra Leone Civil War (1991–2002) {{!}} The Black Past: Remembered and Reclaimed

column2: Queen Elizabeth II]] of the [[Commonwealth Realms]] celebrates her [[Golden Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II
column3: Golden Jubilee]], marking 50 years since her accession to the thrones of the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Queen helps CBC TV mark 50th anniversary

column2: 24]] – The [[2002 Winter Olympics]] are held in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Salt Lake City 2002 Winter Olympics - results & video highlights

column1: * [[February 12]] – The [[trial of Slobodan Milošević]], the former president of [[Serbia and Montenegro
column2: Yugoslavia]], begins at the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] in [[The Hague]].<ref>{{Cite news

column1: * [[February 19]] – [[NASA]]'s ''[[2001 Mars Odyssey]]'' [[space probe]] begins to map the surface of [[Mars]] using its thermal emission imaging system.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Odyssey Turns Its Cameras on Mars

column1: * [[February 22]] – [[UNITA]] guerilla leader [[Jonas Savimbi]] is killed in clashes against government troops led by [[President of Angola
column2: Angolan President]] [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] in [[Moxico Province]], [[Angola]].<ref>{{Cite news
column11: via=}}</ref> His death leads to the end of the [[Angolan Civil War]] on April 4.<ref>{{Cite news
column13: title=Unita signs peace treaty with Angolan army to end 27-year civil war

column1: * [[March 1]] – The [[Envisat]] [[environmental satellite]] is launched, with its purpose being the recording of information on environmental change.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=New satellite will monitor global warming

column2: suicide bomber kills]] 30 people and injures 140 others at a hotel in [[Netanya]], [[Israel]],<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Ten years after Passover blast, survivors return to Park Hotel
column12: via=}}</ref> triggering [[Operation Defensive Shield]], a large-scale counter-terrorism operation in the [[West Bank]], two days later.<ref>{{Cite news
column14: title=UN report details West Bank wreckage

column1: * [[April 2]] – Israeli forces [[Siege of the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem
column2: besiege]] the [[Church of the Nativity]] in [[Bethlehem]], when militants took shelter there. The siege would last for 38 days.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: * [[April 9]] – The [[Funeral of Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother]] takes place at Westminster Abbey, London.
* [[April 15]] – [[Air China Flight 129]] crashes into a hillside during heavy rain and fog near [[Busan]], [[South Korea]], killing 129 people.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Search Continues At Korean Crash Site

column1: * [[April 25]] – South African [[Mark Shuttleworth]] blasts off from the [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] on the [[Soyuz TM-34]], becoming the first African space tourist.<ref>{{Cite news

column2: Buran]], the Russian equivalent to the Space Shuttle, is destroyed in a storm at [[Baikonur Cosmodrome

column4: title=East Timor celebrates as a nation is born

column1: * [[May 24]] – In Moscow, United States President [[George W. Bush]] and Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] sign the [[Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty]] to replace the [[Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty]] of [[1972]] and the [[START II
* [[May 25]] – A [[Boeing 747]] operating as [[China Airlines Flight 611]] breaks up and crashes in the [[Taiwan Strait]], killing all 225 passengers and crew on board.
* [[May 31]] – [[June 30]] – The [[2002 FIFA World Cup]] in South Korea and Japan;<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=The opening ceremony: as it happened
column10: access-date=2017-01-27}}</ref> which is ultimately won by Brazil.<ref>{{Cite web

column2: collides with Earth]] over the [[Mediterranean Sea
column3: Mediterranean]] and detonates in mid-air.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Near-Earth Objects Pose Threat, General Says

column1: * [[June 10]] – The first direct electronic communication experiment between the nervous systems of two humans is carried out by [[Kevin Warwick]] in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Nervous System Hookup Leads to Telepathic Hand-Holding

column1: * [[June 13]] – Afghanistan changes its official longform name to the [[Transitional Islamic State of Afghanistan]].<ref name=AFG_constitution>[http://president.gov.af/sroot_eng.aspx?id=68 Afghanistan ratified a new constitution on 26 Jan 2004] {{webarchive

column2: collides with a freight train]] in [[Dodoma Region]], [[Tanzania]], killing 281 people, making it the worst rail accident in African history.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: ** The [[Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court
column2: Rome Statute]] comes into force, thereby establishing the [[International Criminal Court]].<ref>{{Cite web

column2: collide]] over the town of [[Überlingen]], [[Germany]], killing 71 people.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Information regarding the air accident at Überlingen on 1 July 2002

column1: * [[July 9]] – The [[Organisation of African Unity]] is disbanded and replaced by the [[African Union]].<ref>{{Cite news

* [[July 27]] – [[Sknyliv air show disaster]]: 77 people are killed and 543 injured when a fighter jet crashes into spectators during an aerobatics presentation at Sknyliv airfield near Lviv, Ukraine. It is the deadliest air show accident in history.
* [[August 26]] – [[Earth Summit 2002]] begins in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]], aimed at discussing [[sustainable development]] by the [[United Nations]].<ref>{{Cite web
* [[September 10]] – Switzerland joins the [[United Nations]] as the 190th member state after rejecting a place in 1986.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=With Admission of Switzerland, United Nations Family Now Numbers 190 Member States

column4: title=Ivory Coast: Turmoil in a troubled country

column2: Vitim event]], a possible [[bolide]] impact, occurs in [[Irkutsk Oblast]], Russia.<ref>{{Cite web

column9: access-date=2016-06-04}}</ref> it also changes its official longform name from \"Democratic Republic of East Timor\" to \"Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste\".

column2: detonate multiple bombs]] in two nightclubs in [[Kuta]], [[Indonesia]], killing 202 people and injuring over 300 in the worst terrorist act in Indonesia's history.<ref>{{Cite news

column3: Chechen]] rebels take control of the ''[[Nord-Ost]]'' theatre in [[Moscow]] and [[Moscow theater hostage crisis
column4: hold the audience hostage]]. At least 170 people are killed following a Russian attempt to subdue the militants.<ref>{{Cite news
