column1: The [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]] was confirmed to have reached [[Moldova
column2: the Republic of Moldova]] on 7 March 2020. Data on cases presented in this article refers to the entire territory of the Republic of Moldova, including the [[Transnistria autonomous territorial unit
column3: Transnistrian region]], which is currently not controlled by the constitutional authorities of the Republic of Moldova.

column1: On 12 January, the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) confirmed that a [[novel coronavirus]] was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City, Hubei Province, China, who had initially come to the attention of the WHO on 31 December 2019.<ref name=\"Elsevier\">{{cite web
column14: title=What is coronavirus and how close is it to becoming a pandemic?

column3: case fatality ratio]] for COVID-19 <ref name=\"Imperial13March2020\">{{cite web
column12: title=High consequence infectious diseases (HCID); Guidance and information about high consequence infectious diseases and their management in England
column21: access-date=17 March 2020}}</ref> has been much lower, but the [[Transmission (medicine)
column22: transmission]] has been significantly greater, with a significant total death toll.<ref name=\"WFSA\">{{cite web
column24: title=World Federation Of Societies of Anaesthesiologists – Coronavirus

column1: {{2019–20 coronavirus pandemic data/Moldova medical cases chart}}

* '''27 January 2020''': the Minister of Health, Labor and Social Protection Mrs. Viorica Dumbrăveanu convened an extended meeting of the Commission for Exceptional Situations and Public Health Emergencies of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Social Protection. This meeting was also attended by representatives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the General Inspectorate of Border Police, the Customs Service, the National Insurance Company in Medicine, the National Food Safety Agency and the National Agency for Public Health. Participants discussed the measures to prevent and control the infection with the new type Coronavirus (2019-nCov), based on the epidemiological situation and the global spread of the infection.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-01-27_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column2: title=Viorica Dumbrăveanu a convocat ședința Comisiei pentru Situații excepționale și urgențe de sănătate publică cu privire la măsurile de prevenire și control a infecției cu Coronavirusul de tip nou
column3: trans-title=Viorica Dumbrăveanu convened the Commission for Exceptional Situations and Public Health Emergencies regarding the measures to prevent and control the infection with the new type Coronavirus
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''2 February 2020''': the Extraordinary National Commission of Public Health was convened by the [[Prime Minister of Moldova
column2: Prime Minister]] Mr. Ion Chicu.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Ion Chicu a convocat ședința Comisiei naționale extraordinară de sănătate publică
column4: trans-title=Ion Chicu convened the Extraordinary National Commission of Public Health
column7: publisher=Government of the Republic of Moldova
column10: date=29 March 2020}}</ref> The Commission has examined the information presented by the Ministry of Health, Labor and Social Protection and found that the epidemiological situation related to the infection with the novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) is tense, which has led the [[World Health Organization]] to declare a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. The Commission adopted the Decision No. 1 which provides, ''inter alia'', that risk assessment for public health will continue to be carried out with the attribution, if necessary, of the alert code resulting from the epidemiological situation related to the infection with the new Coronavirus (2019-nCoV).<ref name=\"Gov_Cornavirus_info\">{{cite web
column15: publisher=Governemnt of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''18 February 2020''': the National Agency for Public Health received from Germany, with the support of the World Health Organization, test kits to detect the virus that causes COVID-19.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-02-18_Press release\">{{cite web
column2: title=Testele pentru depistarea Coronavirusul de tip nou au ajuns în Republica Moldova
column3: trans-title=The tests for the detection of new Coronavirus have arrived in the Republic of Moldova
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova
column10: title=Recepţionarea kiturilor pentru depistarea Coronavirusului de tip nou (SARS-CoV-2)
column11: trans-title=Receiving kits for the detection of the new Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2)

column1: * '''24 February 2020''': the Extraordinary National Commission of Public Health was convened by the Prime-minister Mr. Ion Chicu.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Ion Chicu a convocat Comisia națională extraordinară de sănătate publică
column3: trans-title=Ion Chicu convened the Extraordinary National Commission of Public Health
column6: publisher=Government of the Republic of Moldova
column9: date=29 March 2020}}</ref> The Commission adopted the Decision No. 2 which provides, ''inter alia'', the establishment of the Code Yellow alert at national level in the context of the epidemiological situation related to COVID-19 infection and consideting the possible risk for a public health emergency.<ref name=\"Gov_Cornavirus_info\"/><ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-02-24_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column10: title=Viorica Dumbrăveanu: \"Îndemn populația să manifeste maximă responsabilitate și să respecte toate măsurile de igienă și precauție pentru a preveni îmbolnăvirea cu Coronavirus de tip nou\"
column11: trans-title=Viorica Dumbrăveanu: \"I urge the population to show maximum responsibility and to respect all the hygiene and precautionary measures to prevent illness with the new type Coronavirus\"
column14: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''25 February 2020''': the Republic of Moldova has put into action some anti-coronavirus measures.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Moldova prepares for an outbreak of coronavirus in the country

column1: The first coronavirus case in the Republic of Moldova was announced on 7 March 2020. The infected person is a 48-year-old woman who had returned to Moldova from Italy with the flight Milano-Chisinau. She had been taken to hospital immediately from the plane, being in a serious condition: bilateral bronchopneumonia, acute respiratory failure, fever, cough, general weakness. She suffers from a few chronical illnesses: diabetes, overweight and hypertension.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-07_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column2: title=MSMPS confirmă primul caz de Coronavirus de tip nou în Republica Moldova
column3: trans-title=MSMPS confirms first new-type coronavirus case in the Republic of Moldova
column6: publisher=[[Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection (Moldova)]]
column9: date=7 March 2020}}</ref> According to the [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection (Moldova)
column10: Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of Moldova]], she was diagnosed with bilateral bronchopneumonia, fever and cough on 4 March in Italy. She was prescribed antibiotic treatment at home and put in home quarantine pending confirmation of a new type of coronavirus infection, but she decided to return to Moldova.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-08_Press release_1\">{{cite web
column11: title=În Republica Moldova a fost confirmat primul caz de coronavirus. Se iau măsuri pentru limitarea răspândirii virusului
column12: trans-title=The first case of coronavirus in the Republic of Moldova has been confirmed. Measures are put into action to limit the spread of the virus
column15: publisher=[[Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection (Moldova)]]

column1: * '''8 March 2020''': the Extraordinary National Commission of Public Health established the Code Orange alert at national level in the context of the epidemiological situation related to COVID-19 infection.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-08_Press release_1\"/>

* '''10 March 2020''': the Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of Moldova confirmed another two cases (the 2nd and the 3rd) of coronavirus. The infected people are a woman and a man, both of them returned from Italy, on 26 February and 1 March, respectively.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-10_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column2: title=Alte două cazuri de îmbolnăviri cu infecția Coronovirus de tip nou, pe teritoriul țării. Viorica Dumbrăveanu îndeamnă cetățenii să respecte recomandările autorităților
column4: trans-title=Another two cases of a new-type coronavirus in a country. Viorica Dumbrăveanu urges citizens to respect the guidelines of authorities
column6: publisher=[[Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection (Moldova)]]
column9: date=10 March 2020}}</ref> On the same day all foreigners coming from the countries affected by coronavirus have been banned from entering Moldova by plane.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Moldova bans foreigners on all flights from countries with coronavirus

column1: * '''11 March 2020''': the 4th case has been confirmed.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Ultima oră: Încă un caz de coronavirus a fost confirmat; Bilanțul ajunge la 4 persoane
column8: date=11 March 2020}}</ref> Government announced that it closing all kindergartens, schools, colleges and universities for two weeks.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Moldova closes schools, universities to prevent virus spread

column1: * '''12 March 2020''': 2 new cases (the 5th and the 6th) were confirmed.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Ultima oră! Încă două cazuri de coronavirus, confirmate. Bilanțul în Moldova ajunge la 6 persoane
column8: date=12 March 2020}}</ref> As per 12 March 2020, there were no confirmed cases in the Transnistrian region,<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Массово не собираться, в школу не ходить. Уходим на карантин
column14: date=12 March 2020}}</ref> but 8 people were quarantined after returning from abroad.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=8 человек на карантине. Коронавирус и Приднестровье

column1: * '''13 March 2020''': the Extraordinary National Commission of Public Health established the Code Red alert at national level in the context of the epidemiological situation related to COVID-19 infection.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-13_Press release_4\">{{cite web
column2: title=A fost instituit cod roșu de alertă în legătură cu evoluția situației epidemiologice privind infecția cu Coronavirusul de tip nou pe teritoriul Republicii Moldova
column3: trans-title=A Code Red alert was established in relation to the evolution of the epidemiological situation regarding the infection with the new Coronavirus on the territory of the Republic of Moldova
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova
column9: date=13 March 2020}}</ref> During this day other 2 new cases (the 7th and the 8th) have been confirmed.<ref>{{cite web
column13: publisher=National Agency for Public Health of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''14 March 2020''': 4 new cases were confirmed. Thus, the total number of infected people reached 12.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Situația epidemiologică prin infecția cu Coronavirusul de tip nou (COVID-19), actualizat pe 14 martie 2020
column3: trans-title=Epidemiological situation related to the infection with the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), updated on 14 March 2020
column6: publisher=National Agency for Public Health of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''15 March 2020''': 11 new cases were confirmed. The total number of infected people reached 23.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Date actualizate cu privire la răspândirea noului tip de Coronavirus (COVID-19) în Republica Moldova și recomandări pentru populație
column3: trans-title=Updated information related to the spread of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in the Republic of Moldova and recommendations for the population
column6: publisher=National Agency for Public Health of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''16 March 2020''': 6 new cases were confirmed. The total number is 29. One woman recovered.
* '''17 March 2020''': the Parliament declared the state of emergency for the entire territory of the Republic of Moldova for a period of 60 days (17 March - 15 May 2020).<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Parlamentul a declarat stare de urgență pe perioada 17 martie – 15 mai 2020
column3: trans-title=The Parliament decared the state of emergency for the period 17 March - 15 May 2020
column6: publisher=Parliament of the Republic of Moldova
column9: date=17 March 2020}}</ref> During 17 March 2020, the 30th case has been confirmed.

column1: * '''18 March 2020''': the first death was confirmed, a 61-year-old woman who had travelled to Italy.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-18_Press release_1\">{{cite web
column2: title=Republica Moldova a înregistrat primul deces cauzat de noul coronavirus
column3: trans-title=The Republic of Moldova registered the first death from the new coronavirus
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova
column9: date=18 March 2020}}</ref> Another 6 new cases of infection have been confirmed.

column1: * '''19 March 2020''': 13 new cases were confirmed. The total number of infected people since 7 March 2020 reached 49.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-19_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column2: title=În Republica Moldova sunt înregistrate 49 cazuri de infecție cu COVID-19. Respectați recomandările autorităților. Stați acasă
column3: trans-title=The Republic of Moldova registered 49 cases of infections with COVID-19. Please respect the recommendations of authorities. Stay home
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''20 March 2020''': 17 new cases were confirmed, and the total number of infected people since 7 March 2020 reached 66.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-20_Press release_3\">{{cite web
column2: title= 17 cazuri de COVID-19 confirmate în ultimele 24 de ore
column3: trans-title=17 cases of COVID-19 confirmed during the last 24 hours
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova
column9: date=20 March 2020}}</ref> Upon the request of MoH, based on WHO Moldova recommendations short-list, Trimetrica LLC /www.trimetrica.com/ (ESRI Partner in Moldova) launched the customized ArcGIS Dashboard (an online platform) - allowing the real-time monitoring of COVID-19 cases in the Republic of Moldova. It's updated for 2 times per day.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-20_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column10: title= O nouă platformă lansată în Moldova permite monitorizarea cazurilor de COVID-19 în timp real
column11: trans-title=A new platform launched in Moldova allows real-time monitoring of COVID-19 cases
column14: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova
column17: date=20 March 2020}}</ref> The platform is accessible at this link: [http://gismoldova.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/d274da857ed345efa66e1fbc959b021b gismoldova.maps.arcgis.com]

column1: * '''21 March 2020''': 14 new cases were confirmed, the total number of infected people since 7 March 2020 reaching 80. Out of these 14 new cases, 2 cases were recorded for the first time in the Transnistrian region. At the same time, it was announced that the first person infected and confirmed in the Republic of Moldova (on 7 March 2020), was treated and transferred to another section for recovery against other chronic diseases. Thus, the number of recovered persons reached 2.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-21_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column2: title= 14 cazuri noi de infecție prin COVID-19 în Republica Moldova. Respectați recomandările medicilor. Stați acasă
column3: trans-title=14 new cases of infections with COVID-19. Please respect the recommendations of doctors. Stay home
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''27 March 2020''': the second death was confirmed, a 79 years old woman who was a doctor working at the Emergency Medical Assistance Service. She got sick on 19 March, and on 24 March she was admitted to the Republican Clinical Hospital, in serious condition. The patient suffered from several chronic diseases (diabetes, heart failure, high blood pressure).<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-27_Press release_1\">{{cite web
column2: title= Viorica Dumbrăveanu: \"În următoarea perioadă depinde de noi, întreaga societate, cum vom depăși provocarea epidemiei COVID-19. Fac apel la responsabilitate\"
column3: trans-title=Viorica Dumbrăveanu: “In the next period, it is up to us, the whole society, how we will overcome the challenge of the COVID-19 epidemic. I call for responsibility”
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova
column9: date=27 March 2020}}</ref> During 27 March 2020, 22 new cases were confirmed, the total number of infected people since 7 March 2020 reaching 199. On the same day, 3 patients recovered, the total number of recoveries reaching 5.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-27_Press release_2\">{{cite web
column10: title= Situația epidemiologică prin infecția COVID-19, 27 martie, ora 18.00
column11: trans-title=Epidemiological situation regarding the COVID-19 infection, 27 March, 18:00
column14: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''29 March 2020''': the third death was confirmed, a woman from the Transnistrian region.<ref name=\"UNIMEDIA_2020-03-31_Ultima_ora_inca_doua_decese\">{{cite web
column2: title= Ultimă oră! Încă două decese din cauza coronavirusului, confirmate în Republica Moldova
column3: trans-title=Breaking news! Two more deaths due to coronavirus, confirmed in the Republic of Moldova
column10: title= 55 cazuri noi de infecție cu noul tip de Coronavirus, în ultimele 24 de ore
column11: trans-title=55 new cases of infection with the new type of Coronavirus, in the last 24 hours
column14: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''31 March 2020''': after 280 tests were performed, a record number of 55 new cases were confirmed, of wich 48 cases were with local transmission, while 7 were import cases (of which 6 were from the United Kingdom and 1 from Austria). Thus, the total number of infected persons since 7 March 2020 reached 353. At the same time, 4 patients were treated and discharged from hospitals, the total number of recoveries reaching 22. Also, during 31 March 2020 the fourth death was confirmed, a man from the Briceni District of the Republic of Moldova.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-03-31_Press release_2\"/>
* '''1 April 2020''': the fifth death was confirmed, a person from the transnistrian region.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-04-01_Press release_4\">{{cite web
column2: title=70 cazuri noi de infecție cu noul tip de Coronavirus, în ultimele 24 de ore
column3: trans-title=70 new cases of infection with the new type of Coronavirus, in the last 24 hours
column6: publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection of the Republic of Moldova

column1: * '''2 April 2020''': the sixth death was confirmed, a 53-year-old person from Ștefan Vodă District, which was hospitalized in a hospital from Chișinău. The patient also suffered from other chronic diseases.<ref name=\"MSMPS_2020-04-02_Press release_3\">{{cite web

column1: '''Andersen Air Force Base (Andersen AFB, AAFB)''' {{airport codes
column4: UAM}} is a [[United States Air Force base]] located approximately {{convert
column8: Yigo]] near [[Agafo Gumas]] in the [[United States]] territory of [[Guam]]. Along with [[Naval Base Guam]], Andersen AFB was placed under the command of [[Joint Region Marianas]] on 1 October 2009.<ref name=\"JRM\">{{cite web
column15: archivedate=17 October 2012  }}</ref> The two bases are about 30 miles apart at opposite ends of the island. Administration offices for Joint Region Marianas are about half-way in between, at [[Nimitz Hill]].<ref name=\"JRM\" />

column1: The host unit at Andersen AFB is the '''[[36th Wing]] (36 WG)''', assigned to the [[Pacific Air Forces]] [[Eleventh Air Force]].  As a non-flying wing, the 36 WG's mission is to provide support to deployed air and space forces of USAF, foreign air forces to Andersen, and tenant units assigned to the base.

Andersen AFB was established in 1944 as '''North Field''' and is named for [[Brigadier General]] [[James Roy Andersen]] (1904–1945).  The 36th Wing Commander is Brig. Gen. Gentry W. Boswell.  The Vice Wing Commander is Colonel Matthew J. Nicholson and the Command Chief Master Sergeant is Chief Master Sergeant Jason T Heilman<ref>{{Cite web

The most important U.S. air base west of Hawaii, Andersen is the only one in the Western Pacific that can permanently base U.S. heavy strategic bombers (one of the four Air Force Bomber Forward Operating Locations),<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Air Force Base Runway Replacement Supports Global War on Terrorism
column5: website=Stanley Consultants}}</ref> including [[B-1B]], [[B-2]], and [[B-52]] bombers.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Why Is North Korea So Fixated on Guam?
column13: archivedate=24 September 2017}}</ref> Andersen is one of two critical bases in the Asia-Pacific region, the other being [[Diego Garcia]] in the Indian Ocean.  Due to Guam's almost unrestricted airspace and the close proximity of the [[Farallon de Medinilla
column14: Farallon de Medinilla Island]], a naval bombing range {{convert
column17: km}} north, the base is in an ideal training location.

column1: Andersen Air Force Base was established on 3 December 1944 and is named for Brigadier General James Roy Andersen (1904–1945).  General Andersen graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] in 1926, served at various army installations, and obtained his wings at [[Kelly AFB
column2: Kelly Field]], Texas, in 1936. During 1943–1944 he served on the War Department General Staff. In January 1945, General Andersen was assigned to HQ AAF, Pacific Ocean Area. He died on 26 February 1945 in the crash of a [[B-24 Liberator]] aircraft between [[Kwajalein]] and [[Johnston Island]] while en route to [[Hawaii]].

column1: Andersen Air Force Base's origins begin on 7 December 1941 when Guam was attacked by the armed forces of [[Imperial Japan]] in the [[Battle of Guam (1941)]] three hours after the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor]]. The United States Navy surrendered Guam to the Japanese on 10 December. At the height of the war, approximately 19,000 Japanese soldiers and sailors were deployed to the island. Guam was liberated by the [[United States Marine Corps
column2: United States Marine Corps']] 3rd Amphibious Corps on 21 July 1944, in the [[Battle of Guam (1944)]], after a 13-day pre-invasion bombardment.

column1: The Japanese managed to contain the Marines on two beachheads, but their counter-attack failed. The Marines renewed their assault, and reached the northern tip of the island on 10 August 1944.  Japanese guerrilla activities continued until the end of the war, and some were [[Japanese holdout
Guam was considered ideal to establish air bases to launch [[B-29 Superfortress]] operations against the [[Japanese Archipelago
column2: Japanese Home Islands]]. The [[Marianas Islands]] are about {{convert
column5: km}} from Tokyo, a range which the B-29s could just about manage. Most important of all, it could be put on a direct supply line from the United States by ship.  \"North Field,\" as Andersen AFB was first named, was the first air base built in Guam after its liberation. Its construction began in November 1944 and was supported by the [[United States Navy]] [[Seabee]]s.  North Field and its co-located [[Northwest Field (Guam)
column6: Northwest Field]] was a massive installation, with four main runways, taxiways, [[Revetment (aircraft)
column7: revetments]] for over 200 B-29s, and a large containment area for base operations and personnel.

column1: The first host unit at North Field was the [[314th Air Division
column2: 314th Bombardment Wing]], [[XXI Bomber Command]], [[Twentieth Air Force]].  The 314th arrived in Guam on 16 January 1945 from Peterson Field, Colorado.  The 314th controlled four operational B-29 bomb groups, the [[19th Air Refueling Wing

column1: B-29 Superfortress missions from North Field were attacks against strategic targets in Japan, operating in daylight and at a high altitude to bomb factories, refineries, and other objectives. In March 1945, the XXI Bomber Command changed tactics and started carrying out low-level night incendiary raids on area targets.  During the Allied assault on [[Okinawa]], groups of the 314th Bomb Wing attacked airfields from which the Japanese were sending out [[kamikaze
column2: suicide planes]] against the invasion force.

column1: Flying out of Guam, [[Henry E. Erwin
column2: S/Sgt Henry E Erwin]] of the 29th Bombardment Group was awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] for action that saved his B-29 during a mission over [[Koriyama]], Japan, on 12 April 1945. When a phosphorus smoke bomb exploded in the launching chute and shot back into the plane, Sgt Erwin picked up the burning bomb, carried it to a window, and threw it out.

column1: After the war, B-29s from North Field dropped food and supplies to Allied prisoners and participated in several show-of-force missions over Japan.  The 29th, 39th and 330th Bomb Groups returned to the United States and deactivated in December 1945. The 19th remained in Guam to become the station's host unit after the 314th Bomb Wing was reassigned to [[Johnson AB]], Japan for occupation duty.

column4: Northwest Field at Andersen Air Force Base]]

column1: After the end of [[World War II]], [[Guam]] served as a collection point for surplus war goods that had accumulated in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater

The [[19th Bombardment Wing]] (BW) was formed at North AFB in 1948 from the resources of the former North Guam Air Force Base Command (Provisional). The 19th BW operated [[Andersen AFB]] and continued utilizing B-29s. In May 1949, the headquarters of the [[Twentieth Air Force]] moved from Guam to [[Kadena AB]], [[Okinawa]]. Its former staff was assigned to the 19th BW.

At Andersen, the wing assumed responsibility for supervising two active bases and one semi-active base, an assortment of communication, weather, radar, rescue and other facilities and units, including the [[Marianas Air Material Area]], a wing size unit.<ref>Ravenstein, Charles A. ''Air Force Combat Wings Lineage and Honors Histories 1947–1977''. [[Maxwell Air Force Base]], [[Alabama]]: Office of Air Force History 1984. {{ISBN
column2: 0-912799-12-9}}.</ref> Many of the units and facilities were deactivated within a few months.

column1: In October 1949, the 19th Wing was transferred to the 20th Air Force's command. The remaining units in the Marianas and Bonin Islands were shifted to other organizations.  From 17 October 1949 until 28 June 1950, the wing continued B-29 training, operation of Andersen Air Force Base, and rescue and reconnaissance missions.
Three days after [[North Korea]] invaded [[South Korea]] in 1950, the 19th Bomb Group deployed [[B-29 Superfortress
column2: B-29s]] to Andersen to begin bombing targets throughout [[South Korea]]. A few days later, the group was detached from the 19th BW and deployed to [[Kadena Air Base]] on [[Okinawa Island]], Japan. The rest of the wing remained at Andersen, provided maintenance for transient aircraft, and operated ammunition dumps until 1953.

column1: In 1951, the [[Strategic Air Command]] (SAC) selected several overseas bases to support rotational unit deployments of its bombers from stateside bases, starting with [[B-29 Superfortress]] units and later including [[Convair B-36]], [[B-47 Stratojet]], [[B-50 Superfortress]] bombers, and [[Boeing KB-29

With decreased hostility in [[Korea]], the 19th BW headquarters was relocated to [[Kadena Air Base]], Japan in 1953 and was replaced by the 6319th Air Base Wing of the [[United States Far East Air Force
However, the [[United States Far East Air Force
column2: FEAF Bomber Command]] ([[United States Far East Air Force
column3: FEAF's]] 19th Bomb Wing and [[Strategic Air Command
column4: SAC's]] 98th and 307th Bomb Wings) was deactivated in 1954. Its three B-29 wings returned to the contiguous United States and were replaced with [[B-47 Stratojet

column1: The 3rd Air Division was activated on 18 June in its place. Its objective was to control all SAC units in the Far East. The division operated as a tenant unit from June 1954 until April 1955 and received host-base support services from the 6319th until that unit was inactivated on 1 April 1955. The 6319th was replaced with the SAC-aligned 3960th Air Base Wing.
The [[Strategic Air Command]] continued its 90-day unit rotational training program and began to take control of the base from the [[United States Far East Air Force
column2: FEAF]]. After the 1 April 1955 base transfer and activation of the 3960th Air Base Wing, [[B-47 Stratojet
column4: B-36s]] in the rotations. The 43rd Bomb Wing from [[Davis-Monthan Air Force Base]], [[Arizona]], operated from July to October 1957, which eventually became Andersen's host unit. The 3960th Air Base Wing was redesignated on 1 July 1956 as the 3960th Air Base Group.

column1: The [[41st Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]] of the [[United States Pacific Air Forces
column2: Pacific Air Forces]], along with its [[F-86 Sabre
column3: F-86s]], was stationed at Andersen from August 1956 until it was deactivated in March 1960. After that, the air defense mission was provided by deployments of [[Fifth Air Force
column4: Fifth]] and [[Thirteenth Air Force]] units flying the [[F-102 Delta Dagger

column1: Andersen's rotational duties concluded when the [[B-47 Stratojet
column2: B-47]] was phased out and replaced by the [[B-52 Stratofortress]]. The first [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: B-52]], the \"City of El Paso,\" arrived from the 95th Bomb Wing at [[Biggs Army Airfield
column4: Biggs Air Force Base]], Texas in March 1964. It was followed by [[KC-135 Stratotanker]]s.

column1: With the start of [[Operation Arc Light]] in June 1965, [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: KC-135As]] began regular bombing missions over [[Vietnam]] and continued until 1973, with a break between August 1970 and early 1972.

column1: In support of [[Operation Arc Light]], [[Strategic Air Command
column2: SAC]] activated the [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column3: 4133rd Bombardment Wing (Provisional)]] on 1 February 1966. The [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column4: 3960th Strategic Wing]], which was originally activated in 1955 as the 3960th Air Base Wing, continued as the base's host wing until it was deactivated and replaced by the [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column5: 43rd Strategic Wing]] on 1 April 1970. The 43rd assumed the mission of the 4133rd on 1 July 1970 and continued in this capacity until the 57th Air Division (Provisional) and [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column6: 72nd Strategic Wing (Provisional)]] were activated in June 1972 in support of '''Operation Bullet Shot'''<ref>{{cite web

column1: }}</ref> ([[military operation]] name for [[temporary duty assignment]] of US-based [[technician]]s — \"the herd shot 'round the world.\"<ref>{{cite web

column2: title       = USAF has hit Al Queda in Africa
work        = ARP For non HVAC topics

quote       = .... Participated in Operation Bulletshot (known affectionately as the herd shot 'round the world). We were given a 48-hour notification to launch the first aircraft from Dyess, bombers going to Guam and tankers to Okinawa.... We left on 89-day TDY orders and came back to Dyess for 30 days, then cycled back over, repeatedly till the end of the war. It was done that way for budgetary issues....

column1: }}</ref>). The 303rd Consolidated Aircraft Maintenance Wing (Provisional) was activated in July of the same year. All of the provisional units remained at Andersen until bombing missions ceased on 15 November 1973.

column3: About 150 B-52s at Andersen AFB, fall 1972]]

column1: [[Operation Linebacker II]] continued the mission of [[Operation Arc Light]], and was most notable for its 11-day bombing campaign between 18 and 29 December 1972, in which more than 150 [[B-52 Stratofortress
column2: B-52]] bombers flew 729 [[sortie]]s in 11 days. The [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: B-52s]] at Andersen, combined with other bombers stationed at [[U-Tapao International Airport
column4: U-Tapao Field]] in Thailand, constituted about 50 percent of [[Strategic Air Command
column5: SAC's]] total bomber force and 75 percent of all combat crews. Two bases contained the equivalent of 13 stateside bomber wings.

column1: The frequent bombings resulted in a cease-fire in [[Vietnam]]. However, the [[B-52 Stratofortress
column2: B-52s]] continued to fly missions over [[Cambodia]] and [[Laos]] until those were halted on 15 August 1973. With the end of these runs, more than 100 [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: B-52s]], both D and G Models, were deployed elsewhere in the world by October 1973. The [[Eighth Air Force]] moved to [[Barksdale Air Force Base]], [[Louisiana]], and the 3rd Air Division was reactivated on 1 January 1975.

column2: Communist]] forces overran [[South Vietnam]] later in 1975, the base provided emergency relief and shelter for thousands of [[Vietnamese people
column3: Vietnamese]] evacuees as a part of ''[[Operation New Life]]''. After the fall of [[Ho Chi Minh City
column4: Saigon]], Andersen received almost 40,000 refugees and processed another 109,000 for transportation to the United States.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: The base returned to routine operations by the late 1970s, but continued to serve as one of [[Strategic Air Command
column2: SAC's]] strategic locations. Crews and aircraft were regularly sent to sites between Australia, [[Alaska]], and [[Korea]] and supported sea surveillance operations support for the [[United States Navy

column1: Andersen was also home to the 54th Weather Reconnaissance Squadron \"Typhoon Chasers\" during the 1960s through the 1980s. Air crews flying [[WC-130]]s tracked and penetrated typhoons, providing advanced warnings to military and civilian populations throughout the western Pacific. During the Vietnam War, the 54th also provided cloud-seeding capability along the [[Ho Chi Minh Trail]] and synoptic reconnaissance, deploying from [[Udorn RTAFB]] when not in Guam. The 54th WRS was inactivated in September 1987.
In 1983, the 43rd completed its transition from the [[B-52 Stratofortress#B-52D
column3: B-52G]] and became one of only two [[Strategic Air Command
column4: SAC]] bomber wings equipped with the [[Boeing Harpoon

column1: The base saw a major change in 1989, when control transferred from the [[Strategic Air Command]] to [[Pacific Air Forces]]. The 633rd Air Base Wing activated on 1 October 1989, which led to the deactivations of the 43rd Bomb Wing on 26 March 1990 and the 60th Bombardment Squadron (Heavy) on 30 April 1990.
In August 1990, Andersen personnel began shipping over 37,000 tons of munitions to forces in the [[Persian Gulf]] in support of [[Gulf War
column5: title=Trump's plan to pay for border wall with Air Force funds risks national security, report says

column1: With the eruption of [[Mount Pinatubo]] in June 1991, Andersen was instrumental in caring for American evacuees and their pets as a part of [[Operation Fiery Vigil]]. In December, Andersen became home to the [[Thirteenth Air Force]], which had evacuated from [[Clark Air Base]] in the [[Philippines]] after the eruption.
[[File:B-2 and F-15 over Andersen Air Force Base.jpg

The host unit was changed on 1 October 1994, when the 633rd Air Base Wing was deactivated. The 36th Air Base Wing took over host operations and was redesignated as the [[36th Wing]] on 12 April 2006. In October 1994, the U.S. Navy's Helicopter Combat Support Squadron Five (HC-5) relocated to Andersen from the now-closed [[Naval Air Station Agana]], Guam.  HC-5 was later redesignated as Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron Twenty-Five ([[HSC-25]]) following its transition from the [[CH-46]] to the [[MH-60S]].
The base was one of the [[Space Shuttle#Landing sites
column2: few places in the world]] where the [[NASA]] [[Space Shuttle]] was permitted to land, serving as an Augmented Emergency Landing Site for the Shuttle orbiter.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2007, the 50-year-old South Runway's condition had deteriorated to a point at which complete removal and replacement of the runway was necessary to maintain safety. The 50.6 million-dollar runway replacement was a Design-Build project from the [[Air Force Civil Engineer Support Agency]] to the Tutor-Perini Corporation and its local subsidiary, Black Construction Company.<ref name=\":0\" /> The project's scope included demolition and reconstruction of the existing 11,185 feet by 200 feet South Runway, repairs and tie-ins to existing taxiway intersections, removal and replacement of degraded airfield lighting, and arresting gear realignment and reconstruction.
On 23 February 2008, a USAF [[B-2 Spirit]] stealth bomber, one of the most expensive military aircraft in the world, [[Andersen Air Force Base B-2 accident
column2: crashed on the base]].  Both pilots ejected safely before the plane, valued at {{formatprice
column3: 1400000000}} U.S. dollars, crashed moments after take-off due to a mechanical failure. This was the first time a B-2 had crashed.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7260231.stm US stealth bomber crashes on Guam] {{webarchive
column5: date=25 February 2008 }}, BBC News. Retrieved 23 February 2008.</ref>

column1: On 21 July 2008, a US [[B-52 Stratofortress]] [[2008 Guam B-52 crash
column2: crashed into the sea]] while on a training mission that was to fly over a parade in Guam commemorating the [[Battle of Guam (1944)
column3: U.S. liberation of the island from Japanese occupation in 1944]].
A B-52 Stratofortress and other planes flying over Guam in 2009]]

column1: B-2s and B-52 aircraft from the [[13th Bomb Squadron]] and [[393d Bomb Squadron]] have taken turns in order to provide a continuous bomber presence at the base. One four-month deployment involving four B-2s began in March 2009.<ref>Dumat-ol Daleno, Gaynor, \"Stealth Bombers to Deploy to Guam\", ''[[Pacific Daily News]]'', 27 February 2009.</ref>
In March 2009, the base announced that it would investigate allegations made by a whistleblower of environmental violations within the [[Guam National Wildlife Refuge#Military overlay units
column2: protected area]] of the base.  The allegations included poaching, illegal trapping of coconut crabs and resale of trophy deer, paving beaches, and stripping vegetation used for nesting by endangered hawksbill turtles and green sea turtles. [[Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility
column3: Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility (PEER)]] said, \"The Air Force program for protecting Guam's natural resources has utterly broken down.\"<ref>''[[Pacific Daily News]]'', \"Andersen To Review Alleged Environmental Violations\", 7 March 2009.</ref> The Department of Defense Inspector General (DOD IG) determined that the Air Force responses to the PEER allegations adequately addressed the issues raised.  Consequently, DoD IG determined further investigation was not warranted.

column1: The strategic importance of Andersen AFB was brought to the forefront on Tuesday, 12 February 2013 when the base was circled by two Russian [[Tupolev Tu-95
column2: Tupolev Tu-95 Bear-H bombers]] hours prior to [[President Obama]]'s [[State of the Union]] Address. Their flight was monitored by US [[McDonnell Douglas F-15E Strike Eagle
column3: F-15 fighter jets]]. The Russian bombers later left the area in a northbound direction.<ref>Gertz, Bill {{cite web
column10: date=15 February 2013 }}''The Washington Free Beacon'', retrieved 15 February 2013 \"Bear Bombers over Guam\"</ref>

column1: As tensions escalated between the U.S. and the North Korean regime, the latter threatened to strike the island.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=North Korea threatens strike on Guam
column9: archivedate=25 September 2017}}</ref> A total of 816,393 munitions assets valued at over 95 million dollars were delivered to Andersen Air Force Base between 21 August and 30 September 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=U.S. Sends Hundreds of Thousands of Bombs To Guam as North Korea Threat Looms

column1: In early 2019, the main operational and flying units on the base included the [[36th Wing]] (PACAF), elements of the [[624th Regional Support Group]],<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2019-05-12}}</ref> the 734th Air Mobility Support Squadron (Air Mobility Command),<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=734th Air Mobility Squadron}}</ref> Detachment 1, [[69th Reconnaissance Group]], flying the [[Northrop Grumman RQ-4 Global Hawk]],<ref>{{Cite web
column12: access-date=2019-05-12}}</ref> and the Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron Two-Five ([[HSC-25]]), [[United States Navy

column4: A B-52 from Barksdale AFB takes off from Andersen in 2007]]

column1: Andersen Air Force Base is home to Andersen Elementary School and [[Andersen Middle School]]. High school students attend [[Guam High School (Guam)

Higher educational opportunities are available for those in the military, Department of Defense employees, and family members at Andersen through contracted academic institutions such as The Asian Division of [[University of Maryland University College]] (UMUC)<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=University of Maryland University College Asia - UMUC Asia
column8: archivedate=27 February 2014  }}</ref> and The Pacific Far East Division of [[Central Texas College]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Pacific Far East - Central Texas College

column1: Andersen Middle School caters to a population of 6th to 8th graders from [[United States
column2: American]] military families.  The school is within the [[Department of Defense Education Activity]] school system and the subsystem [[DDESS]] Guam. It has a 5-year accreditation obtained from the [[North Central Association of Colleges and Schools]].  In September 1997, DoDEA opened its own schools for children of military personnel.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Guam School to Be Renamed in Honor of NASA Astronaut William McCool}}</ref>

column1: Andersen Middle School's sports include volleyball, cross country, softball, soccer, and basketball.

Andersen Middle School was founded in 1997 and was scattered across Andersen Air Force Base.  Classes for the original school were held in former Air Force dormitories. Many rooms had walls knocked out in order to accommodate class sizes. The original library for the elementary school was shared with the base library for its first year.  As of 2012, it is now permanently located in an air conditioned building.
Andersen Middle School adopted the [[block scheduling]] system. The required core classes are [[physical education]], [[mathematics]], [[science]], [[social studies]], [[Reading (process)
column2: reading]], and [[language arts]]. The elective classes include [[Spanish language
column4: band]], [[study skills]], [[video production]], [[culture]] and [[drama]]. The school offers both a [[special education]] program and opportunities to take high school courses, such as [[algebra]] and [[geometry]].

column1: '''Andersen Air Force Base (Andersen AFB, AAFB)''' {{airport codes
column4: UAM}} is a [[United States Air Force base]] located approximately {{convert
column8: Yigo]] near [[Agafo Gumas]] in the [[United States]] territory of [[Guam]]. Along with [[Naval Base Guam]], Andersen AFB was placed under the command of [[Joint Region Marianas]] on 1 October 2009.<ref name=\"JRM\">{{cite web
column15: archivedate=17 October 2012  }}</ref> The two bases are about 30 miles apart at opposite ends of the island. Administration offices for Joint Region Marianas are about half-way in between, at [[Nimitz Hill]].<ref name=\"JRM\" />

column1: The host unit at Andersen AFB is the '''[[36th Wing]] (36 WG)''', assigned to the [[Pacific Air Forces]] [[Eleventh Air Force]].  As a non-flying wing, the 36 WG's mission is to provide support to deployed air and space forces of USAF, foreign air forces to Andersen, and tenant units assigned to the base.

Andersen AFB was established in 1944 as '''North Field''' and is named for [[Brigadier General]] [[James Roy Andersen]] (1904–1945).  The 36th Wing Commander is Brig. Gen. Gentry W. Boswell.  The Vice Wing Commander is Colonel Matthew J. Nicholson and the Command Chief Master Sergeant is Chief Master Sergeant Jason T Heilman<ref>{{Cite web

The most important U.S. air base west of Hawaii, Andersen is the only one in the Western Pacific that can permanently base U.S. heavy strategic bombers (one of the four Air Force Bomber Forward Operating Locations),<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Air Force Base Runway Replacement Supports Global War on Terrorism
column5: website=Stanley Consultants}}</ref> including [[B-1B]], [[B-2]], and [[B-52]] bombers.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Why Is North Korea So Fixated on Guam?
column13: archivedate=24 September 2017}}</ref> Andersen is one of two critical bases in the Asia-Pacific region, the other being [[Diego Garcia]] in the Indian Ocean.  Due to Guam's almost unrestricted airspace and the close proximity of the [[Farallon de Medinilla
column14: Farallon de Medinilla Island]], a naval bombing range {{convert
column17: km}} north, the base is in an ideal training location.

column1: Andersen Air Force Base was established on 3 December 1944 and is named for Brigadier General James Roy Andersen (1904–1945).  General Andersen graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] in 1926, served at various army installations, and obtained his wings at [[Kelly AFB
column2: Kelly Field]], Texas, in 1936. During 1943–1944 he served on the War Department General Staff. In January 1945, General Andersen was assigned to HQ AAF, Pacific Ocean Area. He died on 26 February 1945 in the crash of a [[B-24 Liberator]] aircraft between [[Kwajalein]] and [[Johnston Island]] while en route to [[Hawaii]].

column1: Andersen Air Force Base's origins begin on 7 December 1941 when Guam was attacked by the armed forces of [[Imperial Japan]] in the [[Battle of Guam (1941)]] three hours after the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor]]. The United States Navy surrendered Guam to the Japanese on 10 December. At the height of the war, approximately 19,000 Japanese soldiers and sailors were deployed to the island. Guam was liberated by the [[United States Marine Corps
column2: United States Marine Corps']] 3rd Amphibious Corps on 21 July 1944, in the [[Battle of Guam (1944)]], after a 13-day pre-invasion bombardment.

column1: The Japanese managed to contain the Marines on two beachheads, but their counter-attack failed. The Marines renewed their assault, and reached the northern tip of the island on 10 August 1944.  Japanese guerrilla activities continued until the end of the war, and some were [[Japanese holdout
Guam was considered ideal to establish air bases to launch [[B-29 Superfortress]] operations against the [[Japanese Archipelago
column2: Japanese Home Islands]]. The [[Marianas Islands]] are about {{convert
column5: km}} from Tokyo, a range which the B-29s could just about manage. Most important of all, it could be put on a direct supply line from the United States by ship.  \"North Field,\" as Andersen AFB was first named, was the first air base built in Guam after its liberation. Its construction began in November 1944 and was supported by the [[United States Navy]] [[Seabee]]s.  North Field and its co-located [[Northwest Field (Guam)
column6: Northwest Field]] was a massive installation, with four main runways, taxiways, revetments for over 200 B-29s, and a large containment area for base operations and personnel.

column1: The first host unit at North Field was the [[314th Air Division
column2: 314th Bombardment Wing]], [[XXI Bomber Command]], [[Twentieth Air Force]].  The 314th arrived in Guam on 16 January 1945 from Peterson Field, Colorado.  The 314th controlled four operational B-29 bomb groups, the [[19th Air Refueling Wing

column1: B-29 Superfortress missions from North Field were attacks against strategic targets in Japan, operating in daylight and at a high altitude to bomb factories, refineries, and other objectives. In March 1945, the XXI Bomber Command changed tactics and started carrying out low-level night incendiary raids on area targets.  During the Allied assault on [[Okinawa]], groups of the 314th Bomb Wing attacked airfields from which the Japanese were sending out [[kamikaze
column2: suicide planes]] against the invasion force.

column1: Flying out of Guam, [[Henry E. Erwin
column2: S/Sgt Henry E Erwin]] of the 29th Bombardment Group was awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] for action that saved his B-29 during a mission over [[Koriyama]], Japan, on 12 April 1945. When a phosphorus smoke bomb exploded in the launching chute and shot back into the plane, Sgt Erwin picked up the burning bomb, carried it to a window, and threw it out.

column1: After the war, B-29s from North Field dropped food and supplies to Allied prisoners and participated in several show-of-force missions over Japan.  The 29th, 39th and 330th Bomb Groups returned to the United States and deactivated in December 1945. The 19th remained in Guam to become the station's host unit after the 314th Bomb Wing was reassigned to [[Johnson AB]], Japan for occupation duty.

column4: Northwest Field at Andersen Air Force Base]]

column1: After the end of [[World War II]], [[Guam]] served as a collection point for surplus war goods that had accumulated in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater

The [[19th Bombardment Wing]] (BW) was formed at North AFB in 1948 from the resources of the former North Guam Air Force Base Command (Provisional). The 19th BW operated [[Andersen AFB]] and continued utilizing B-29s. In May 1949, the headquarters of the [[Twentieth Air Force]] moved from Guam to [[Kadena AB]], [[Okinawa]]. Its former staff was assigned to the 19th BW.

At Andersen, the wing assumed responsibility for supervising two active bases and one semi-active base, an assortment of communication, weather, radar, rescue and other facilities and units, including the [[Marianas Air Material Area]], a wing size unit.<ref>Ravenstein, Charles A. ''Air Force Combat Wings Lineage and Honors Histories 1947–1977''. [[Maxwell Air Force Base]], [[Alabama]]: Office of Air Force History 1984. {{ISBN
column2: 0-912799-12-9}}.</ref> Many of the units and facilities were deactivated within a few months.

column1: In October 1949, the 19th Wing was transferred to the 20th Air Force's command. The remaining units in the Marianas and Bonin Islands were shifted to other organizations.  From 17 October 1949 until 28 June 1950, the wing continued B-29 training, operation of Andersen Air Force Base, and rescue and reconnaissance missions.
Three days after [[North Korea]] invaded [[South Korea]] in 1950, the 19th Bomb Group deployed [[B-29 Superfortress
column2: B-29s]] to Andersen to begin bombing targets throughout [[South Korea]]. A few days later, the group was detached from the 19th BW and deployed to [[Kadena Air Base]] on [[Okinawa Island]], Japan. The rest of the wing remained at Andersen, provided maintenance for transient aircraft, and operated ammunition dumps until 1953.

column1: In 1951, the [[Strategic Air Command]] (SAC) selected several overseas bases to support rotational unit deployments of its bombers from stateside bases, starting with [[B-29 Superfortress]] units and later including [[Convair B-36]], [[B-47 Stratojet]], [[B-50 Superfortress]] bombers, and [[Boeing KB-29

With decreased hostility in [[Korea]], the 19th BW headquarters was relocated to [[Kadena Air Base]], Japan in 1953 and was replaced by the 6319th Air Base Wing of the [[United States Far East Air Force
However, the [[United States Far East Air Force
column2: FEAF Bomber Command]] ([[United States Far East Air Force
column3: FEAF's]] 19th Bomb Wing and [[Strategic Air Command
column4: SAC's]] 98th and 307th Bomb Wings) was deactivated in 1954. Its three B-29 wings returned to the contiguous United States and were replaced with [[B-47 Stratojet

column1: The 3rd Air Division was activated on 18 June in its place. Its objective was to control all SAC units in the Far East. The division operated as a tenant unit from June 1954 until April 1955 and received host-base support services from the 6319th until that unit was inactivated on 1 April 1955. The 6319th was replaced with the SAC-aligned 3960th Air Base Wing.
The [[Strategic Air Command]] continued its 90-day unit rotational training program and began to take control of the base from the [[United States Far East Air Force
column2: FEAF]]. After the 1 April 1955 base transfer and activation of the 3960th Air Base Wing, [[B-47 Stratojet
column4: B-36s]] in the rotations. The 43rd Bomb Wing from [[Davis-Monthan Air Force Base]], [[Arizona]], operated from July to October 1957, which eventually became Andersen's host unit. The 3960th Air Base Wing was redesignated on 1 July 1956 as the 3960th Air Base Group.

column1: The [[41st Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]] of the [[United States Pacific Air Forces
column2: Pacific Air Forces]], along with its [[F-86 Sabre
column3: F-86s]], was stationed at Andersen from August 1956 until it was deactivated in March 1960. After that, the air defense mission was provided by deployments of [[Fifth Air Force
column4: Fifth]] and [[Thirteenth Air Force]] units flying the [[F-102 Delta Dagger

column1: Andersen's rotational duties concluded when the [[B-47 Stratojet
column2: B-47]] was phased out and replaced by the [[B-52 Stratofortress]]. The first [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: B-52]], the \"City of El Paso,\" arrived from the 95th Bomb Wing at [[Biggs Army Airfield
column4: Biggs Air Force Base]], Texas in March 1964. It was followed by [[KC-135 Stratotanker]]s.

column1: With the start of [[Operation Arc Light]] in June 1965, [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: KC-135As]] began regular bombing missions over [[Vietnam]] and continued until 1973, with a break between August 1970 and early 1972.

column1: In support of [[Operation Arc Light]], [[Strategic Air Command
column2: SAC]] activated the [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column3: 4133rd Bombardment Wing (Provisional)]] on 1 February 1966. The [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column4: 3960th Strategic Wing]], which was originally activated in 1955 as the 3960th Air Base Wing, continued as the base's host wing until it was deactivated and replaced by the [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column5: 43rd Strategic Wing]] on 1 April 1970. The 43rd assumed the mission of the 4133rd on 1 July 1970 and continued in this capacity until the 57th Air Division (Provisional) and [[List of USAF Strategic Wings assigned to the Strategic Air Command
column6: 72nd Strategic Wing (Provisional)]] were activated in June 1972 in support of '''Operation Bullet Shot'''<ref>{{cite web

column1: }}</ref> ([[military operation]] name for [[temporary duty assignment]] of US-based [[technician]]s — \"the herd shot 'round the world.\"<ref>{{cite web

column2: title       = USAF has hit Al Queda in Africa
work        = ARP For non HVAC topics

quote       = .... Participated in Operation Bulletshot (known affectionately as the herd shot 'round the world). We were given a 48-hour notification to launch the first aircraft from Dyess, bombers going to Guam and tankers to Okinawa.... We left on 89-day TDY orders and came back to Dyess for 30 days, then cycled back over, repeatedly till the end of the war. It was done that way for budgetary issues....

column1: }}</ref>). The 303rd Consolidated Aircraft Maintenance Wing (Provisional) was activated in July of the same year. All of the provisional units remained at Andersen until bombing missions ceased on 15 November 1973.

column3: About 150 B-52s at Andersen AFB, fall 1972]]

column1: [[Operation Linebacker II]] continued the mission of [[Operation Arc Light]], and was most notable for its 11-day bombing campaign between 18 and 29 December 1972, in which more than 150 [[B-52 Stratofortress
column2: B-52]] bombers flew 729 [[sortie]]s in 11 days. The [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: B-52s]] at Andersen, combined with other bombers stationed at [[U-Tapao International Airport
column4: U-Tapao Field]] in Thailand, constituted about 50 percent of [[Strategic Air Command
column5: SAC's]] total bomber force and 75 percent of all combat crews. Two bases contained the equivalent of 13 stateside bomber wings.

column1: The frequent bombings resulted in a cease-fire in [[Vietnam]]. However, the [[B-52 Stratofortress
column2: B-52s]] continued to fly missions over [[Cambodia]] and [[Laos]] until those were halted on 15 August 1973. With the end of these runs, more than 100 [[B-52 Stratofortress
column3: B-52s]], both D and G Models, were deployed elsewhere in the world by October 1973. The [[Eighth Air Force]] moved to [[Barksdale Air Force Base]], [[Louisiana]], and the 3rd Air Division was reactivated on 1 January 1975.

column2: Communist]] forces overran [[South Vietnam]] later in 1975, the base provided emergency relief and shelter for thousands of [[Vietnamese people
column3: Vietnamese]] evacuees as a part of ''[[Operation New Life]]''. After the fall of [[Ho Chi Minh City
column4: Saigon]], Andersen received almost 40,000 refugees and processed another 109,000 for transportation to the United States.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: The base returned to routine operations by the late 1970s, but continued to serve as one of [[Strategic Air Command
column2: SAC's]] strategic locations. Crews and aircraft were regularly sent to sites between Australia, [[Alaska]], and [[Korea]] and supported sea surveillance operations support for the [[United States Navy

column1: Andersen was also home to the 54th Weather Reconnaissance Squadron \"Typhoon Chasers\" during the 1960s through the 1980s. Air crews flying [[WC-130]]s tracked and penetrated typhoons, providing advanced warnings to military and civilian populations throughout the western Pacific. During the Vietnam War, the 54th also provided cloud-seeding capability along the [[Ho Chi Minh Trail]] and synoptic reconnaissance, deploying from [[Udorn RTAFB]] when not in Guam. The 54th WRS was inactivated in September 1987.
In 1983, the 43rd completed its transition from the [[B-52 Stratofortress#B-52D
column3: B-52G]] and became one of only two [[Strategic Air Command
column4: SAC]] bomber wings equipped with the [[Boeing Harpoon

column1: The base saw a major change in 1989, when control transferred from the [[Strategic Air Command]] to [[Pacific Air Forces]]. The 633rd Air Base Wing activated on 1 October 1989, which led to the deactivations of the 43rd Bomb Wing on 26 March 1990 and the 60th Bombardment Squadron (Heavy) on 30 April 1990.
In August 1990, Andersen personnel began shipping over 37,000 tons of munitions to forces in the [[Persian Gulf]] in support of [[Gulf War
column5: title=Trump's plan to pay for border wall with Air Force funds risks national security, report says

column1: With the eruption of [[Mount Pinatubo]] in June 1991, Andersen was instrumental in caring for American evacuees and their pets as a part of [[Operation Fiery Vigil]]. In December, Andersen became home to the [[Thirteenth Air Force]], which had evacuated from [[Clark Air Base]] in the [[Philippines]] after the eruption.
[[File:B-2 and F-15 over Andersen Air Force Base.jpg

The host unit was changed on 1 October 1994, when the 633rd Air Base Wing was deactivated. The 36th Air Base Wing took over host operations and was redesignated as the [[36th Wing]] on 12 April 2006. In October 1994, the U.S. Navy's Helicopter Combat Support Squadron Five (HC-5) relocated to Andersen from the now-closed [[Naval Air Station Agana]], Guam.  HC-5 was later redesignated as Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron Twenty-Five ([[HSC-25]]) following its transition from the [[CH-46]] to the [[MH-60S]].
The base was one of the [[Space Shuttle#Landing sites
column2: few places in the world]] where the [[NASA]] [[Space Shuttle]] was permitted to land, serving as an Augmented Emergency Landing Site for the Shuttle orbiter.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2007, the 50-year-old South Runway's condition had deteriorated to a point at which complete removal and replacement of the runway was necessary to maintain safety. The 50.6 million-dollar runway replacement was a Design-Build project from the [[Air Force Civil Engineer Support Agency]] to the Tutor-Perini Corporation and its local subsidiary, Black Construction Company.<ref name=\":0\" /> The project's scope included demolition and reconstruction of the existing 11,185 feet by 200 feet South Runway, repairs and tie-ins to existing taxiway intersections, removal and replacement of degraded airfield lighting, and arresting gear realignment and reconstruction.
On 23 February 2008, a USAF [[B-2 Spirit]] stealth bomber, one of the most expensive military aircraft in the world, [[Andersen Air Force Base B-2 accident
column2: crashed on the base]].  Both pilots ejected safely before the plane, valued at {{formatprice
column3: 1400000000}} U.S. dollars, crashed moments after take-off due to a mechanical failure. This was the first time a B-2 had crashed.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7260231.stm US stealth bomber crashes on Guam] {{webarchive
column5: date=25 February 2008 }}, BBC News. Retrieved 23 February 2008.</ref>

column1: On 21 July 2008, a US [[B-52 Stratofortress]] [[2008 Guam B-52 crash
column2: crashed into the sea]] while on a training mission that was to fly over a parade in Guam commemorating the [[Battle of Guam (1944)
column3: U.S. liberation of the island from Japanese occupation in 1944]].
A B-52 Stratofortress and other planes flying over Guam in 2009]]

column1: B-2s and B-52 aircraft from the [[13th Bomb Squadron]] and [[393d Bomb Squadron]] have taken turns in order to provide a continuous bomber presence at the base. One four-month deployment involving four B-2s began in March 2009.<ref>Dumat-ol Daleno, Gaynor, \"Stealth Bombers to Deploy to Guam\", ''[[Pacific Daily News]]'', 27 February 2009.</ref>
In March 2009, the base announced that it would investigate allegations made by a whistleblower of environmental violations within the [[Guam National Wildlife Refuge#Military overlay units
column2: protected area]] of the base.  The allegations included poaching, illegal trapping of coconut crabs and resale of trophy deer, paving beaches, and stripping vegetation used for nesting by endangered hawksbill turtles and green sea turtles. [[Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility
column3: Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility (PEER)]] said, \"The Air Force program for protecting Guam's natural resources has utterly broken down.\"<ref>''[[Pacific Daily News]]'', \"Andersen To Review Alleged Environmental Violations\", 7 March 2009.</ref> The Department of Defense Inspector General (DOD IG) determined that the Air Force responses to the PEER allegations adequately addressed the issues raised.  Consequently, DoD IG determined further investigation was not warranted.

column1: The strategic importance of Andersen AFB was brought to the forefront on Tuesday, 12 February 2013 when the base was circled by two Russian [[Tupolev Tu-95
column2: Tupolev Tu-95 Bear-H bombers]] hours prior to [[President Obama]]'s [[State of the Union]] Address. Their flight was monitored by US [[McDonnell Douglas F-15E Strike Eagle
column3: F-15 fighter jets]]. The Russian bombers later left the area in a northbound direction.<ref>Gertz, Bill {{cite web
column10: date=15 February 2013 }}''The Washington Free Beacon'', retrieved 15 February 2013 \"Bear Bombers over Guam\"</ref>

column1: As tensions escalated between the U.S. and the North Korean regime, the latter threatened to strike the island.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=North Korea threatens strike on Guam
column9: archivedate=25 September 2017}}</ref> A total of 816,393 munitions assets valued at over 95 million dollars were delivered to Andersen Air Force Base between 21 August and 30 September 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=U.S. Sends Hundreds of Thousands of Bombs To Guam as North Korea Threat Looms

column12: access-date=2019-05-12}}</ref> and the Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron Two-Five ([[HSC-25]]), [[United States Navy

column1: Andersen Air Force Base is home to Andersen Elementary School and [[Andersen Middle School]]. High school students attend [[Guam High School (Guam)

Higher educational opportunities are available for those in the military, Department of Defense employees, and family members at Andersen through contracted academic institutions such as The Asian Division of [[University of Maryland University College]] (UMUC)<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=University of Maryland University College Asia - UMUC Asia
column8: archivedate=27 February 2014  }}</ref> and The Pacific Far East Division of [[Central Texas College]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Pacific Far East - Central Texas College

column1: Andersen Middle School caters to a population of 6th to 8th graders from [[United States
column2: American]] military families.  The school is within the [[Department of Defense Education Activity]] school system and the subsystem [[DDESS]] Guam. It has a 5-year accreditation obtained from the [[North Central Association of Colleges and Schools]].  In September 1997, DoDEA opened its own schools for children of military personnel.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Guam School to Be Renamed in Honor of NASA Astronaut William McCool}}</ref>

column1: Andersen Middle School's sports include volleyball, cross country, softball, soccer, and basketball.

Andersen Middle School was founded in 1997 and was scattered across Andersen Air Force Base.  Classes for the original school were held in former Air Force dormitories. Many rooms had walls knocked out in order to accommodate class sizes. The original library for the elementary school was shared with the base library for its first year.  As of 2012, it is now permanently located in an air conditioned building.
Andersen Middle School adopted the [[block scheduling]] system. The required core classes are [[physical education]], [[mathematics]], [[science]], [[social studies]], [[Reading (process)
column2: reading]], and [[language arts]]. The elective classes include [[Spanish language
column4: band]], [[study skills]], [[video production]], [[culture]] and [[drama]]. The school offers both a [[special education]] program and opportunities to take high school courses, such as [[algebra]] and [[geometry]].
